title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Shoppers have said they hope a council's plans for a deserted store will boost the appeal of their high street.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: The mayor of Bedford has outlined plans to convert a former Debenhams - purchased by a council for about £1.8m - into smaller commercial spaces and housing.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Tom Wootton, the elected Conservative mayor, said: "It's going make a difference to the town - it's going to bring people in."

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Supporting the proposed redevelopment, Alex Reader, 29, from Bedford, commented: "We need a reason to come into town."

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Mr Wootton said the short term plan was to get businesses into the space by Christmas and the long term plan was to keep the outside, knock it down inside and "build shops on the ground floor and flats and apartments above".

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: He said Bedford Borough Council purchased the property, which closed in May 2021, "very cheap because it was so run down" and the money had come from "earmarked reserves" and the former government's Towns Fund project.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: "It's a massive space, a massive part of Bedford, part of Bedford's history, but also Bedford's future because you cannot have this sort of size of place in the middle of the high street shut up for years."

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: He said by the end of the year smaller shopping spaces would be created and he wanted anyone with ideas to "come and talk to us - we're all ears".

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Mr Wootton said the renovation was "going to cost a lot of money" as the building was water damaged.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: "We're really keen that we get people living in town, as that's the thing that is going to pay for this redevelopment," he added.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Giving her reaction, Ms Reader, who was in the town centre, said: "I think it's important that we start reopening these shops.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: "It's an eyesore when you just see shut doors."

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: She said she would prefer to see "family-orientated" businesses, such as play areas.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Lauren Steels, 32, a mother from the town, said she wanted to see "more local stores and less chains, more of a market town look".

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: "We've got lots of cafes and restaurants. It would be nice to have something a bit unique and bit different and something to entertain, not just shops."

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Wasem Sebi, founder of Simply Creative Agency on Bedford High Street, said: "Ensuring the right mix of retail and residential space is crucial to meet the needs of the Bedford community without over-saturating the housing sector."

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: He said the plans could "transform" the area, bring "new life to the town centre" and could help create "a more dynamic and diverse urban environment".

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Kay Orton said she rarely came into town since Marks & Spencer closed its doors in May 2019.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: She said converting the empty store was "positive" but it "all depends what the shops are".

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: She said more variety could coax her back to the town centre.

title: Bedford Debenhams plan: 'We need a reason to come into town' - BBC News
text: Follow Beds, Herts and Bucks news on BBC Sounds, Facebook, external, Instagram, external and X, external.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: The Spectator has been sold for £100m to Sir Paul Marshall, a hedge fund tycoon and major investor in GB News.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: He beat around 20 other bidders to buy the right-leaning magazine, once edited by former Prime Minister Boris Johnson.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: It went back on sale in April after an Abu Dhabi-backed bid to buy it along with the Daily Telegraph and the Sunday Telegraph collapsed.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: This came after the government intervened in January. Legislation banning foreign states from owning UK newspapers soon followed.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: That deal would have transferred the ownership to the Gulf-backed Redbird IMI consortium.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: The Telegraph newspapers remain for sale, and Sir Paul is also in the running to buy those as he continues his bid to build an empire of right-wing media outlets.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: Others thought to be among the bidders include Rupert Murdoch’s News UK and former chancellor Nadhim Zahawi.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: After the deal was announced, Spectator chairman Andrew Neil said he would resign with immediate effect, having previously stated that hedge funds should not be allowed to own news publications because of the risk of conflict of interest.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: "I made it clear many months ago that I would step down when a new owner took over. That time has now come," he posted on X, external, formerly Twitter.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: The Spectator was established in 1828, making it one of the oldest politics and current affairs magazines in the world.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: Sir Paul, who is buying the magazine through his Old Queen Street (OQS) media group, said: “As a long-term Spectator reader, I am delighted it is joining the OQS stable.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: "The plan is for OQS to make good previous underinvestment in one of the world’s great titles."

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: Sir Paul started work in the City and set up his own hedge fund with business partner Ian Wace in 1997. According to Wace, a "considerable proportion" of the first $50m they had under management came from the famous investor and philanthropist George Soros.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: Worth an estimated £875m, Sir Paul is not that well known outside the financial and political worlds. He is probably less famous than his son Winston, a former member of the folk-rock band Mumford & Sons.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: A devout Christian, Sir Paul is also known for his philanthropy, co-founding the children's educational charity ARK, and donating millions to set up the Marshall Institute for Philanthropy and Social Entrepreneurship.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: In 2016 he was knighted for services to education and philanthropy.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: Politically, he was a member of the Liberal Democrats for many years, and in 1987 he stood to be an MP for the SDP, a forerunner of the party.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: By 2016 his allegiance had switched to the Conservative Party and he was a supporter of Brexit, donating £100,000 to the Leave campaign.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: In 2017 he founded the news website UnHerd, and he has invested tens of millions of pounds in GB News since its launch in 2021.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: Earlier this year he was accused of liking or reposting tweets that appeared to be anti-Muslim in sentiment. He apologised and said the tweets were not representative of his views, but he was widely criticised. Former Guardian editor Alan Rusbridger said the "hateful ‘likes’ make him unfit to be a media mogul, external".

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: LISTEN: Profile - Sir Paul Marshall

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: Current Spectator editor Fraser Nelson told the BBC's World at One programme he felt "pretty confident" about the new owner.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: "What you want in a proprietor is somebody who is willing to invest, who is willing to have the confidence in what the journalists are doing, and also is willing to protect editorial independence. And there’s not the slightest suggestion that Paul Marshall isn’t willing to do that," he said.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: "The idea that he’s going to turn it into anything other than the journalistic enterprise which it is is just for the birds."

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: The Spectator and the Telegraph papers were put up for sale last year when they were seized by Lloyds Banking Group from long-time owners the Barclay family, who had failed to pay back a loan of more than £1bn.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: They were sold to RedBird IMI in a deal which valued the publications at around £600m, before the government intervened and passed legislation, prompting RedBird to halt the takeover and put them back up for sale.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: As a weekly news publication, the Spectator is not defined as a "newspaper" under the Enterprise Act and therefore does not fall within scope of the culture secretary’s powers to examine media mergers in the public interest.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: "It is essential that the availability of a wide range of accurate and high-quality news and perspectives can be protected, and that the regime we have in place is equipped to keep up with changes and development in our media landscape," a spokesperson for the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport said.

title: GB News owner Sir Paul Marshall buys Spectator magazine for £100m - BBC News
text: "The culture secretary is now considering recommendations previously put forward by the independent regulator Ofcom on the function of the current regime."

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Barratt Developments, the UK's largest housebuilder, saw a sharp drop in profits after it built far fewer homes last year.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: It completed just 14,000 in the year to June, compared to 17,000 for the previous 12 months, and says the total will be lower again next year.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Pre-tax profit fell by three quarters for the year, which Barratt blamed on high interest rates putting off housebuyers and inflation pushing up costs.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: The completion figures pose a problem for the new Labour government's pledge to "get Britain building".

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Chief executive David Thomas said the firm was "well-positioned to meet the strong underlying demand for new homes".

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: However, the firm forecasts it will only finish between 13,000 and 13,500 new homes next year.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: The government has made increasing the supply of housing a priority, pledging to build 1.5 million more homes in England over the next five years.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: It has promised to reform the planning process, free up parts of the green belt, and reintroduce mandatory housing targets for local authorities.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Mr Thomas said the firm welcomed the government's proposed reforms of the planning system as a "key lever to increase house building, drive economic growth and tackle the chronic under-supply of high-quality, sustainable homes".

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: The government hopes changes to planning policy will increase housebuilding, but Barratt's results show the extent to which mortgage rates affect how much it decides to build.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Aarin Chiekrie, an equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown, said Barratt's numbers were "a painful read for investors" despite being in line with market expectations.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: "With fewer homes being sold and at lower prices, less cash has come through the front door," he wrote in a note.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: "With a new government now in power, there’s increased hope that some of the issues hindering housebuilders, like planning regulations, can be fixed," he said.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: "But further easing of mortgage rates will be necessary for activity to pick up significantly," he added.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Barratt also revealed a jump in the cash it has set aside for cladding removal as it continues to probe its buildings following the Grenfell fire tragedy.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Having assessed 53% of its buildings, it says its "current best estimate" for the final cost of fixing them £628m, much higher than the £536m it had calculated last year.

title: Barratt: Biggest UK housing firm to build fewer homes - BBC News
text: Barratt is in the process of acquiring fellow housebuilder Redrow, although the deal is still awaiting approval from the competition regulator.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: People have been encouraged to register for a conference that aims to provide insights into the Isle of Man government's future plans.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: The 2024 Government Conference, which is set to take place on 17 and 18 September from 08:00 to 17:00 BST at the Comis Hotel in Santon, will focus on business and the economy.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: Cabinet Office Minister Kate Lord-Brennan said this year's event was "geared towards the business community" and was an "important opportunity" to provide updates on several topics.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: The combination of presentations, panel sessions and roundtable discussions would allow attendees to "connect directly" with ministers and key speakers, she said.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: The third annual event will also provide an opportunity to discuss island security, air and sea connectivity ambitions and the future delivery of public services.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: The conference is set to include panel discussions with Chief Minister Alfred Cannan and Treasury Minister Alex Allinson, as well as an update on the island's economic development initiatives by Enterprise Minister Tim Johnston.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: As part of the event, workshops will be held by representatives of the Institute of Directors Isle of Man on enhancing the island's business and economic proposition.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: Representatives from the Isle of Man Steam Packet Company and the airport will also be involved in panel discussions, and presentations will be provided with updates on preventing organised crime and the island's immigration services and enforcement.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: Attendees can register for individual sessions or for a whole day.

title: People encouraged to 'connect' with government at annual conference - BBC News
text: Why not follow BBC Isle of Man on Facebook, external and X, external? You can also send story ideas to IsleofMan@bbc.co.uk

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: One of the UK's largest mobile network providers is advising parents not to give primary school-aged children their own smartphone.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: EE, which is owned by BT, said it aims to improve children's "digital wellbeing" after receiving increasing requests for guidance from parents.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: It said that under-11s should be given "non-smart" devices that have similar capabilities as old brick phones.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: The recommendation - announced for the start of the new school year - comes amid growing concern about the effects of smartphone and internet usage on children's mental health and behaviour.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Access to the internet can support young people's education and social activities, as well as helping parents keep track of their whereabouts.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: But, some experts warn it contributes to shorter attention spans, exposes children to harmful content, and displaces other activities such as playing outside or talking to friends.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: EE said under-11s should be given phones that can be used to text and make calls, but without access to the internet or social media apps like TikTok and Youtube.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: The firm, which is marketing a phone with limited capabilities for children, suggests parents use apps and settings to monitor older children's internet usage.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Its corporate affairs director Mat Sears said EE wanted to help parents and caregivers "make the best choices for their children".

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: He told the BBC: "Under-11s we feel should not be given access to smartphones. They don't need the usage of a smartphone and, actually, a feature phone - or a dumb phone, as some people call them - is more suitable."

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Almost a quarter of five-to-seven-year-olds now have their own smartphone, recent research from the telecoms regulator Ofcom found.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: By age 11, when children typically transfer to secondary school, almost all have a phone of some kind, it says.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Ofcom described its research, published earlier this year, as a "wake-up call" after it found over half of under-13s were using social media, despite most of the big platforms having rules requiring that users are over 13.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Mr Sears said he believed smartphones were appropriate for children aged between 11 and 13 - but not access to social media.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: For 13-to-16-year-olds, he advised parents to exercise "care and attention" over which social media apps they download.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: "We think it's absolutely fine and okay for social media to be used [by over-13s] but various parental controls and privacy settings should be put in place, as well as screen locks for the amount of time that is being placed on these various social media sites."

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Clare Fernyhough, co-founder of grassroots campaign group Smartphone Free Childhood, welcomed EE’s new guidance.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: “It’s a positive move to get parents to question this norm that ‘yeah I’ll just get them a smart phone'," she said.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Ms Fernyhough continued: “I would challenge the idea all children need a phone.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: “[But] if a child needs a phone at all, absolutely it should be a simple phone. They are far less addictive.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: “The way smartphones are, they are adult devices, they are not safe for children."

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: She would like to see a mechanism introduced for verifying a person’s age on the device itself, not just when signing up to access content, as is the case now.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Recent government legislation aims to ensure children are not exposed to harmful online content, such as material that promotes suicide and self-harm, eating disorders, and violent content.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: The Online Safety Act places more responsibility on technology platforms, introducing a legal duty of care towards their users.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: But the Act does not come into force until 2025, and critics, including Ms Fernyhough, say while it is a step in the right direction it does not go far enough to protect young people.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Some other countries, including France, Italy and the Netherlands, have banned the use of smartphones in schools.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Last year, China's regulator proposed limiting daily screen time for children up to the age of 18.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: The UK's Commons education committee said in May that the government should consider a total ban on smartphones for under-16s.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said in July that he does not support "simply banning" phones for under-16s, but that the government needed to "look again" at what content children were accessing online.

title: EE tells parents not to give smartphones to primary-age children - BBC News
text: Last year, parents from eight primary schools in County Wicklow, Ireland, agreed not to give their children smartphones before they went to secondary school to relieve the peer pressure from other children already having access.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Fish and chips is a British family favourite equally enjoyed around the table on a Friday night or out of the paper on an often overcast beach.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: But the deep fried delicacy has seen the biggest price increase of some of the UK’s most popular takeaways, according to new figures.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: The average price for a portion of fish and chips rose more than 50% to nearly £10 in the five years to July – while the cost of a kebab went up 44% and pizza 30%.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Chip shop owners cite a "perfect storm" of costs in recent years, including soaring energy bills, tariffs on seafood imports and extreme weather hammering potato harvests.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: This all means a family of four won't get much change out of a £50 note once they've forked out for their tea and added some mushy peas and cans of pop.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: "I’ve never known an onslaught of pressures in terms of costs going up," said Jon Long, of Long John’s Fish and Chips in Dorset.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Jon is the third generation of his family in the trade and his daughter Emma has recently taken the helm of the business.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: He added: "I’d like to think we’ll see a fifth generation but I’m not sure."

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Fish and chips has been a staple on the menus of British families for decades, so much so that supplies of the two ingredients were protected during both world wars.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: But according to Jon, a combination of increased energy and labour costs, sanctions on Russian seafood due to the invasion of Ukraine, and poor potato harvests, have forced fish and chip shops to raise their prices.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: The average price of takeaway fish and chips was £9.88 in July this year, according to data from the Office for National Statistics (ONS). That was up by 52% compared with £6.48 in July 2019.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: While the ONS says the figures are estimates, it suggests the cost of a fish supper has gone up more in percentage terms than that for pizza, or an Indian or Chinese main course.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: "We’ve had the perfect storm of events in terms of cost pressures," said Jon.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: "It’s not a cheap meal anymore. I think it’s still good value but it has become more expensive."

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: In March 2022, the UK government announced a 35% tariff on Russian seafood imports in response to the invasion of Ukraine, at a time when food prices across the UK were rising at the fastest rate in more than a decade.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: More recently, extreme weather conditions have hit potato harvests.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Cedric Porter, a potato market expert, said the rise in spud prices had been "dramatic".

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: He added: "We’ve seen very high potato prices because of a small crop last year, and there's been a small crop across the whole of Europe."

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Prices paid to UK farmers for potatoes have shot up over the last two years, according to the latest figures from the Department for Environment Food and Rural Affairs' Agricultural Price Index (API).

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Angela Cartwright, owner of Kingfisher Fish Bar in Salford, previously told BBC Breakfast that potato prices were "extortionate".

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: She said: "People think that fish and chips is a cheap meal and it just isn’t. People are prepared to pay £15-20 for a pizza but they’re not prepared to pay it for a portion of fish and chips."

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: Jon said the current economic climate was the "toughest set of conditions" he had faced in his 30-plus years in the business.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: "More and more pubs, hotels, chip shops, bakers and other businesses are shutting down due to crippling costs," he said.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: For Jon, the main challenge remains his energy costs, especially standing charges, which are a daily fixed fee paid to energy suppliers for being connected to the system, regardless of how much gas or electricity a business uses.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: He said the amount these charges had increased since 2021 was "outrageous", adding that the energy regulator Ofgem had failed to protect small businesses from the increases.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: A spokesperson for Ofgem said it had introduced new rules to ensure businesses get fairer treatment, more support resolving disputes, and greater transparency on fees charged by energy brokers.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: They added: "We know high energy bills continue to be a challenge for many businesses. We are working closely with government and industry to understand the range of issues non-domestic customers face, and where the powers we have to tackle them could be stronger."

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: The government said it was right to impose tariffs on imports of Russian fish, as well as other exports from the country.

title: Fish and chips UK takeaway with biggest price rise - BBC News
text: A statement said local takeaways were "essential to thriving, vibrant communities" and support would be developed which included reforming business rates.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: A typical household's annual energy bill will rise by £149 in October under the new price cap.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: People using an average amount of gas and electricity will pay £1,717 a year, a 10% rise compared with now.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: The cap, set by the energy regulator Ofgem, affects the price paid for each unit of gas and electricity used in 27 million homes in England, Wales and Scotland.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Although prices are still lower than last winter, the rise in bills comes as some support for bills has been withdrawn, and the new government has announced it will halt winter fuel payments for 10 million pensioners in England and Wales.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Energy prices have fallen twice this year - in April and July - but will head back up in the run-up to winter, by about £12 a month for a typical user.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: To calculate the effect on what households will pay this autumn, billpayers can add 10% to their current annual bill.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: The rise in the price cap is the result of higher prices on the international energy market, Ofgem said, owing to increasing geopolitical tensions and extreme weather driving competition and demand for gas, which determines the price of wholesale electricity.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Bills will remain about £117 a year cheaper for a typical household than in October last year, but analysts say another rise in prices is likely in January.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Standing charges are rising by one penny a day for gas and also for electricity, but the regulator is considering reforming the system.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Energy consumer minister Miatta Fahnbulleh has invited the heads of the energy suppliers for a meeting on 28 August to discuss how to support the most vulnerable with their bills as a result.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: In specific terms:

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Gas prices will be capped at 6.24p per kilowatt hour (kWh), and electricity at 24.5p per kWh - up from 5.48p and 22.36p respectively now. A typical household uses 2,700 kWh of electricity a year, and 11,500 kWh of gas

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Households on prepayment meters will pay slightly less than those on direct debit, with a typical bill of £1,669

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Those who pay their bills every three months by cash or cheque will pay more, with a typical bill of £1,829

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Standing charges - a fixed daily charge covering the costs of connecting to a supply - will go up to 61p a day for electricity and 32p a day for gas, compared with 60p and 31p respectively now, although they vary by region

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Prices are much lower than their peak, but they remain well above pre-Covid pandemic levels, and financial support from the government has either been wound down or is being cut.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: The final cost-of-living payment was made to eight million people on means-tested benefits in February, and the new government has announced it will stop winter fuel payments for 10 million pensioners in England and Wales.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: The payment is a devolved matter in Scotland and Northern Ireland and the Scottish government confirmed it will also no longer provide winter fuel payments to all pensioners.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Billy and Sylvia Cunningham, a couple aged in their 70s from Warrington, are two people that will be hit by the benefit changes.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: "We did get the help last year, but we still felt the cold, we still had to wrap in blankets and watch the smart meter shooting up," said Mrs Cunningham.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Her husband has Parkinson’s and struggles when he gets cold. "It’s hard work sometimes," he said. "If your fingers are freezing, you can't do nothing."

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: The couple are just £100 above the threshold to qualify for pension credit, a state pension top-up, and so will also miss out on the winter fuel payment worth another £200. One unexpected bill, they said, could push them into an overdraft as higher prices had already eroded their savings buffer.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Some households are already in debt to their supplier and now face increased prices in the run up to winter.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Latest Ofgem figures show that £3.3bn is owed to suppliers by customers behind on, or not paying, bills. That figure is expected to rise when the next data is published in September.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Ofgem chief executive Jonathan Brearley said prices would be "volatile" in the long-term and so building a low-carbon, homegrown energy system was a sensible policy.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Energy secretary Ed Miliband said the increase in prices would be "deeply worrying" for families.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: "We will also do everything in our power to protect billpayers, including by reforming the regulator to make it a strong consumer champion, working to make standing charges fairer, and a proper warm homes plan to save families money," the Labour MP said.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Conservative Claire Coutinho, shadow energy secretary, criticised the government's decision to make the winter fuel payment benefit means-tested.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Although the price cap is changed every three months, it is illustrated by Ofgem in terms of an annual bill for a household using a typical amount of gas and electricity.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: People in larger properties will tend to pay more overall due to higher energy usage, while those in smaller properties likely use less so pay less.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: As well as announcing the new price cap, Ofgem also outlined options to change the standing charge billing system.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Standing charges are the fixed daily fees paid for being connected to the system, but they are unaffected by how much people use.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: The short-term options presented by the regulator include a potential plan to move between £20 and £100 from the standing charge to the price paid for every unit of energy used, giving customers the opportunity to save money by lowering their usage.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: But many vulnerable people do not have the opportunity to do so, as they might need to keep the heating on, or use electricity to run medical equipment.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Mr Brearley said there was "no silver bullet" when it came to altering standing charges.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Greg Jackson, the boss of supplier Octopus Energy said it was "crazy" that standing charges were so high and varied by region.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: An estimated 880,000 low-income pensioner households eligible for pension credit currently fail to claim it.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: The government says it is worth an average of £3,900 a year and claiming it can qualify people for other financial support such as winter fuel payments.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: You can check your eligibility for pension credit via the government's online calculator, external.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Information is also available on how to make a claim, external. There is also a phone line available on weekdays - 0800 99 1234.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Guide to benefits, when you qualify and what to do if something goes wrong, are provided by the independent MoneyHelper website, external, backed by government.

title: Energy price cap: Typical household to pay £149 more a year - BBC News
text: Benefits calculators are also run by Policy in Practice, external, and charities Entitledto, external, and Turn2us, external.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: A shop owner hopes new life could liven up their High Street after the closure of a Clarks shoe shop and upcoming closure of a Tesco Express.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Shoppers in March, Cambridgeshire, said they would have to go "further afield" for some of their shopping after the announcement that two shops would close.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Clarks is closing this Wednesday and Tesco Express is expected to close on Friday.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Greetings' card and gift shop owner, Julie Lambert, 59, said the High Street had been "starved of customers," but new stores could help bring more shoppers in.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Mrs Lambert said it was "very sad" to see another town centre shop go and hoped something other than a hairdresser or vape shop could help fill vacant space.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: "When you go into town for shopping it's nice to look around, but we have less and less now... you have to go further afield," she told BBC Radio Cambridgeshire.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: "I think [renovation work, external] has had an impact on the High Street. It has been starved of customers for nearly two years... people don't come in because of the traffic."

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Clarks thanked its customers for their loyalty and said they would continue to serve them online or at its other stores in Peterborough and King's Lynn.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Julie Gargiulo, 71, who lives in March, said she would have to travel elsewhere for her shopping, but did not think closures were the result of town centre works.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: "It doesn't matter where you go it's all the same; everything is closing down; we haven't really got clothes or shoes shops, just charity shops," she said.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: "It is sad to see it [Clarks] go. I remember when I used to go to have my school shoes fitted, and my children, and grandchildren before first day at school.

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: "I've been in a few times and their shoes last forever; you pay more for the quality."

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Tesco previously told the BBC: "We serve a fantastic community in March and will continue to do so through our nearby local stores and our dotcom service."

title: Clarks and Tesco closing in March, Cambridgeshire, this week - BBC News
text: Follow Cambridgeshire news on BBC Sounds, Facebook, external, Instagram, external and X, external.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: After years of encouraging shoppers to scan their own groceries, some supermarkets are checking out a move back to traditional tills.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Asda said it would put more staff on checkouts, while Morrisons admitted it might have "gone too far" with self-scan. Northern upmarket chain Booths has got rid of them altogether.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: The dreaded "unexpected item in the bagging area" announcement is among a list of customer complaints about self-service tills.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: But some shoppers told the BBC they're happy to skip the queues and the chit chat if it speeds up their shop.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: The debate over staffed versus unstaffed tills has continued to rumble on as the number of self-scan tills has increased over the past 20 years to some 80,000 in the UK.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Now Morrisons chief executive has claimed the store "went a bit too far" with the self-checkout. Although they drive some productivity, "some shoppers dislike it, mainly when they have a full trolley," Rami Baitiéh, told the Telegraph., external

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: He said the chain was now "reviewing" its number of self-service checkouts, with plans to remove some in favour of staffed tills.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: His comments came after Asda pledged to put more staff on checkouts after admitting it had reached a limit with self-service tills.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Some have gone further. Booths - a smaller, upmarket supermarket chain based in the north of England - rid itself of the technology completely last November.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: For Beverley Hyrb, from Oldham in Greater Manchester there's a new nuisance when it comes to negotiating the self-scan. She is particularly turned off by the cameras on some of these tills that capture live footage of the user.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "You see an image of yourself moving about and I don’t like it," the 62-year-old said. "I’d rather get in a queue."

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Stores could be using the technology to discourage shoplifting, after such cases in England and Wales hit the highest level for 20 years in April.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Ms Hyrb added that there were mental health benefits to speaking to someone when grocery shopping.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "Especially if you’re living on your own. Doesn’t matter if it’s about the weather or the news or whatever, it’s just good to chat."

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: For others self-checkouts are not merely annoying, but a challenge to use.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "As a deaf person, I can't hear the beep when I scan items so I'm always getting in a tangle with them as they don't always scan correctly," said Anna Kenyon from Manchester.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: She said people - as opposed to machines - are much better at adapting to her condition. Like Beverley, she appreciates the human touch.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "I've had some lovely interactions in Aldi where a checkout assistant spontaneously started signing with me. Little moments of connection like that are lovely.”

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Julie Yates has two adult sons who have autism and said self-checkouts allow them some independence.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "They don't have to interact with anyone, they can be in and out and gone," she said. "They don't have to make eye contact or small talk."

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "My mum and I, we go to a [staffed] checkout," Ms Yates said. "It's a little social interaction, it can be a nice part of the day."

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Others simply prefer self-checkout because they find it quicker.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: For 74-year-old Trevor Springford from Dunbar in East Lothian "it's all about getting in and out fast without having to queue, get involved in a conversation or field questions."

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: For people like Trevor, it is welcome news that self-checkouts won't be going away entirely anytime soon.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: As for those who loathe them, they may start to see a few more staffed tills in future.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: The British Retail Consortium which represents most of the UK's major supermarkets would not be drawn on whether this was the start of a phasing out of self-scan. A spokesperson told BBC News: "Retailers will adapt check-out systems across their different stores to meet the diverse needs of their customers."

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Ged Futter, director of supermarket consultancy The Retail Mind, agreed that customer feedback is king when it comes to these kinds of shifts in retail.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "At the moment, I think it's particular to those two retailers [Asda and Morrisons]," he told BBC Breakfast.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: One of the benefits self-scans bring to supermarkets is they cut staff wage bills, but if it impacts on customer experience, it's bad for business.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "The retailers themselves will always be looking at costs, [but] sometimes when you're looking at costs, you can go too far," Mr Futter said.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "Successful retailing is all based on feedback from the customer. It's about understanding your customer," he added.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: BBC News contacted all the UK's major supermarket chains to ask whether they were changing their till set-up. Tesco, Lidl, Co-Op and Waitrose said they would continue to offer both.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Marks and Spencer said their stores had different formats for different customer needs, but all stores with staffed tills always has at least one open for checkout.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Aldi and Sainsbury's did not respond to requests for comment.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Tesco said it introduced self-checkout tills nearly 20 years ago. A spokesperson for the country's biggest supermarket said: "We are proud to offer customers choice when it comes to checking out and customers can always ask a colleague for a manned till to be opened."

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: But Fazilet Hadi, head of policy at Disability Rights UK, said customers should not have to ask for a staffed till to be opened. "They're not always that visible, these staff. What if I can't see them?"

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: However she acknowledged that reasonable adjustments for people with disabilities "have to be proportionate".

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "What's reasonable for a multi-million pound chain may not be reasonable for a corner shop," she said, but added that choice was important as everyone's needs are different.

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: Mel Merritt, head of policy and campaigns at the National Autistic Society, said some people "may prefer the reduced level of social communication and interaction which a self-service checkout provides".

title: What could Asda and Morrisons move away from self-checkout mean? - BBC News
text: "Others may need more support while shopping and may benefit from having staff at checkouts who can help," she added.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: People have been asked to share their views on banking and accessing cash in Jersey as part of a review.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: The States of Jersey's Economic and International Affairs Scrutiny Panel launched the review in June.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: As part of it, the panel wanted to hear how the closure of Lloyds Bank's Les Quennevais branch in St Brelade on 13 December and the closure of other out-of-town banks over the years had impacted people's ability to access cash.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: Anyone who wanted to share their views on branch closures or other banking issues has been asked to email or write to the panel before 20 September.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: The panel said it had heard from the Jersey Chamber of Commerce that businesses would face increased costs due to having to travel elsewhere to visit a bank to pay in money.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: The Jersey Bankers Association has also been asked if it would like to discuss the closure of local bank branches as part of the review, the panel added.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: Deputy Montfort Tadier, the panel's chair, said the branch's closure would have "clear ramifications" on people who wanted to access cash.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: "We heard from the Chamber of Commerce about the costs, including travel time, to businesses paying in cash to their accounts, especially for those who are situated out of town," Mr Tadier said.

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: "The closure will also affect personal account holders too, including the elderly, who may not wish to travel into town to access banking services."

title: Jersey bank closure and cash access views sought - BBC News
text: Follow BBC Jersey on X (formerly Twitter), external and Facebook, external. Send your story ideas to channel.islands@bbc.co.uk, external.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Chinese car giant Chery is weighing up the possibility of building cars in the UK, according to a senior executive.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Its UK head Victor Zhang told the BBC it was a "matter of time" before the company made a final decision.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: He said Chery, which is already preparing to build cars in Spain, was determined to take a "localised" approach to the European market.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Mr Zhang denied the company’s exports had benefitted from unfair subsidies.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Chery, which was set up in 1997, is one of China’s largest car companies. It is already the country’s biggest exporter of vehicles, but has ambitious plans to expand further.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: To help take that plan forward, it has set up two new brands focused entirely on the international market, Omoda and Jaecoo.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Last month, Omoda was officially launched in the UK. It has begun selling a mainstream SUV, the Omoda 5, in both electric and petrol-powered versions.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: It has built a network of 60 dealerships, and hopes to have more than 100 here by the end of the year.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: But it is far from the only Chinese manufacturer to see the British market as potentially lucrative.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: BYD, which has been vying with Tesla for the title of the world's biggest manufacturer of electric cars, has also opened dozens of dealerships here.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: SAIC is already well-established in the UK, selling cars under the classic British MG marque.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Cars for sale in Europe are currently built at Chery’s manufacturing HQ in Wuhu, in Eastern China. But that situation is expected to change.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: The company already has a deal with the Spanish firm EV Motors, which will allow Omoda and Jaecoo models to be built at a former Nissan factory in Barcelona. But it wants to establish other bases as well.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Earlier this year, the company said the UK could also be a candidate for an assembly plant. That option remains on the table.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: “Barcelona, this is something we are already commited to”, explained Mr Zhang

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: “For the UK, we are also evaluating. To be honest, we are open for all options and opportunities.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: “So I think it’s just a matter of time. If everything is ready, we will do it”.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: A spokesperson from the Department for Business described the UK's auto sector as "thriving".

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: "While we cannot speculate on commercial investment decisions, we welcome Chery International's Omoda launch in the UK and would positively view any new investment in the UK," they said.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: But the UK is not the only country on Chery’s list. It has also been talking to the Italian government about setting up production in Italy, for example.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Mr Zhang denied the decision would come down to whichever country was able to offer the best incentives.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: “For such a big investment project, it’s a combination of factors”, he said.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: “It’s not just government policy or incentives. You also need to look at the market itself; education, because you need good talented people such as engineers and factory workers; there’s also supply chain, logistics.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: "So there will be many factors involved in our final decision”.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: The pressure to set up manufacturing bases in Europe has increased since July, when the EU imposed steep tariffs, or taxes, on imports of electric vehicles from China.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: This was done, Brussels said, because carmakers in China were benefitting from "unfair subsidies" which allowed their cars to be sold abroad very cheaply, undermining local manufacturers. China accused the EU of protectionism.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: By building its products in Europe, Chery would avoid paying those tariffs. But Mr Zhang insisted his company was always committed to local production.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: “We are not trying to use any unfair methods”, he insisted.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: “We want to be adaptable to the local market, and provide the best products, using the best dealerships. To be localised is the only strategy for the long term," he said.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: The UK has yet say whether it will take a similar approach with tariffs of its own.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: China's domestic car market is vast, with more than 30 million vehicles sold each year.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: Its stake in the global market is also already significant, with roughly 5 million cars exported last year. That was a 64% increase on the year before.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: In the UK, Chinese brands still account for a relatively small proportion of cars sold, around 5%.

title: Chinese giant Chery could build cars in UK - BBC News
text: But established carmakers are concerned that figure could grow quickly, with the prices offered by Chinese brands expected to play a key role.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: There’s one in every town centre. The High Street store that has been boarded up for years, wasting valuable space.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: One in seven shops on UK High Streets is empty, according to analysis by the Local Data Company, external. Many still carry the sign of the chain store that went bust or closed that branch.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: But now traders in one city are calling for big empty shops to be divided up and let to small local independents.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Luke Lutman, chair of the Gloucester Chamber of Trade, said there is a “real hunger for small independents, especially all in one place”.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: In the centre of Gloucester, the Wilko sign still hangs over the huge building that once housed the national chain.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: It went bust a year ago, but still the store is boarded up.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Round the corner, another vacant shopfront has been painted by a local artist, as the city council tries to reduce some of the visual damage done by empty shops.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Luke Lutman thinks it’s time something was done.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “This is a giant store, and clearly no-one wants it as it is,” he tells me.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Mr Lutman chairs the Gloucester Chamber of Trade, and wants new thinking on an old problem.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “It has been empty for years, and it could well be divided up to make space for independents. Coffee shops, creative businesses, specialist traders; it could become a vibrant space.”

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: The city has an experiment that, Mr Lutman believes, proves his point.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: On Gloucester's historic dockside, old warehouses have been redeveloped.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: There are coffee shops, a pizzeria, a craft brewery, just as you would expect.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Unusually though, there is not a national name in sight.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: A tempting gelateria offers ice-cream made on a dairy farm just miles outside the city.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “We previously just sold through a hatch on the farm,” smiles Emily Lee.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “Then we got offered this, and it’s been a rollercoaster – but so exciting.”

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Emily and her husband Will took the plunge in November 2023, not the easiest month to sell ice-cream.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “We had a pretty ropey winter,” laughs Will, “but when the summer came, we thought ‘Phew, this is going to be ok.’”

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: On sunny weekends, people queued out the door and down the stairs for their signature Gloucestershire ice-cream.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Taking a permanent unit in a brand new development on a prime site like a harbourside is pretty unusual for a new business.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: But every one of the ten units in the ‘Food Dock’ is an independent. Most have never had a bricks and mortar site space before.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “It’s so exciting, it’s brilliant,” enthuses Hetty Kitt in her new brunch bakery.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Hetty began baking brownies in her flat in 2011, and has gradually grown. The café is her first big full service operation.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “Giving small businesses a chance to show what they can do in such a prime location is fantastic,” she says.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: The developers are as commercial here as anywhere, so why have they refused the usual national chains?

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “It just doesn’t work any more,” explains Ken Elliott, who planned and financed the development. His company has made large shopping centres, but he says the public are tired of the same old casual dining chains.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Fine, I say, but there is a reason new developments are full of national chains. Investors are wary of taking a risk on untried new businesses, especially a whole group of them.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: Mr Elliott explains they have financed the Food Dock completely differently.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: "We're not asking for guarantees, we're not asking for deposits, we help with fit out costs."

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: But most of all, they charge rent as a percentage of sales, rather than as a flat rate.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “So if they don’t make any money, we don’t make money,” he smiles.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: It means the development company has to stay for longer, earning back the original building costs through steady rent, rather than selling quickly to another property management firm.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: “We love working with these enthusiastic entrepreneurs,” Mr Elliott says. “And they are really less risk than the nationals, because they aren’t going anywhere. They live here.”

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: In the gelateria, Emily and Will do have to go. They leave the sundaes in their assistant’s capable hands and return to their farm.

title: Could independents in Gloucester hold the key to empty shops? - BBC News
text: There are cows to be milked.
