title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Royal Mail could be allowed to end the delivery of second class letters on Saturdays, as part of reforms being considered by the regulator.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Ofcom is also investigating whether to allow second class deliveries to be made on alternate weekdays, which could help cut costs for Royal Mail.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The regulator has been reviewing the Universal Service Obligation (USO) under which Royal Mail is required by law to deliver letters six days a week and parcels five days a week.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The number of letters sent through the post has been falling steadily for years while parcels volumes have grown, leading to millions of pounds in losses at Royal Mail.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Royal Mail estimates that reforming second class services, plus changing its performance targets, could save the business £300m a year.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Lindsey Fussell, Ofcom’s group director for networks and communications, told the BBC's Today programme the universal service “does need to change”.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: “To be clear, no change is not really an option, otherwise it is going to be unsustainable and we’re all going to have to pay a lot more for it,” she said.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Royal Mail's owner, International Distribution Services (IDS), said that “change cannot come soon enough”.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: It had proposed axing second class mail on Saturdays as well alternate weekday deliveries - both of which options are now being examined by Ofcom.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: In theory, it would mean second class deliveries being made on Monday, Wednesday and Friday one week then Tuesdays and Thursdays the following week.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: IDS chief executive Martin Seidenberg said: “The universal service faces a very real and urgent financial sustainability challenge."

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: But Tom MacInnes, interim policy director at Citizens Advice, said that Royal Mail had failed to meet its targets for half a decade, and the USO "clearly doesn’t protect consumers as it should".

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Reforms should not "just be a disguise for cuts that prioritise saving Royal Mail money over providing a good standard of service", he added.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Ofcom said no final decision had been made and it continues to review the possible changes. It aims to publish a consultation early next year and make a decision in the summer.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Asked why the process was taking so long, Ms Fussell said the national debate had helped the regulator "narrow down to what we think is an option really worth exploring, but we now need to do some really detailed consumer research".

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Last year, Ofcom fined Royal Mail £5.6m for failing to meet its first and second class delivery targets.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Between April and the end of June, Royal Mail delivered less than 80% of first class post on time, missing key targets set by the communications watchdog.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Ms Fussell said: "We’re now looking at whether we can get the universal service back on an even keel in a way that meets people’s needs."

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: "But this won’t be a free pass for Royal Mail – under any scenario, it must invest in its network, become more efficient and improve its service levels."

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The number of letters being sent in the UK has fallen from a peak of 20 billion a year in 2004-05 to seven billion last year, Royal Mail said.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: In contrast, parcel volumes have jumped, especially during the pandemic when lockdowns led millions to shop online.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Royal Mail is also facing increased competition from other parcel delivery companies.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Nick Quinn is 86 years old and lives in Manchester. He says he’s lucky to get mail every three weeks. He is due to receive an urgent letter regarding his rent which he’s still waiting for.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: He told BBC News: “On 1st July my landlord increased my rent. I was told to get off the rent I had and take out another rent agreement. I’m supposed to get a letter regarding this.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: "I’m now nearly £2,000 in arrears because I’m not getting the mail that I should get to tell me whether I can object to the increase or not."

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The UK Greeting Card Association said it was concerned that the options outlined by Ofcom "takes us one step closer to the dismantling of a postal service that’s affordable and reliable".

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The association said that cards were the most frequent things that people post. "Any changes to the USO must prioritise the needs of small businesses and consumers - not Royal Mail profitability,” it said.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The Professional Publishers Association said it continued to be concerned about potential changes to second class deliveries, specifically "the impact this will have on publishers of weekly time-sensitive magazines".

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The body which represents trade and magazine publishers, said: "Consumers who subscribe to these services expect reliable delivery, and delays compromise the value of these products."

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Royal Mail has hiked the price of stamps a number of times over the past couple of years. In March, the cost of both first class and second class stamps rose by 10p each, to £1.35 and 85p respectively.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: In its last full financial year, Royal Mail's losses stood at £348m.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: IDS is in the process of being bought by Czech billionaire Daniel Kretinsky for £3.57bn.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Mr Kretinsky has committed in writing to honouring the universal service obligation, but only for five years.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: His Royal Mail takeover will face a government probe, including into potential links with Russia.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: The Communication Workers Union said that Ofcom's "absolute priority" at the moment "should be restoring quality of service", adding that the regulator was now "completely unsuitable" to oversee "one of the UK’s key pieces of infrastructure".

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: "The takeover bid by Daniel Kretinsky coupled with the ongoing mismanagement of the company at the highest level means Royal Mail faces a serious threat to its very existence," a union spokesperson said.

title: Second class letter deliveries could be cut from Saturdays - BBC News
text: Additional reporting by Sherie Ryder

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: President Joe Biden is preparing to block the takeover of a storied US steel-maker by a Japanese company, a controversial move that critics say would lead to job losses and could chill foreign investment in the US, according to US media reports.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: The $15bn deal was announced by Japan's Nippon Steel and US Steel last year.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: It would have created one of the world's biggest steel companies outside of China and had been hailed by investors as an answer to the company's financial woes.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: But it soon ran into resistance from politicians and the US Steelworkers union, which said it did not want to see the 123-year-old firm fall into foreign hands.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: US Steel shares fell nearly 20% after reports of the decision, which involves a company headquartered Pennsylvania, a swing state, during a heated campaign season.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Mr Biden had already moved to have the deal probed on national security grounds and voiced opposition to the takeover earlier this year.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Both Donald Trump and Kamala Harris, rivals in the race for president, have also come out against the merger.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: US Steel said it had not received any update about a formal decision and said it stood by the deal, noting that Japan was one of America's "most staunch allies".

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: "We fully expect to pursue all possible options under the law to ensure this transaction, which is [the] best future for Pennsylvania, American steelmaking, and all of our stakeholders, closes," a spokesman said.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Earlier on Wednesday, the company held a rally to show support for the merger.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: It warned that blocking the deal would put "thousands of jobs" at risk, prompting it to shut factories and potentially move its headquarters from Pennsylvania.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: "We want elected leaders and other key decision makers to recognise the benefits of the deal as well as the unavoidable consequences if the deal fails," chief executive David Burrit said in a statement announcing a rally in favour of the plans.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: The deal has been under review by the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US (CFIUS), a group led by the Treasury Department that looks at national security concerns.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Treasury declined to comment on the president's decision, which was first reported by the Washington Post and Financial Times. White House Press Secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said Wednesday the Committee on Foreign Investment in the US had not yet given a recommendation to the president.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Speaking to the BBC, a White House official did not deny reports of that the president planned to block the deal, saying only that receiving the CFIUS recommendation would be the "next step in this process".

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: As of 2020, the US had formally blocked just five foreign investments via CFIUS, deals that involved Chinese firms.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Nippon Steel is based in Japan, a US ally.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Earlier this year, the US Chamber of Commerce warned against politicising such reviews, saying officials risked sending a "chilling signal" to firms abroad.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Though the involvement of CFIUS makes this case unusual, political intervention in the steel industry is not, said Alan Wolff, a visiting fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics and a former trade lawyer who has worked with firms, including US Steel.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: More than 20 years ago, George W Bush, "otherwise a free-trader", put in place protections for steel, he noted.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: Donald Trump's administration was also marked by a trade fight over tariffs put in place to protect US steelmakers. Biden modified those protections, easing tensions with allies, but still kept in place some guards.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: The economic stature of US steel, founded by Andrew Carnegie, may have shrunk, but it still plays a big role in our national psyche, Mr Wolff said.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: "It has a big part in our view of where manufacturing has gone and the threat to manufacturing jobs," he said.

title: US prepares to block Nippon Steel takeover of US Steel - BBC News
text: "That's a big part of the Biden administration and it's a big part of this election," he said.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: A newly elected MP has used his first parliamentary debate to call for action to help stop rural communities becoming "banking deserts".

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: Labour's Joe Morris MP, who took the Hexham seat from Conservative Guy Opperman in July, said closures left countryside residents feeling "frozen out".

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: During his adjournment debate, which closed proceedings on Monday, Mr Morris said it was "simply unfair to expect our constituents to put up with a second-class service just because they live rurally".

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: Research published last year by the consumer group Which? showed almost 6,000 bank branches had closed, external in the last decade, and more closures have been announced.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: During the debate, Mr Morris said: "These bank branch closures do not just mean an inconvenience to my constituents.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: "They present a toxic cocktail that both damages quality of life and holds back the growth of our rural economy."

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: He also raised concerns about elderly residents who struggled to use digital banking services.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: Economic Secretary to the Treasury Tulip Siddiq MP said the government recognised "part of the population remain digitally excluded" and was "committed to improving connectivity and digital access for all".

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: She also said new Financial Conduct Authority rules would compel banks to keep open branches scheduled for closure until alternative provisions, like cash machines, were installed.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: In January, Labour announced plans to increase alternative banking hubs to 350 in the next five years, but some have complained hubs do not offer the same service as bank branches.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: Mr Morris told the BBC he supported the new government's policy, but wanted to make sure the issue remained high on the agenda.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: "It does cause genuine distress to people, so it's very important for me to raise the issue," he said.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: "There are parts of the Hexham constituency where a lot of passing trade is tourism with customers using cash.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: "Those businesses need easy bank access."

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: In Haltwhistle, Mr Morris's constituents have been advised to travel either to Carlisle or Hexham to access banking facilities, while residents in Alnwick will soon lose their remaining bank services.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: In Blyth, two neighbouring bank branches will close within four months of each other.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: During the debate the town’s MP Ian Lavery said he was concerned it was one of the areas becoming a banking desert.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: "We must take immediate action to look after these vulnerable people," he said.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: Lloyds Group, which operates both the Lloyds and Halifax bank branches in Blyth, said in both cases at least 75% of customers were already using online and mobile banking services.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: "Mobile banking is more popular than ever, with over 19 million customers choosing our app to manage their money," a spokesperson said.

title: Hexham MP leads debate on North East bank closures - BBC News
text: "Alongside our app, customers can bank online, over the phone, at a Post Office or by speaking to one of our Community Bankers."

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: More than 3,500 current and former workers at Next have won the final stage of a six-year legal battle for equal pay.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: An employment tribunal said store staff, who are predominantly women, should not have been paid at lower rates than employees in warehouses, where just over half the staff are male.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Lawyers for the shop staff described the judgement as "hugely significant" and the amount of back-pay owed could amount to more than £30m.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: However, Next said it would appeal against the ruling.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Next argued that pay rates for warehouse workers were higher than for retail workers in the wider labour market, justifying the different rates at the company.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: But the employment tribunal rejected that argument as a justification for the pay difference.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: According to the tribunal's ruling, between 2012 and 2023, 77.5% of Next's retail consultants were female, while 52.75% of warehouse operators were male.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: The tribunal accepted that the difference in pay rates between the jobs was not down to "direct discrimination", including the "conscious or subconscious influence of gender" on pay decisions, but was caused by efforts to "reduce cost and enhance profit".

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: It ruled that the "business need was not sufficiently great as to overcome the discriminatory effect of lower basic pay".

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: The ruling means women such as Helen Scarsbrook, who has worked for Next for more than 20 years, are in line to receive thousands of pounds of compensation for the pay they missed out on.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: "We did it!" the 68-year-old from Eastleigh, near Southampton, one of the lead claimants in the case, said.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: “It has been a long six years battling for the equal pay we all felt we rightly deserved but today we can say we won.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: "Anyone who works in retail knows that it is a physically and emotionally tough job," she said.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: "We do lots of heavy lifting, the same as the men do in the warehouse. We lift the same boxes they lift."

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Add to that the unpredictability of customers who are sometimes wonderful but sometimes challenging, she said.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: "It’s an enjoyable job, but it’s not easy and it’s really undervalued financially and I just thought 'it has to stop'," she told the BBC.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Ms Scarsbrook put in her claim in 2018 and should receive compensation for being paid less than her male counterparts in the warehouse going back six years, to 2012.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: It is likely to amount to several thousand pounds, which would let her pay off her car loan, take a "very nice" holiday or perhaps retire, she told the BBC.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Elizabeth George, barrister and partner at the law firm Leigh Day representing the workers, said the ruling would come as a "huge encouragement" to workers in other sectors.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: "Retail isn't the only sector where you have jobs that are divided along clear gender lines and you see the male-dominated market is attracting a higher rate than the female-dominated roles," she said.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Workers at five of the UK's largest supermarkets, Asda, Tesco, Morrisons, Sainsbury's and the Co-op, are also pursuing equal pay cases, with the firms using the same arguments as Next around market pay rates to counter them.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Ms George said she believed the judgement could prompt further cases, for example in the care sector, hospitality or construction.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: There have already been cases in the public sector over lower pay for workers, including teaching assistants and dinner ladies paid less than men employed in refuse collection and similar roles.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: In a statement, Next said: "This is the first equal pay group action in the private sector to reach a decision at tribunal level and raises a number of important points of legal principle."

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: The firm emphasised that no cases alleging direct discrimination against female staff were upheld and that the tribunal found "there was no conscious or sub-conscious gender influence in the way Next set pay rates".

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: More than 80% of Next's store staff are women.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Barrister Ms George said: "[The tribunal] rightly found that Next could have afforded to pay a higher rate but chose not to and that the reason for that was purely financial."

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: The argument around market rates was essentially "circular" Ms George said, suggesting women should be paid less because they were already currently being paid less elsewhere.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: Leigh Day said that the claimants' contracts would now be changed to reflect fairer rates of pay.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: In other areas where there was a mismatch, for example over different ways of calculating night payments, paid rest breaks for warehouse staff and Sunday pay, better terms would also be extended to shop staff.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: However, it was not yet clear whether other staff, not directly involved in the case, would see their employment terms upgraded automatically, she said.

title: Next shop workers win equal pay claim - BBC News
text: The process of calculating what claimants were owed as back-pay should begin as soon as possible, said Ms George.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Imagine picking up a nice juicy apple - but instead of biting into it you keep the seeds and throw the rest away.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: That's what chocolate producers have traditionally done with the cocoa fruit - used the beans and disposed of the rest.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: But now food scientists in Switzerland have come up with a way to make chocolate using the entire cocoa fruit rather than just the beans - and without using sugar.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The chocolate, developed at Zurich’s prestigious Federal Institute of Technology by scientist Kim Mishra and his team includes the cocoa fruit pulp, the juice, and the husk, or endocarp.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The process has already attracted the attention of sustainable food companies.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: They say traditional chocolate production, using only the beans, involves leaving the rest of the cocoa fruit – the size of a pumpkin and full of nutritious value -  to rot in the fields.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The key to the new chocolate lies in its very sweet juice, which tastes, Mr Mishra explains, "very fruity, a bit like pineapple".

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: This juice, which is 14% sugar, is distilled down to form a highly concentrated syrup, combined with the pulp and then, taking sustainability to new levels, mixed with the dried husk, or endocarp, to form a very sweet cocoa gel.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The gel, when added to the cocoa beans to make chocolate, eliminates the need for refined sugar.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Mr Mishra sees his invention as the latest in a long line of innovations by Swiss chocolate producers.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: In the 19th Century, Rudolf Lindt, of the famous Lindt chocolate family, accidentally invented the crucial step of "conching" the chocolate – rolling the warm cocoa mass to make it smooth and reduce its acidity  – by leaving a cocoa mass mixer running overnight. The result in the morning? Deliciously smooth, sweet chocolate.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "You need to be innovative to maintain your product category," says Mr Mishra.  "Or... you will just make average chocolate."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Mr Mishra was partnered in his project by KOA, a Swiss start-up working in sustainable cocoa growing. Its co-founder, Anian Schreiber, believes using the entire cocoa fruit could solve many of the cocoa industry’s problems, from the soaring price of cocoa beans to endemic poverty among cocoa farmers.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "‘Instead of fighting over who gets how much of the cake, you make the cake bigger and make everybody benefit," he explains.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "The farmers get significantly extra income through utilising cocoa pulp, but also the important industrial processing is happening in the country of origin. Creating jobs, creating value that can be distributed in the country of origin."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Mr Schreiber describes the traditional system of chocolate production, in which farmers in Africa or South America sell their cocoa beans to big chocolate producers based in wealthy countries as "unsustainable".

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The model is also questioned by a new exhibition in Geneva, which explores Switzerland’s colonial past.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: To those who point out that Switzerland never had any colonies of its own, chocolate historian Letizia Pinoja counters that Swiss mercenary soldiers policed other countries' colonies, and Swiss ship owners transported slaves.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Geneva in particular, she says, has a particular link to some of the most exploitative phases of the chocolate industry.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "Geneva is a hub for commodity trade, and since the 18th Century, cocoa was reaching Geneva and then the rest of Switzerland to produce chocolate.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "Without this commodity trade of colonial goods, Switzerland could never have become the land of chocolate. And cocoa is no different from any other kind of colonial good. They all came from slavery."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Listen to Business Daily:  Swiss chocolate breakthrough

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Nowadays, the chocolate industry is much more highly regulated. Producers are supposed to monitor their entire supply chain to make sure there is no child labour. And, from next year, all chocolate imported to the European Union must guarantee that no deforestation took place to grow the cocoa used in it.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: But does that mean all the problems are solved? Roger Wehrli, director of the association of Swiss chocolate manufacturers, Chocosuisse, says cases of child labour and deforestation remain, particularly in Africa. He fears that some producers, in a bid to avoid the challenges, are simply shifting their production to South America.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "Does this solve the problem in Africa? No. I guess it would be better for responsible firms to stay in Africa and help to improve the situation."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: That is why Mr Wehrli sees the new chocolate developed in Zurich as "very promising... If you use the whole cocoa fruit, you can get better prices. So it's economically interesting for the farmers. And it's interesting from an ecological point of view."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The link between chocolate production and the environment is also stressed by  Anian Schreiber. A third of all farm produce, he says, "never ends up in our mouths".

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Those statistics are even worse for cocoa, if the fruit is abandoned to use only the beans. "It's like you throw away the apple and just use its seeds. That's what we do right now with the cocoa fruit."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Food production involves significant greenhouse gas emissions, so reducing food waste could also help to tackle climate change. Chocolate, a niche luxury item, may not by itself be a huge factor, but both Mr Schreiber and Mr Wehrli believe it could be a start.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: But, back in the laboratory, key questions remain. How much will this new chocolate cost?

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: And, most important of all, without refined sugar and only the cocoa fruit's own natural juice, which contains fruit sugar to keep it sweet, what does it really taste like?

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The answer to the last question, in this chocolate-loving correspondent’s view, is: surprisingly good. A rich, dark but sweet flavour, with a hint of cocoa bitterness that would fit perfectly with an after dinner coffee.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: The cost may remain something of a challenge, because of the global power of the sugar industry, and the generous subsidies it receives. "The cheapest ingredient in food will always be sugar as long as we subsidise it," explains Kim Mishra. "For a... tonne of sugar, you pay $US500 [£394] or less." Cocoa pulp and juice cost more, so the new chocolate would, for now, be more expensive.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Nevertheless, chocolate producers in countries where cocoa is grown, from Hawaii to Guatemala, to Ghana have contacted Mr Mishra for information about the new method.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: In Switzerland, some of the bigger producers - including Lindt - are starting to use the cocoa fruit as well as the beans, but none, so far, has taken the step of eliminating refined sugar completely.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "We have to find daring chocolate producers who want to test the market and are willing to contribute to a more sustainable chocolate," says Mr Mishra. "Then we can disrupt the system."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: Perhaps those daring producers will be found in Switzerland, whose chocolate industry makes 200,000 tonnes of chocolate each year, worth an estimated $US2bn. At Chocosuisse, Roger Wehrli sees a more sustainable, but still bright, future.

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: "I think chocolate will still taste fantastic in the future," he insists. "And I think the demand will increase in the future due to the growing world population."

title: Swiss chocolate: Scientists cut waste and sugar - BBC News
text: And will they be eating Swiss chocolate? "Obviously," he says.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: UK shares dropped on Wednesday morning following falls in Asian and US markets as concerns grow about the world's largest economy.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Data showed US manufacturing activity remains subdued, with investors now focussed now on US jobs figures due on Friday.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: American chip giant Nvidia was hit particularly hard, slumping by almost 10% as optimism about the boom in artificial intelligence (AI) dampened.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Despite the sharp fall, Nvidia's shares are still worth double their value a year ago.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: The FTSE 100 index, which comprises the largest companies on the London Stock Exchange, dropped 0.55% by lunchtime, with major European indexes also down. Germany's Dax fell 1.41%, France's Cac 40 was down by almost 1%, and Spain's Ibex was also lower, by 0.51%.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Market watchers are now trying to second-guess how the Federal Reserve, the US central bank, will respond when it meets to decide interest rate policy next week.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: "Growth concerns are dominating market moves," Julia Lee at FTSE Russell told the BBC.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: In New York on Tuesday, the S&P 500 index closed more than 2% lower, while the technology-heavy Nasdaq fell by over 3%.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Nasdaq-listed Nvidia fell by 9.5%, wiping $279bn (£212.9bn) off its stock market valuation.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Over the longer term however Nvidia shares are still worth nine times their price in November 2022, when the launch of ChatGPT set off the current bout of interest in AI, prompting a surge in demand for Nvidia's chips.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Other US tech giants — including Alphabet, Apple and Microsoft — also saw their shares tumble on Tuesday.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Japan's Nikkei 225 ended Wednesday’s trading session 4.2% lower, while South Korea's Kospi lost more than 3% and the Hang Seng in Hong Kong dropped 1.1%.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Major Asian technology firms including TSMC, Samsung Electronics, SK Hynix and Tokyo Electron were sharply lower.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Asian markets have performed less strongly over the last year, with the Shanghai and Hong Kong indexes lower over the twelve months. Japan's Nikkei is up 12% over the year, however.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: "Concerns around global growth look to be hitting exporting countries in the region particularly hard," Ms Lee added.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: As well as next week's interest rate decision in the US, investors will be waiting for Friday's US jobs market report, to provide further signs on the direction the US economy is taking.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Swetha Ramachandran, fund manager for Artemis Investment Management in London, said Tuesday's US share falls were a sign that investors were beginning to doubt the Federal Reserve would make a large cut in interest rates.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: Nvidia’s slide was a matter of “expectations catching up with reality” for the AI giant, she told the BBC.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: “[Nvidia] did report results last week where it alluded to a natural and expected deceleration in growth: from having delivered 122% growth in the second quarter it expects to deliver 80% growth in the third quarter,” she said.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: The fall might also be a reaction to reports that the US Department of Justice had issued a subpoena, requiring the firm to give evidence over anti-trust issues, she added.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: However, Nvidia later said that it had not been subpoenaed.

title: UK shares down after Nvidia plunges almost 10% - BBC News
text: The Department of Justice declined to comment.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Ted Baker - a fixture on UK High Streets since the late 1980s - is the latest casualty in the battle facing brick-and-mortar shops.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Known for its quirky advertising and signature floral prints, the brand has long been synonymous with British fashion and heritage.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: But in recent years, it has faced huge challenges such as fierce competition, the shift to online shopping and the departure of its founder Ray Kelvin.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: It is now set to close its remaining stores this week, putting more than 500 jobs at risk in the UK.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: "This is an iconic brand with a signature design," Diane Wehrle, retail expert and chief executive at Rendle Intelligence and Insights told the BBC.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: During the brand's 36-year history, it has been forced to compete with other, higher-end, High Street fashion outfits such as Reiss, Whistles, Mango and Massimo Dutti, "all of which have eaten away at its market share", she noted.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: It has had to fend off competition while facing huge overheads with some 1,000 employees across 46 stores, concessions and the online business, she said.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: But its fatal error? A failure to evolve with consumer tastes.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: "Over the last three decades their signature floral design, whilst iconic, simply became too tired for current consumers," Ms Wehrle said.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: According to Ms Wehrle, the brand's "instability and poor media profile" has also been exacerbated by allegations of misconduct against its founder, further impacting sales.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Founder Ray Kelvin stepped down as chief executive in March 2019 after allegations of inappropriate behaviour, which he denied.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: His successor Lindsay Page and chairman David Bernstein then resigned in late 2019 after the firm issued a profit warning.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Ted Baker started out as a menswear brand in Glasgow in 1988. Eventually, it had set up shops all across the UK and in the United States, with licensing agreements in place for stores in cities in Asia and the Middle East.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Danni Hewson, head of financial analysis at AJ Bell, told the BBC that Ted Baker achieved massive success in the nineties and noughties, by creating highly sought-after product for special occasions.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: "Teenage boys bought their first suits for prom, twenty-something women picked up signature florals to wear at friend’s wedding and Christmas stockings were packed full of branded fragrances and lotions," she said.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: But she suggests its charm began to fade as its footprint expanded, and once consumers recognised in lockdown that they could opt for athleisure instead of being "suited and booted", it struggled to stand out.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: “Retail is brutal and fashion retail particularly so," she said.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: "What strikes a chord with shoppers one season might be off key the next and social media has made being 'on trend' even more important".

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Plenty of other names have seen similar struggles. Although the likes of Karen Millen and Coast still exist as part of bigger online stables, they don’t have the same brand recognition they once did.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Susannah Streeter, head of money and markets at Hargreaves Lansdown, said that while bigger operations like Next and M&S were able to "switch focus" to establish digital channels and more laid-back ranges, "Ted Baker floundered as the company failed to shift gears".

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: She said that when Authentic Brands Group snapped up Ted Baker in 2022, there were "high hopes of a revival, but the investment needed to rejuvenate the brand didn’t materialise".

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: The cost-of-living squeeze has also squeezed customers' budgets in another blow for brands positioning themselves in the middle of the market.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: The firm which ran Ted Baker's UK stores, No Ordinary Designer Label (NODL), fell into administration in March this year.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: US firm Authentic Brands Group owns the intellectual property for Ted Baker, while NODL was the holding company for the brand in the UK.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: When NODL collapsed, Authentic said the "damage done" during a tie-up with another firm was "too much to overcome".

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: Authentic has been in talks with other retailers about a possible licensing partnership for the brand.

title: Ted Baker: What went wrong for the British fashion label? - BBC News
text: However, reports suggest these talks have stalled and so for now the future of the Ted Baker brand remains in the balance.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: The 75th anniversary of a pioneering aircraft, which laid the foundation for the development of Concorde, is being celebrated.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: About 10,000 people gathered at Filton Airfield to witness the maiden flight of the Bristol Brabazon on 4 September 1949.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: The ambitious project - designed to be the 'ocean liner of the sky' - promised a new era of luxury passenger travel.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: Talks and displays on the history of the iconic aircraft are being hosted by the Aerospace Bristol museum throughout September.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: "The Bristol Brabazon is a hugely important part of Bristol’s history, and we are thrilled to display aspects of this remarkable aircraft for the anniversary," said Amy Seadon, head of collections, learning and interpretation.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: "Visitors will be able to see items such as the Brabazon’s cockpit window and tyre, and learn about the wider public reaction through newspaper clippings from the time.”

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: Bill Morgan’s father worked for the Bristol Aeroplane Company and once took him inside the Brabazon's 25ft (7.6m) fuselage when it was still under construction.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: "I recall that it was like being in the inside of a whale with all the fuselage frames defining the shape," he said.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: Despite its technical brilliance, the Brabazon - originally known as Type 167 - was a commercial failure.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: By the time it was ready, the market for expensive luxury travel was shifting towards smaller airlines with high-density seating and lower fares.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: But it earned a place in aviation history as it laid the groundwork for the Bristol Aeroplane Company's eventual contract to build the world's first supersonic passenger jet

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
text: The Brabazon Hangar and Filton runway, specifically built for the Brabazon, would later prove to be the ideal location for designing and building Concorde.

title: Pioneering Bristol Brabazon aircraft celebrates 75th anniversary - BBC News
