title: £10m invested in Highland broadband rollout - BBC News
text: Ultrafast broadband is to be made available to more than 100,000 properties in the Highlands.

title: £10m invested in Highland broadband rollout - BBC News
text: The publicly-owned Scottish National Investment Bank (SNIB) has invested £10m in the rollout of gigabit-capable networks.

title: £10m invested in Highland broadband rollout - BBC News
text: Highland Broadband, which is part of Lothian Broadband Networks Ltd, is carrying out the work.

title: £10m invested in Highland broadband rollout - BBC News
text: SNIB provided the company with £20m funding in 2021 and again in 2023 to boost connectivity across Scotland.

title: £10m invested in Highland broadband rollout - BBC News
text: The latest phase involves network improvements across the Black Isle, Great Glen and Cairngorms.

title: £10m invested in Highland broadband rollout - BBC News
text: Gavin Rodgers, of Highland Broadband, said: "The bank's continued support has enabled us to accelerate our plan to connect these regions, which ultimately helps reduce place-based inequality in areas such as education, employment and healthcare."

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Rising sales at its Waitrose supermarkets have helped the John Lewis Partnership to nearly halve its losses over the first half of the year.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: The partnership - which includes the John Lewis department stores as well as Waitrose - reported a loss of £30m, down from a £59m deficit last year.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: The retail giant said the results were proof that its recovery plan was working, and it expected annual profits to "grow significantly" this year.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: However, sales at the John Lewis department stores fell amid a "challenging market", and it warned that the outlook for consumer spending was uncertain.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: The retailer has been trying to win back customers after a tough few years that has seen it cut jobs and close several stores.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: In March, it reported its first annual profit after years of losses, but also said it would not pay a staff bonus for the second year in a row.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: John Lewis makes the majority of its profits in the second half of the year, which includes the key Christmas trading period.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Announcing the latest results, Nish Kankiwala, chief executive of the John Lewis Partnership, said: “These results confirm that our transformation plan is working and we expect profits to grow significantly for the full year, a marked improvement from where we were two years ago."

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Sales at the John Lewis department stores were down 3% over the first half of the year, with fashion hit by "the well-documented squeeze on customers’ disposable income and unseasonal weather".

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Diana Wehrle, retail analyst at Rendle Intelligence and Insights, said fashion was a "key thing" for John Lewis but they were facing challenges from rival chains. "Marks and Spencer have really upped their game," she said.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: John Lewis said its strategy for boosting the business included the return of its  "never knowingly undersold" price pledge, which it announced last week.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: It has also agreed a new tie-up with book chain Waterstones, which is set to open in its Oxford Street store in London next month.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Waitrose sales climbed 5% over the half-year, in a period which has seen the first opening of an in-store outlet from Gail’s bakery.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Operating profits at the supermarket chain rose by £75m to £113m over the six months to 27 July.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Waitrose is also planning to open up to 100 new convenience shops over the next five years.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Ms Wehrle said the tie-ups with Gail's and Waterstones aimed to drive more people into stores and make them stay longer. However, she added it was "not going to significantly move the dial" on sales.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: Waitrose has been the "shining light", she said, and the new convenience stores made sense as "a lot of their offering is designed in smaller portions".

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: New chairman Jason Tarry, the former boss of Tesco UK, will join the company on Monday.

title: John Lewis losses halve as Waitrose sales rise - BBC News
text: The current chairman, Dame Sharon White, announced last year that she would be stepping down after five years in the role.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Sir Keir Starmer has blamed the Conservatives for leaving a "£22bn black hole" in the public finances during Prime Minister's Questions.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Government ministers have repeatedly used the figure to justify the decision to cut the winter fuel payment, while the Labour leader has also warned that October's Budget will be "painful".

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: But economists say the state of the public finances should not have come as a complete surprise to the Labour government, arguing some of the pressures should have been anticipated.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: The £21.9bn figure was in an audit published by the Treasury at the end of July, external – just a few weeks after Labour came to power.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: The document looked at areas of public spending which are set to go over budget this year, including:

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Public sector pay rises

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Overspending on certain projects, such as supporting the asylum system

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Unforeseen costs, such as inflation being higher than expected

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Military assistance to Ukraine

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: To put the figure into context, in the Spring Budget, external it was expected that total public spending this year would be £1,226bn. The £22bn is a small proportion of that.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: But Gemma Tetlow from the Institute for Government think tank told BBC More or Less: "looking back at history and the amount that the government tends to overspend its budgets in previous years, £22bn would be quite a large number".

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: To cover some of the shortfall, Chancellor Rachel Reeves made several announcements:

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Ending winter fuel payments for those not receiving pension credit

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Cancelling infrastructure projects, such as the road tunnel near Stonehenge

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Scrapping previous government measures, such as the planned cap on social care charges from October 2025.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: It is true that some aspects of spending have come as a surprise.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: According to the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS) - an independent think tank - Ms Reeves was right to say that nearly all the estimated £6.4bn cost of supporting the asylum system was unfunded, for example.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: On 29 July, the government’s own public finance watchdog - the Office for Budget Responsibility - wrote that it had not been made aware of the extent of overspends, external. It is now carrying out an investigation and will report back before October’s Budget.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: But while Labour can credibly claim it was not aware of all areas of overspending, certain things were known.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: For example, pay review bodies were likely to recommend a raise bigger than the 2% initially budgeted by the last government in order to retain teachers, nurses and other public sector workers.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: It is a point made by IFS director, Paul Johnson: “The numbers may be a little bit worse than they thought at the time, and I think there were some things that were hidden from view, but the overall picture over the next four or five years is very, very similar to what we knew before the election.”

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Jeremy Hunt - the last Conservative chancellor - said the £22bn gap was “spurious” and that the public finances were not nearly as bad as Ms Reeves had tried to present them. He accused her of a "shameless attempt to lay the grounds for tax rises".

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: However, in a leaked letter, Britain’s most senior civil servant, Simon Case, suggested that the previous government’s failure to hold a spending review in its final years in office contributed to uncertainty over the public finances.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Responding to the letter on X, external, Mr Hunt said it would be a breach of the Civil Service Code if officials had knowingly signed off incorrect public finance estimates, irrespective of the last government's decision to hold a spending review or not - and if this had not been the case, "then Labour’s claim of a £22bn ‘black hole’ is exposed as bogus".

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: The trouble with terms such as “black hole” is they suggest the government’s hand was forced. Ms Reeves told the Commons: "The scale of the situation we are dealing with means incredibly tough choices.”

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: It is important to remember that choices were indeed made. The government decided to do things like giving winter fuel payment only to those receiving pension credit, but it could have taken other decisions.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: For example, it is basing the decisions on needing to meet the fiscal rules that it imposed on itself, but it could have changed the rules. Or it could have decided to spend less on something else.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: The Leader of the House of Commons, Lucy Powell, told BBC News on 1 September: “If we hadn’t taken that action we would have seen a run on the pound, we would have seen the economy crashing.”

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: It is always hard to predict at what point markets would lose confidence in a government, as happened after former PM Liz Truss’s mini-budget, but there is little sign that it would have happened if the government had not taken its immediate action.

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: Nina Skero, chief executive of the Centre for Economics and Business Research told BBC Verify: "It is hard to find any evidence to support the claim that there is an imminent risk of a run on the pound."

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: She added that the size of any hole in the public finances is "highly speculative, subject to forecasts, and there are no alarm bells going off at the moment among investors looking at the UK".

title: Is there a £22bn ‘black hole’ in the UK’s public finances? - BBC News
text: What do you want BBC Verify to investigate?

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: India’s market regulator is facing a threat to its credibility after a barrage of allegations against its chief, top fund managers have told the BBC.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Multiple charges, mostly around conflict of interest, have surfaced against Madhabi Puri Buch, chairperson of the Securities and Exchange Board of India (Sebi), from at least four different corners over the past month. She has denied most of them and not publicly responded to some.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: This comes amid a bull run in India’s equity markets, which are among the world’s best performing this year.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Foreign investors have pumped in over $6bn (£4.5bn), while millions of new mom-and-pop investors have opened electronic accounts to invest in a mutual funds and initial public offering (IPO) frenzy.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Trouble for Ms Buch began in August when US-based short-seller Hindenburg Research accused her and her husband of holding investments in an offshore fund used by the Adani Group, implying it was why Sebi was dragging its feet on an investigation against Adani over allegations of accounting fraud and market manipulation.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Since then a number of other accusations have come to the fore.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: The main opposition Congress party has accused Ms Buch of receiving rental income from a company she was investigating. It has also alleged that she held an "office of profit" at ICICI Bank, one of India’s largest private lenders, continuing to earn large sums of money through Employee Stock Ownership Plans (Esops) long after her stint with them was over.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Subhash Chandra Goyal, the chairman emeritus of media giant Zee Entertainment Enterprises, blamed her for the collapse of a merger between his company and Sony Enterprises, stating "I am convinced that the Sebi chairperson is corrupt" and calling her "vindictive" in a press conference. He is currently facing regulatory action, charges of fund diversion and is barred from holding key posts in listed firms.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: But perhaps most damaging of all is growing internal dissent within Sebi, which has now spilled out into the public domain.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: On 5 September, furious staff members staged a rare protest outside the regulator’s headquarters demanding Ms Buch’s resignation. Around 1,000 employees had reportedly complained of a toxic work culture in a letter to the finance ministry earlier, local media reported. They complained of "immense pressure" and "shouting, scolding and public humiliation” becoming a norm in meetings.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Sebi has publicly rejected the claims as “misplaced”, adding that “junior officers have been misguided, perhaps by external elements”.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: However, protesters on Thursday called for an immediate retraction of this statement.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: “This is unprecedented,” says Hemindra Hazari, an independent business analyst. “Until yesterday it was allegations from the outside, now internal problems have become public. Something is seriously wrong.”

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Ms Buch has strongly defended herself, denying any conflict of interest claims in the Hindenburg case, while ICICI Bank has denied paying her a salary or Esops and said she only received her retirement benefits after she left the bank. The Sebi chief has so far not made a public statement on protesting employees or the criticisms levelled at her by Mr Chandra.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Sebi didn't respond to the BBC's request for comment.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: An alumnus of India’s premier management school, Indian Institute of Management Ahmedabad, Ms Buch is a trailblazer in many ways. The youngest and first female chairperson to lead Sebi, she became the first chief to have come from a private corporate background.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Despite being credited for reforming Sebi with stricter insider trading rules and auditing frameworks, allegations of a lack of transparency in her own financial affairs raise serious concerns about whether Sebi holds its top officials to the same standards it expects from public companies, experts say.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: “The crux of the issue is about disclosure rules governing the senior-most officials at regulatory bodies, given their access to unpublished price-sensitive information. Their orders and decisions can dramatically impact stock prices, raising the stakes for stringent disclosure and compliance norms,” writes Sucheta Dalal, a veteran financial journalist, in a column for Moneylife magazine.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Standards for heads of regulators are much more stringent in developed countries where they are required to, for instance, “divest from direct holdings in entities that could post conflict of interest”, says Ms Dalal, adding that certain discrepancies in the statement put out by ICICI Bank about its Esop policy have complicated rather than clarified matters.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Regulators like Sebi typically have political appointees and lateral hires from the private sector. Sebi is run by a board with members from the finance ministry, the central bank and others nominated by the federal government.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: The Buch episode is a “learning” not just for Sebi, but also for other Indian regulators like the insurance watchdog or the Competition Commission to apply more robust disclosure processes, says Shriram Subramanian of the proxy advisory firm InGovern Research.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: “It will bring more transparency,” Mr Subramanian adds.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: For the moment, investors seem unperturbed by the events of the past month.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: “Global investors already pay a regulatory risk premium when they invest in India, they will ignore this,” said a veteran trader.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: But things could take a turn for the worse if the controversy snowballs further, says Mr Hazari.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: “Institutional money can flee if internal warnings go out around compliance issues. And then retail investors will slowly start pulling out of the market,” he adds.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: With pressure mounting from both outside and inside Sebi, some say Ms Buch is now faced with the very real question of leaving her post.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Her position was "untenable" a few weeks ago, but has become increasingly "unsustainable" now, Subhash Garg, a former finance secretary, told journalist Barkha Dutt on Mojo Story, a digital outlet.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: A resignation or a suspension would be seen as an admission of guilt, which neither Ms Buch nor the government would want.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: At least three market experts the BBC spoke with said the most likely outcome of the controversy will be that Ms Buch's appointment won’t be renewed. Her current three-year tenure as chairperson ends in February 2025.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: “For me what’s most astounding is that the government has been totally silent. They need to step in now. When serious allegations are made against the head of a regulator, the government or the judiciary are the only higher authorities which can authorise a credible investigation,” said Mr Hazari.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: Others have also called for the board of Sebi to step in and publicly address the allegations.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: An executive at a foreign fund house who spoke to the BBC on condition of anonymity said global investors will watch the way the government handles the matter, and how swiftly it acts.

title: Madhabi Puri Buch: Allegations mount against India market regulator - BBC News
text: “This will affect investor sentiment going forward,” he said.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Job growth in the US was weaker than expected last month, raising concern that the world's largest economy is starting to stumble under the weight of higher interest rates.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Employers added 142,000 jobs in August, less than the roughly 160,000 analysts had forecast, the Labor Department said. It also said job gains in the previous two months were lower than initially estimated.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: However, the unemployment rate fell back, dropping to 4.2% from 4.3% in July.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: The report is one of the most important gauges of the US economy and comes at a critical time, as voters weigh presidential candidates for the November election and the US central bank debates its first cut to interest rates in four years.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Analysts said the latest figures kept the Federal Reserve on track for a rate cut at its meeting this month, but would do little to resolve questions about the direction of the US economy or how big a cut it should make.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: "Rarely has there been such a make or break number – unfortunately, today’s jobs report doesn’t entirely resolve the recession debate," said Seema Shah, chief global strategist at Principal Asset Management.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Soaring prices in 2022 prompted the Federal Reserve to raise its key lending rate to 5.3%, a roughly 20-year high.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Faced with higher borrowing costs for homes, cars and other debt, the economy has slowed, helping to ease pressures that were fuelling inflation, but adding to market jitters.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: As inflation has subsided, falling to 2.9% in July, the Fed is now under pressure to cut rates and ward off further economic slowing.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: The job gains in August, although below estimates, were higher than July, when a slowdown sparked fears and prompted several days of stock market turmoil.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Construction and health care firms led the hiring last month, while manufacturers and retailers got rid of roles.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Ms Shah said the data in Friday's report was mixed, but contained enough worrying signs that the Fed should make a bigger cut.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: "On balance, with inflation pressures subdued, there is no reason for the Fed not to err on the side of caution and frontload rate cuts," she said.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: But others said the gains were just steady enough to warrant a 0.25 percentage point cut, as markets have long predicted - though it might be a sign of more cuts than expected in the months ahead.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: The Fed's decision would be "close run", said Paul Ashworth, chief North America economist for Capital Economics.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: "The labour market is clearly experiencing a marked slowdown," he said, adding that the latest figures were "overall still consistent with an economy experiencing a soft landing rather than plummeting into recession".

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: The concerns about the economy are a key issue in the US election.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Polls suggest that a majority of Americans already believe the US is experiencing a recession, despite solid 2.5% growth last year.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Donald Trump has claimed that the economy is headed for a "crash" and his campaign quickly seized on the latest figures to attack vice president Kamala Harris, issuing a press release titled "warning lights flash as Kamala's economy keeps weakening".

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: Democrats have defended their record, arguing that the US weathered the pandemic and inflation better than many other countries.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: They say that the slowdown is a sign of an economy returning to a more sustainable pace of growth after the post-pandemic boom.

title: Mixed August jobs report adds to US economy concerns  - BBC News
text: "Although hiring has slowed, the US job market continues to generate solid job gains and wage growth that is consistently beating inflation," the White House Council of Economic Advisors said in a blog.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: In a warehouse building in a quiet town in Northern Ireland, a robot arm is opening and closing an airplane meal table over and over again.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: It has been programmed to carry out this mundane task no fewer than 28,000 times, day and night, for more than a week. And it won’t even get a bag of peanuts.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: “We can measure the force that the robot’s having to apply to that,” says Gerald King, head of engineering at Thompson Aero Seating in Banbridge. “Is it increasing? Which means more friction.”

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Thompson makes first class and business class seats – the expensive kind usually at the front of passenger aircraft, with their own privacy-simulating enclosures, built-in entertainment systems, and heaps of leg room.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: The company has various machines for testing the longevity and safety of such seats. Including a new £7.5m facility, opened last autumn, where crash test dummies are strapped to a seat and shot down a short track at incredible speeds.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: The idea is to ensure that the seat – and passenger – would survive a brief exposure to 16 g’s. It is the only facility of its kind on the island of Ireland.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Perhaps surprisingly, just under one third of the world’s aircraft seats are manufactured in Northern Ireland, according to Invest NI, an economic development agency. Thompson, which was bought by a Chinese company in 2016, is one of a few businesses in the region that specialise in this trade. The firm currently churns out roughly 1,500 seats per year.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Another major Northern Ireland-based supplier of seats is Collins Aerospace, in Kilkeel. There is also Alice Blue Aero, in Craigavon.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: One of the largest seat manufacturing companies worldwide is Safran. It has facilities on six continents.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: But, thanks to the pandemic, demand for aircraft seats has flip-flopped dramatically of late. When Covid-19 emerged, the aerospace manufacturing industry slowed to a crawl. Globally, companies laid off thousands of workers. Thompson, for one, cut its own workforce in half, and has faced financial losses running to many millions.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: The world has at last opened up again, but seat manufacturers have not been able to find all the skilled workers they need, meaning that demand, globally speaking, is outstripping supply. It is a “very difficult situation”, Airbus’ chief executive said in June, referring to the slow supply of seats and other cabin parts.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: “The industry lost that expertise, both in terms of direct, hands-on manufacturing, but also in terms of teaching younger people how to do the job,” explains Nick Cunningham, an analyst at Agency Partners who tracks the fortunes of another seat maker, Safran.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: One of the problems, he adds, is that seat makers are finding it hard to get their seats tested and certified quickly by third-parties, since they are also facing labour shortages.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Thompson, however, can sidestep this problem with its in-house testing facilities, explains Colm McEvoy, vice president of corporate accounts. He says that the firm is able to meet its customers’ needs at present, though he adds, “We’re having to be very strategic with regards to the new customers.”

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: There are more than 650 people working at Thompson’s sites in Northern Ireland, but, at the time of writing, the company had more than a dozen job vacancies listed on its website. “We’re in competition with other manufacturing companies to try and secure the best talent,” says Mr McEvoy.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Despite this challenge, Thompson has a five-year plan to multiply its annual output of seats. Mr McEvoy shows me around the factory floor at the firm’s Portadown site, where workers are busy riveting aluminium seat parts together, and checking the complex wiring for the entertainment systems in these expensive structures – each seat costs “tens of thousands” to make, says Mr McEvoy.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: “This seat in front of you is the most complex seat we make,” adds Eoin Murray, operations manager. It takes around 100 hours for the highly skilled workers here to assemble in full.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Mr Murray is determined to boost the rate of production on this factory floor. He shows off a jig, developed in-house, upon which a seat can be mounted and angled so that workers can easily access the sides or underside. “This allows us to hit like a rate 14,” says Mr Murray – 14 seats produced in one shift. “I need to get to 18. To 20,” he adds.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: To that end, there’s another even more capable version of the jig in the room next door, a prototype that staff here hope will be even better. Mr Murray and his colleagues are also developing new working practices – such as utility belts with tools arranged in the sequence they are required.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: If the worker is left-handed, that sequence can be reversed so that the process of picking a tool and carrying out a task with it is as rapid as possible.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Workers here rehearse and hone key stages of seat assembly, which helps them go faster. A bit like learning how to build the same piece of Ikea furniture over and over again until it becomes like muscle memory, I suggest – just a lot more complicated.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: “We can seamlessly slot people in, and they can now work through these different stages with no computers,” says Mr Murray. “When I started working here, if you told me I would be working without a computer I’d have told you [that] you were crazy.”

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Besides volume, there is constant pressure to come up with new and better seat designs, says Mr McEvoy. Airlines want the latest and best entertainment technology, for example – 32 inch screens are now included in Thompson’s top seats.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: “They’re striving for something different, something that makes them unique,” Mr McEvoy adds. Thompson uses leather and soft fabrics on selected parts of the seat and enclosure to provide a luxury feel, which is increasingly popular with airlines. The seats themselves can recline into two-metre long, fully flat beds.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: One I try for myself is certainly comfortable – though I would probably have to lie in it for seven hours or so to test it properly, I think to myself.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: “They’re good firms, very, very good firms – they know what they’re doing,” says Marisa Garcia, an aviation industry analyst who used to work in seat manufacturing herself, referring to the Northern Ireland-based companies who make aircraft seats. She has no commercial relationship with any of them, she adds.

title: How airline seats became key tech products - BBC News
text: Despite supply chain headaches, seat manufacturers are in a good position to clean up, if they prove themselves able to keep pace with industry requirements, says Ms Garcia: “The demand is there from passengers – and the demand is there from airlines.”

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Deep under the Nevada desert in the 1980s the US conducted secret nuclear weapons research.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Among the experiments was an effort to see if nuclear fusion, the reaction which powers the sun, could be sparked on earth in a controlled setting.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: The experiments were classified, but it was widely known among physicists that the results had been promising, external.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: That knowledge caught the attention of two young graduate students working at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in the late 2000s, Conner Galloway and Alexander Valys.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: The Los Alamos lab was originally set up in 1943 as a top-secret site to develop the first nuclear weapons. Located near Santa Fe, New Mexico it is now a US government research and development facility.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: "When Alex and I learned about those tests at Los Alamos, our reaction was like 'wow, inertial fusion has already worked!'. Laboratory-scale pellets were ignited, the details were classified, but enough was made public that we knew that ignition was achieved," says Mr Galloway.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Nuclear fusion is the process of fusing hydrogen nuclei together, which produces immense amounts of energy. The reaction creates helium and not the long-lived radioactive waste of the fission process which is used in existing nuclear power stations.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: If fusion can be harnessed, then it promises abundant electricity, generated without producing CO2.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Those tests in the 1980s led to the US government building the National Ignition Facility (NIF) in California, a project to see if nuclear fuel pellets could be ignited using a powerful laser.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: After more than a decade of work, in late 2022 researchers at NIF made a breakthrough. Scientists conducted the first controlled fusion experiment to produce more energy from the reaction than that supplied by the lasers which sparked it.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: While physicists around the world marvelled at that breakthrough, it had taken the scientists at NIF much longer than expected.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: "They were energy starved," says Mr Galloway.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: He doesn't mean they needed more snacks, instead the NIF laser was only just powerful enough to ignite the fuel pellet.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Mr Galloway and Mr Valys think that more powerful lasers will make it possible to build a working fusion reaction that can supply electricity to the power grid. To do that they founded Xcimer, based in Denver.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: NIF had to make do with a laser that could pump out two megajoules of energy. Mr Galloway and Mr Valys are planning to experiment with lasers that can supply up to 20 megajoules of energy.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: "We think 10 to 12 [megajoules] is the sweet spot for a commercial power plant," says Mr Galloway.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Such a laser beam would hit the fuel capsule with a powerful punch. It would be like taking the energy of a 40-tonne articulated lorry travelling at 60mph and focussing it on the centimetre-sized capsule for a few billionths of a second.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: More powerful lasers will allow Xcimer to use larger and simpler fuel capsules than NIF, which found it difficult to perfect them.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Xcimer joins dozens of other organisations around the world trying to build a working fusion reactor.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: There are two main approaches. Smashing a fuel pellet with lasers falls under the category of inertial confinement fusion.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: The other way, known as magnetic confinement fusion, uses powerful magnets to trap a burning cloud of atoms called plasma.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Both approaches have daunting engineering challenges to overcome.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: In particular, how do you extract the heat generated during fusion so you can do something useful with it, like drive a turbine to make electricity?

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: "I suppose my scepticism is, I haven't yet even seen a persuasive conceptual diagram of how you manage the process of taking energy out while keeping the fusion reaction going," says Prof Ian Lowe at Griffith University in Australia.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: He has spent his long career working in energy research and policy.  While Prof Lowe supports the development of fusion technology, he just argues that a working fusion reactor won't come fast enough to help bring down CO2 emissions and tackle climate change.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: "My concern is that even the most optimistic view is that we'd be lucky to have commercial fusion reactors by 2050. And long before then we need to have decarbonized the energy supply if we're not going to melt the planet," he says.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Another challenge is that the fusion reaction produces high energy particles that will degrade steel, or any other material that lines the reactor core.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Those in the fusion industry don't deny the engineering challenges, but feel they can be overcome.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Xcimer plans to use a "waterfall" of molten salt flowing around the fusion reaction to absorb the heat.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: The founders are confident that they can fire the lasers and replace the fuel capsules (one every two seconds) while keeping that flow going.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: The flow of molten salt will also be thick enough to absorb high energy particles that could potentially damage the reactor.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: "We just have two relatively small laser beams coming in from either side [of the fuel pellet]. So you only need a gap in the flow big enough for those beams, and so you don't have to turn off and turn on the entire flow," says Mr Valys.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: But how quickly can them make such a system work?

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Xcimer plans to experiment with the lasers for two years, before building a target chamber, where they can target the fuel pellets.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: The final stage would be the working reactor, which they hope would be plugged into the electricity grid in the mid-2030s.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: To fund the first phase of their work, Xcimer has raised $100m (£77m) . The money will be used to build a facility in Denver and the prototype laser system.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: Hundreds of millions dollars more will be needed to build a working reactor.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: But for the founders of Xcimer, and other fusion start-ups, the prospect of cheap, carbon-free electricity is irresistible.

title: Fusion energy: Could powerful lasers power a working reactor? - BBC News
text: "You know, it'll change the trajectory of what's possible for humanity's progress," says Mr Valys.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: High on a mountain, in Chile's bone dry Atacama desert the European Southern Observatory (ESO) is currently building the world's largest optical telescope.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: No time was wasted on choosing a name -  it will be called the Extremely Large Telescope or ELT.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Instead, huge energy has gone into designing and building “the world’s biggest eye on the sky”, which should start collecting images in 2028 and is very likely to expand our understanding of the universe.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: None of that would be possible without some of the most advanced mirrors ever made.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Dr Elise Vernet is an adaptive optics specialist at ESO and has been overseeing development of the five giant mirrors that will gather and channel light to the telescope’s measuring equipment.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Each of the ELT’s custom mirrors is a feat of optical design.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Dr Vernet describes the 14ft (4.25m) convex M2 mirror as “a piece of art”.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: But perhaps the M1 and M4 mirrors best express the level of intricacy and precision required.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: The primary mirror, M1, is the largest mirror ever made for an optical telescope.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: “It’s 39m [128ft] in diameter, made up of [798] hexagonal mirror segments, aligned so that it behaves as a perfect monolithic mirror,” says Dr Vernet.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: M1 will collect 100 million times more light than the human eye and must be able to maintain position and shape to a level of precision 10,000 times finer than a human hair.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: The M4 is the largest deformable mirror ever made and will be able to change shape 1,000 times per second to correct for atmospheric turbulence and the vibrations of the telescope itself that could otherwise distort imagery.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Its flexible surface is made up of six petals of a glass-ceramic material that is less than 2mm (0.075in) thick.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: The petals were made by Schott in Mainz, Germany and then shipped to engineering firm Safran Reosc just outside Paris, where they were polished and assembled into the complete mirror.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: All five mirrors are nearing completion and will soon be transported to Chile for installation.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: While these enormous mirrors will be used to capture the light of the cosmos, ESO’s neighbours in Garching, at the Max Planck Institute for Quantum Optics, have created a quantum mirror to operate at the tiniest scales imaginable.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: In 2020, a research team was able to make a single layer of 200 aligned atoms behave collectively to reflect light, effectively creating a mirror so small it cannot be seen by the naked eye.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: In 2023, they succeeded in placing a single microscopically controlled atom at the centre of the array to create a “quantum switch” that can be used to control whether the atoms are transparent or reflective.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: “What theorists predicted, and we observed this experimentally, is that in these ordered structures, once you absorb a photon and it gets re-emitted, it's actually emitted [in one predictable] direction and this is what makes it a mirror,” says Dr Pascal Weckesser, a postdoctoral researcher at the institute.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: This ability to control the direction of atom-reflected light could have future applications in a number of quantum technologies like, for example, hack-proof quantum networks for storing and transmitting information.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Further north-west in Oberkochen near Stuttgart, mirrors with another extreme property are being made by Zeiss.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: The optics company spent years developing an ultra-flat mirror which has become a key component in the machines which print computer chips, called extreme ultraviolet lithography machines, or EUVs.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Dutch company ASML is the world's leading maker of EUVs, and Zeiss mirrors are an essential component of them.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: Zeiss’s EUV mirrors can reflect light at very small wavelengths which enables image clarity at a tiny scale, so more and more transistors can be printed on the same area of silicon wafer.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: To explain how flat the mirrors are, Dr Frank Rohmund, president of semiconductor manufacturing optics at Zeiss, uses a topographical analogy.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: “If you took a household mirror and blew it up to the size of Germany, the highest elevation point would be 5m. On a space mirror [as in the James Webb Space Telescope], it would be 2cm [0.75in]. On an EUV mirror, it would be 0.1mm,” he explains.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: This ultra-smooth mirror surface combined with systems that control the mirror’s positioning, also made by Zeiss, yield an accuracy level equivalent to bouncing light off an EUV mirror on the Earth’s surface and picking out a golf ball on the moon.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: While those mirrors may already sound extreme, Zeiss has plans for improvement, to help make even more powerful computer chips.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: “We have ideas about how to develop EUV further. By 2030, the goal is to have a microchip with one trillion transistors on it. Today, we are maybe at a hundred billion.”

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: That goal came closer with Zeiss's latest tech, which enables the printing of about three times more structures on the same area than the current generation of chip making machines.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: “The semiconductor industry has this dominating strong roadmap which provides a drumbeat for all players contributing to the solution. With this, we are able to provide progress in terms of microchip fabrication which today allows things like artificial intelligence which were unthinkable even ten years ago,” says Dr Rohmund.

title: The mind-bending mirrors behind advanced technology - BBC News
text: What humanity will understand and be capable of in ten years’ time remains to be seen, but mirrors will no doubt be at the heart of the technologies that take us there.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "All you can fly" - unlimited flights for an annual subscription fee. What's not to like? A fair amount, for some passengers, it turns out.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Wizz Air's new scheme under that title has divided opinion. Some have praised the €499 (£426) scheme's "insanely great" value on trips as far as the Maldives, and the budget airline says it has been "overwhelmed" by the positive response.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: But others hit out at the airline's service and recalled their own experience of delays, while questioning the scheme's terms and conditions.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Wizz says its new membership, effective from September, will allow frequent flyers to "save money, visit friends and family more regularly and spontaneously visit off-the-beaten-track destinations".

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: It says it sold out in most markets within 24 hours, but some customers have been pointing out what they describe as a "catch". Those who sign up can only book flights up to three days before departure and must pay a fee of about €10 per flight.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Flights do not include "trolley bags" to stow in overhead compartments or checked baggage. And crucially, the scheme is limited to just 10,000 people. It's also dependent on whether there are any seats left.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Wizz, which flies to 53 countries, carried 62 million passengers in the year to the end of March.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Its scheme is similar to those being offered by Frontier Airlines in the US and Malaysia-based AirAsia.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Rory Boland, editor of Which? Travel, advises passengers to look behind the enticing headline price to work out if this really is a good deal for them.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Once booking fees, seat selection and luggage costs are added on, travellers will see costs climb, he says - particularly as multiple short-notice journeys will be required to break even on the original cost of the subscription.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "It is also ironic to see an airline which claims to be Europe's 'greenest' encouraging consumers to take unlimited flights," he adds.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: The Hungarian airline has faced a number of hurdles in the last year, which it might be hoping to overcome with the new scheme.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: In June, the airline was named the worst for UK flight delays for the third year in a row, based on analysis of official data by the PA news agency.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: And in January, it had to pay an extra £1.2m to customers in compensation, after the industry regulator intervened over the way it had handled flight disruption.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Wizz Air points out that it has been working on improvements, such as investing an extra £90m in its operations and customer service last year. And it says 1.8% of its UK flights were delayed for more than three hours in the first half of this year - a 50% reduction on last year.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Talie Delemere, 34, is excited about the scheme and has already signed up. She lives near Luton airport and likes being able to travel whenever she likes.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "I travel a lot anyway, between eight and 12 times a year and I mostly travel with hand luggage," she tells the BBC.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "Wizz Air are a mixed bag but I don't find them any better or worse service-wise than any other low cost carriers and their aircraft are far nicer and more comfortable than Ryanair's."

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: But others are not convinced.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "You can subscribe to this scheme but you might never take off," says James Glenton, 36, from York, who is still hoping for compensation for a cancelled Wizz Air flight a year on.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: In July 2023, Wizz cancelled Mr Glenton's flight from Leeds Bradford Airport to Wroclaw in Poland and rebooked him on one from London Luton the next day, he says.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: That meant he lost two days of his holiday, the parking he'd booked at Leeds Bradford, money spent on his hotel, and the petrol costs getting to Luton and back, he says.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: According to Mr Glenton, Wizz has blamed air traffic control restrictions for the cancellation so won't refund him. But he claims the airport denies this and has told him it was the airline that cancelled the flight directly.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "I am not hopeful about a refund, I won’t get anything from them," he says. "I am angry, I would never fly with Wizz Air again."

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Mark Shatliff, 39, from Reading, also says he won't be signing up to the scheme.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: His Wizz Air flight from Istanbul to London was delayed by six hours last July and was so late when he landed that he had to pay an additional £120 for a taxi home, he says.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Wizz initially refused to refund him but relented when he took the matter to a dispute resolution company.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "I think people who subscribe to this scheme won’t get the value out of it," he tells the BBC.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "What you end up paying if things go wrong is so much more - it isn't worth it."

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: While Wizz said it could not comment on individual cases, it offered to look into James' and Mark's reports.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Travel expert Simon Calder thinks the scheme could be a good deal for some fliers but not others.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: He believes the subscription offer is aimed at travellers such as Eastern Europeans in the UK who go home regularly to see family. Wizz already offers other discount schemes for travellers, he adds.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: "People will do their sums and I’ve done mine, it won’t really work for me," he tells the BBC.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Some have raised concerns that the scheme could encourage frivolous flying that harms the environment, but Mr Calder thinks the impact will be minimal. He also thinks criticism of the airline's performance is overblown.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: Mr Calder says: "I fly on lots of airlines, if I want to be on time I generally go with Ryanair. In general I find Wizz and EasyJet pretty much the same.

title: Wizz Air: Is budget airline 'all you can fly' subscription too good to be true? - BBC News
text: While he says that Wizz's recovery "when things go wrong has historically not been great", they are still a "perfectly reasonable choice" for the thousands of passengers who may opt for its "all you can fly" option.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Despite interest rates falling in August, Guernsey is still waiting for mortgage rates to follow suit.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Lloyds Bank and Skipton have dropped their rates locally, but other providers were yet to follow suit.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: This contrasts to the UK where most banks and lenders have dropped rates following the Bank of England's decision to lower interest rates to 5% from 5.25% last month - the first cut since the start of the pandemic in March 2020.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Pierre Blampied, managing director of mortgage broker SPF Private Clients, said: "Banks are here to make a profit so they're going to take their time."

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Interest rates influence the cost of borrowing which affects high street banks and money lenders' rates for mortgages, he said.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Mr Blampied said he was "not expecting to see a big reduction in fixed rates imminently".

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: He said it was "a supply and demand market", adding "we don't have increased competition".

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Mr Blampied said: "In the UK a lender wants to be the first to reduce their rates - they'll get an avalanche of business.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: "Whereas here if they take their time to reduce the rates, it's not really going to make a massive difference.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: "We are relatively the equivalent of a small town in the UK, combining both Channel Islands, so they don't have to move as quickly onshore."

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Nick Paluch, director of Savills Guernsey, said he had "confidence that rates will drop," and the island was "heading in the right direction."

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: But he said the island "still needs mortgage rates to drop" to help boost property sales for first time buyers and starters.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: Mr Paluch said they had seen more activity in the middle and upper end of the property market since interest rates dropped last month.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: "The fact the market is now stable means the battle is half won."

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: A spokesperson for the Association of Guernsey Banks said setting mortgage rates was a "commercial decision for each bank", but the "Channel Islands mortgage market is different to the UK".

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: He said average house prices were "much higher" as was the ratio of property prices to average household incomes.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: He said: "It is also a much smaller market and Guernsey banks generally face higher operating costs and a different regulatory environment that affects funding models and overall cost of borrowing.

title: Mortgage rates yet to drop in Channel Islands  - BBC News
text: "Local mortgages also involve more complex local conveyance requirements than the UK."

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: The UK's economy grew by 0.6% between April and June as it continued its recovery from the recession at the end of last year.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: The latest figure was in line with forecasts and follows a 0.7% increase in the first three months of this year.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Growth was led by the services sector, in particular the IT industry, legal services and scientific research.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Services are the biggest contributor to the UK's economy, far outstripping manufacturing and construction, both of which saw output fall between April and June.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: "The UK economy has now grown strongly for two quarters, following the weakness we saw in the second half of last year,” said Liz McKeown, director of economic statistics at the Office for National Statistics, which released the figures.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Last year, the UK economy fell into a shallow and short-lived recession.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: A recession is defined as economic activity shrinking for two three-month periods – or quarters – in a row.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: While gross domestic product (GDP) - a key measure of all the economic activity of companies, governments and people - expanded over the latest quarter, growth was flat in June.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: While the services sector helped economic expansion over the three months, it was a drag on the performance in June alone.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Strike action by junior doctors affected growth. NHS England reported that 61,989 appointments were cancelled because of industrial action by junior doctors between 27 June and 2 July.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Economists also warned that growth might slow in the second half of 2024.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Anna Leach, chief economist at the Institute of Directors, said businesses were reporting modest activity for the summer months "no doubt affected by still high interest rates".

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Earlier in August, the Bank of England trimmed interest rates to 5% in its first cut for four years.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: “The challenge for government is to firmly lift the UK’s growth performance out of the doldrums," said Ms Leach.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: "There’re no quick fixes here: we’ll need the government to follow-through on its manifesto commitments to set and stick with long-term infrastructure investment plans."

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: The economy was a key battleground in the general election which Labour won in a landslide after 14 years of a Conservative government.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer pledged to take “take the brakes off Britain” and in the King’s Speech announced a number of plans, including changes to the planning system to make it easier to build houses and infrastructure.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Chancellor Rachel Reeves said: "The new government is under no illusion as to the scale of the challenge we have inherited after more than a decade of low economic growth."

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: But shadow chancellor Jeremy Hunt said that the GDP figures "are yet further proof that Labour have inherited a growing and resilient economy".

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Activity in the manufacturing sector was mixed in the three months to June. While  it was down overall during the quarter, there was growth in June.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Matthew Knight, commercial manager at RNA, a Birmingham-based firm which designs and make automation equipment, told the BBC: "Business is very good, we’re very busy. We can sell into different countries, if one area or country isn’t doing well, we can sell into another."

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: He said that business is picking up. "Interest rates falling might have something to do with it, because a lot of customers finance the equipment RNA makes, rather than purchasing it direct," he said.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: The ONS data also revealed that output from the construction sector dipped by 0.1% between April and June as new building declined, though repair and maintenance work grew.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: The ONS said that the pace of decline in the sector was easing, but a survey of businesses conducted by the Bank of England found that “any improving sentiment is not expected to translate to activity until later this year”.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Construction could be boosted if the Bank cuts interest rates again this year.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: This week, new inflation data revealed that the rate had increased to 2.2% in the year to July.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: That is higher than the Bank of England's 2% inflation target. However, inflation in the services sector - which the Bank also looks at when deciding on interest rates - continued to ease.

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: Capital Economics said that although the services sector grew between April and June "recent strength of activity won’t prevent further falls in services inflation".

title: UK economy continues recovery with 0.6% growth  - BBC News
text: It said it expects to the Bank to cut interest rates twice more this year to 4.5%.
