title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Next month's Budget will involve "difficult decisions" on tax, spending and welfare, the Chancellor Rachel Reeves has told the BBC.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: The new chancellor has faced mounting criticism after cutting Winter Fuel Payments for all but the poorest pensioners.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: But she said it was the "right decision" and there were further tough decisions to come.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Her warning comes as new figures show the UK economy failed to grow in July, after flatlining in June.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: The July figure is a knock-back for the new government, which has named boosting the economy as one of its key priorities.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Speaking to the BBC, Reeves tried to paint a positive picture for future growth, but warned of the need for further belt-tightening this autumn.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: “I’ve been really clear that the Budget on 30 October will require difficult decisions on tax, on spending, and on welfare," she said.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: "But the prize - if we can bring stability back to our economy, if we can bring investment back to Britain - is economic growth, good jobs, paying decent wages in all parts of our country, to realise the huge potential that we have.”

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: The Chancellor said she faced a £22bn "black hole" in the public finances this year, although about £9bn of that reflects her decision to award and fund above-inflation public sector pay deals.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Speculation is building over which taxes she might raise in the Budget or whether she might tweak the debt targets she has pledged to stick to.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: These are known as the fiscal rules and are self-imposed by government to manage its borrowing within a five-year time-frame. Changing these rules would give Reeves more flexibility over tax and spending plans. She has so far refused to rule out altering them.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: The Chancellor also referred to Amazon's announcement on Wednesday of plans to spend £8bn building data centres in the UK.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: She said this would "help rebuild Britain and make every part of the country better off".

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: The lack of growth in July also means the Treasury has missed out on the boost to tax revenues that would have come with a stronger economic performance.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Analysts had forecast growth of 0.2% for the month of July.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: A summer of sport, including the Euros and the Olympics, helped boost the services sector, but production and construction output both fell.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Despite the lack of growth in July, Liz McKeown, director of economic statistics at the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said "longer term strength in the services sector meant there was growth over the last three months as a whole".

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Services growth was led by computer programmers and the health sector, which recovered from strike action in June. But there was a drop in output for advertising, architects and engineers, Ms McKeown added.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: It was a "particularly poor" month for car and machinery firms, she added.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: The ONS monitors GDP - or gross domestic product - on a monthly basis, but more attention is paid to the trend over three months.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Monthly figures are an early estimate and are often revised slightly after more data comes in.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: At the end of last year the UK fell into a shallow recession, with the economy failing to grow for two three-month periods in a row. But the first half of 2024 saw a return to growth.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: "The economy stagnated in July... but that doesn’t mean the UK is on the cusp of another recession," said Ruth Gregory at Capital Economics.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: "And we can take some comfort from the fact that services output rose by 0.1% month on month."

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: The ONS said retailers and hospitality venues noted an uptick in business in July as the England men's football team progressed through the European championships.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Gillian Fletcher, general manager for Spinningfields, which runs food and drink venues in Manchester, said they had screened the Euros, Wimbledon and the Olympics over the summer and had found people were "in the market" for that kind of experience.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: “It's not that people don't want to spend money or they don't want to go out. It's just the economic landscape has changed," she said.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: "We've had a really, really great year and summer... and that's proof that if you've got the right recipe, people will come.”

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: However, some restaurants told the ONS the football tournament had had a negative impact on footfall.

title: Rachel Reeves warns of difficult decisions ahead in Budget - BBC News
text: Despite some travel agents seeing an increase in bookings because of the Paris Olympics, overall bookings fell month on month, the ONS said.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: A total of nine offshore wind farm contracts have been awarded by the government after last year's auction failed to attract any bidders at all.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: The contracts are part of a wider slate of green energy projects that also include tidal and solar power, and will provide enough electricity to fuel the equivalent of 11 million UK homes, the government said.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: However, while the new offshore wind projects have been broadly welcomed, some experts questioned whether they would generate enough capacity to meet renewable energy targets set for 2030.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Households are also facing higher energy bills later this year, with a typical bill to rise by 10%.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: On Tuesday, a total of 131 contracts have been awarded to firms for projects which will generate 9.6 gigawatts (GWs) of renewable energy.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: The new offshore projects include what will be Europe's largest and second-largest wind farms, Hornsea 3 and Hornsea 4, which will be built off the Yorkshire coast by Ørsted, the Danish energy giant that is majority-owned by the state.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: The contracts are boost to the UK's renewable energy sector, after no companies bid in the auction to build offshore wind farms last September.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Back then, the industry said the guarantee price offered by the then Conservative government for electricity generated by the wind farms did not take into account higher costs such as construction materials, which had risen because of inflation.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Keith Anderson, chief executive of Scottish Power, said offshore wind was "back on track after last year’s misstep".

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: "It will allow investment into manufacturing in the UK. It allows the sector to get back up and running and it puts the government back on track for hitting targets, really important targets to decarbonise the sector," he told the BBC's Today programme.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Scottish Power's parent company Iberdrola won contracts to build capacity at its East Anglia offshore wind farm project.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: The Labour government is aiming to produce 60GW of energy through offshore wind farms by 2030.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: The offshore wind farm projects announced on Tuesday provide capacity of 4.9GW.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Pranav Menon, a research associate at Aurora Energy Research, said the government still has some way to go to meet its goal.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: "It still falls short of the pace required to meet its ambitious targets," he said.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: A number of contracts announced on Tuesday had been previously been awarded in 2022 but companies re-bid in this auction to get a better price for the electricity generated from offshore wind farms.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Mr Menon next year’s auction would be "the last chance" to procure enough capacity for delivery before 2030, with an additional 31GW needed to meet the target 60GW target for offshore wind.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Campaign group Greenpeace warned that "the government clearly needs to take a hard look at how this system is working".

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Ami McCarthy, Greenpeace UK's political campaigner, said: "5GW of offshore wind is of course welcome, but it is only about half of what is required each year to meet the government's 2030 target.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: "The last renewables contract auction was a catastrophic failure, and in fact the biggest disaster for clean energy in almost a decade - because of this, the new government has an uphill battle."

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Energy Secretary Ed Miliband said the new government had "inherited a broken energy policy", but claimed "these results show that together, this government and the energy industry are securing investment into our country".

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: He hailed Tuesday's auction as a "significant step forward" in the government's aim of achieving "energy independence and lower bills for good".

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: Gas and electricity prices rose in 2021 as the global economy began to re-open from lockdowns implemented in the Covid pandemic. The increase accelerated the following year following the invasion of Ukraine by Russia, which is a major oil and gas producer.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News
text: While the long-term aim is to bring energy prices down and lessen the UK's reliance on overseas providers, it will take some time for consumers to benefit.

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News

title: Nine offshore wind farm projects awarded in UK auction - BBC News

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: The public are being warned about fake bottles of Glen’s Vodka which have been found to contain an industrial solvent that can cause death in severe cases.

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: The Food Standards Agency (FSA) said some 35cl counterfeit bottles have been found to contain isopropyl alcohol, which is not intended for human consumption.

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: The fake vodka may have a strange smell and taste differently to genuine vodka, the FSA warned.

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: It comes a day after Food Standards Scotland, external (FSS) warned that fake Glen's Vodka had been found in local convenience stores in Glasgow and Lanarkshire.

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: In a statement, the FSA - which covers England, Wales and Northern Ireland - said it "has been made aware of the production and distribution of counterfeit vodka labelled as Glen’s Vodka".

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: "Products sampled were found to contain isopropyl alcohol, so they are unsafe. Isopropyl alcohol is an industrial solvent and is not intended for human consumption," it said.

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: Drinking the solvent "can quickly lead to alcohol poisoning and in severe cases death", the FSA said., external

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: It advises consumers to check for a "laser etched lot code applied to the bottle between the rear label and the base of the bottle".

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: The FSA says that isopropyl has "a strong odour and it may be possible to detect contaminated products by smell alone".

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: "If the vodka has a strong smell, do not consume it. Instead store it in a safe place and report it to your local authority for further instruction and advice," the agency said.

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: After the FSS released a warning in Scotland on Tuesday, a spokesperson for the Loch Lomond Group, which owns Glen’s Vodka, said: “Our priority is the health and safety of the public which includes our many thousands of loyal Glen’s customers.

title: Alert issued over potentially deadly fake bottles of Glen's Vodka - BBC News
text: "We are working hard to support the excellent efforts of Food Standards Scotland and the other authorities involved to address the matter urgently."

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: After years of declining defence spending in many Western countries, the war in Ukraine since 2022 has led to a huge increase.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: While Nato member states are not directly involved in the conflict, support for Kyiv has ramped up production of weapons and other military equipment.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: And longer-term concerns about Russia has meant that Nato countries are continuing to increase their own armament stockpiles.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: For defence firms like the UK’s BAE Systems, it has meant a surge in sales over the past three years. This month the company announced that its latest half-year revenues were up to £13.4bn, 13% higher, external than the same period in 2023.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Meanwhile, its order backlog now stands at £74.1bn, its highest ever. “We will keep investing in new technologies, facilities and our people, so that we can deliver on our record order backlog, and help our government customers stay ahead in an uncertain world,” said BAE’s chief executive Charles Woodburn.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: But how easy or otherwise has it been for Western defence firms to increase production? And how long will the demand boom last?

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: To boost armament production since 2022 it has mainly been a matter of increasing output at existing factories. But this is not quite as easy as it sounds.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Many sites had only really been ticking over, if that, for years. This made expanding production not something that could be done quickly or easily.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Andrew Kinniburgh, director general of Make UK Defence, one of the industry’s trade bodies gives me an example.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: “If you look at the Nlaw [a shoulder-fired anti-tank missile system] designed by [Swedish firm] Saab, and built by Thales in Belfast, they hadn’t had any new orders for many years, and the production line was basically mothballed.”

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Then in 2022, Saab got a £229m contract, external from the UK Ministry of Defence (MoD) for thousands more Nlaws, with many of these to be assembled in Belfast by Thales over the next four years. Going from “mothballed” to fulfilling an order of that size is quite the challenge for any factory.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: The facility has more recently won a £176m order from the MoD for a separate weapon, Thales' lightweight multi-role missiles.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: “I’m incredibly proud of our Belfast workforce, who have massively stepped up to the challenge," says Alex Cresswell, chief executive of Thales in the UK. "This has included new shift patterns, and processes being implemented to maximise working time.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: “Since just before the invasion of Ukraine up to this year, just a little over two years, factory outputs have doubled. It’s doubled to the most this factory has produced in living memory. And then in the next couple of years it will double again.”

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Much of the West’s armed forces have not been prepared for the possibility of fighting a major conflict since the end of the Cold War. The only ammunition they really use is during training, and stockpiles of weapons are very low.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: A sizeable chunk of what they did have in storage has been given to Ukraine, and now needs replacing. And future stockpiles need to be much larger.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Mr Kinniburg says that Western governments are going to have to help defence firms significantly invest in both new production facilities and storage space for armaments.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Building more weapons and increasing ammunition supplies is very expensive, but Nato nations are finding the money. As the International Institute for Strategic Studies reported recently: “Overall, total Nato spending increased by 11% in 2024, compared to 3% in 2023.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Growth was even stronger among Nato’s European members, “who increased their combined military spending by 19% in real terms in 2024”, said the study.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: In the UK, Kier Starmer, the new Labour Prime Minister, has reaffirmed the government’s commitment to increase defence spending, external to 2.5% of GDP, up from 2%.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: It comes as Russia has significantly ramped up its arms production, and increased imports from North Korea, external and Iran. Meanwhile, although China denies sending Russia weapons, it does supply Moscow with "dual-use items" - those with both commercial and military applications.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Stuart Dee, research leader in defence and security at the Rand Europe think tank, says that increased military spending across Nato members is unlikely to be a temporary phenomenon. “More than two years in, the conflict in Ukraine is increasingly unlikely to be a short.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: “Moreover, the security situation that emerges after the Ukraine conflict, whenever that is, is increasingly unclear, with potential security challenges across the globe. We are likely to see a sustainment of the increased defence spending across the board, as states around the globe adjust away from what has been a relatively benign period.”

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: But defence manufacturers do not seem convinced yet, they have spent decades being rather unloved. Mr Dee says that means Western governments are trying to persuade them they are now back in favour and will stay in favour.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: “Governments are attempting to give surety, that this is a long-term supply deal,” he says. “That this is not just a two-second thing, and then you will be back to another 30 years of decline.”

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Governments are trying to press home that message. Dr Cynthia Cook is a senior fellow at the International Security programme, and the head of the defence industry initiatives group at the Washington-based Center for Strategic and International Studies.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: She says one way for governments to do this is by placing long-term orders now. “The challenge for defence firms is not really solely how long the war in Ukraine is going to last, and whether it is worthwhile investing, but who is going to pay?

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: “One of the signals that governments can send is to have long-term, multi-year contracts that tells industry they are going to get the money back from these investments.”

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: But that is not defence firms’ only problem. New investments and capacities push up costs, and the next time the government is tendering for supplies of ammunition, the company that didn’t invest to increase production, might well be able to undercut the company that did. Knowing which way to jump is difficult.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Then there is the problem of recruitment, people are wary of joining an industry that was ignored and run down until the war in Ukraine broke out. People are not exactly queuing to join an industry and devote their lives to it, when it has been in the doldrums for so long.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Even so, defence manufacturers from Lockheed Martin and General Dynamics in the US, German’s Rheinmetall, Sweden’s Saab, and the UK’s BAE Systems, are continuing to see a boom in orders. This is reflected in their soaring share prices.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Meanwhile, the FTSE All-Share Defence and Aerospace index has risen by more than half , externalover the past year.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Then, of course, there are the lessons to be learnt from the war in Ukraine. Experts from the world’s armed forces and their suppliers are poring over the data from the battlefield.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Makers of military drones, seem to be the first major gainers from this analysis, it is a new technology which is cheap, easy to use and is having a decisive effect on the future of warfare. It is a sector where small and medium-sized companies are making a name for themselves.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: That in turns means there will be more spending on anti-drone capability. No country can afford to shoot down £500 drones with missiles that cost hundreds of thousands of pounds and take months to replace for very long.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: War is good for business, but it has also usually been good too for developing new technologies and weapons, and then developing the response to those new weapons.

title: Defence firms 'need reassuring' that big orders will be long-term - BBC News
text: Ukraine is just accelerating that process, if at a huge cost in human lives and misery.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: With business slumping, Apple has been under pressure to show what it will offer buyers to jumpstart a new wave of iPhone sales.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: On Monday, the technology giant revealed its hand - the iPhone 16 which has a camera button on the outside of the handset.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: The button is an external clue to the changes Apple said it had made inside its latest smartphone, aimed at harnessing the latest in artificial intelligence (AI).

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Apple's chief executive Tim Cook said the upgrades would "push the boundaries of what a smartphone can do" but the firm has tough competition, as other brands have already integrated generative AI features into their handsets.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Apple's share price fell during its  "Glowtime" event, where it unveiled the iPhone 16 as well as other products, and ended the day flat. The company, worth $3 trillion, is facing concern that it is losing its edge in the burgeoning area of artificial intelligence.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Sales of the iPhone - Apple's most important product which accounts for around half of its total sales - have stalled in recent months. They slipped by 1% over the nine months ended 29 June compared with a year earlier.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Apple said its new phones, which come with longer lasting batteries, more powerful chips and enhanced privacy features, were its first built specifically to handle AI and its new "Apple Intelligence" tools, many of which were announced in June.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Those include new tools for writing and creating new emojis as well incorporating OpenAI's chatbot ChatGPT into Siri to help users with some queries and text generation requests.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: On Monday, Apple also announced updates to its Apple Watch and its AirPod headphones, which will allow them to automatically drop the volume when users start in-person conversations and to decline calls with the shake of a head.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: It said the Pro version of its AirPods would be able to be used as a "clinical grade" personal hearing aid for people with mild or moderate hearing loss.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: The company said it was expecting marketing approval from regulators for the device "soon" and the feature would be available this autumn in more than 100 countries, including the US, Germany and Japan.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Previously, the company had a feature that allowed people to pair hearing aids with iPhones and other devices.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: The products were rolled out at a glossy event where protestors gathered in a designated free speech area across the street, urging executives to ramp up efforts to protect children from dangerous content in the company’s App Store.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: The protest featured a life-sized blow-up made to resemble Mr Cook.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Sales of the new range start in September, with prices for the iPhone16 starting at $799.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: But the Apple Intelligence features are not set to be available on operating systems until October, starting in the US and heading to other countries in the following months. They will be available in the UK in December.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Ben Wood, chief analyst at the market research firm CCS Insight, said it was likely that many people would dismiss the company's new camera control as a "glorified shutter button".

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: But he said it offered "very significant" upgrades, including visual, AI-powered search and he came away from the presentation persuaded that Apple would win over customers.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: "The combination of Apple Intelligence and new camera features on the iPhone 16 will help spur upgrades from loyal Apple customers," he said. "Particularly as Apple is positioning this latest update as being a future-proof purchase for customers wanting to get Apple Intelligence features as they roll out over the next few years."

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Apple has been slower than rivals Samsung and Google to bake generative AI features for photo editing, translation and web browsing into its devices.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Competitors are now building them into folding, flipping and even tri-folding smartphones.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Pre-orders for Huawei's new tri-fold phone, the Mate XT, reportedly, external hit more than three million on Monday.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: Gartner analyst Annette Zimmermann said because Apple was rolling out AI-ready smartphones later than rivals, it was "critical" they deliver.

title: Apple banks on AI to boost sales of new iPhone 16 - BBC News
text: She warned that rolling the features out before they were ready could risk their reputation or prompt sales losses.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: Workers who leave the head office to buy a cup of coffee are costing an Australian mining firm too much money, according to its boss.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: Managing director of Mineral Resources Chris Ellison said during a financial results presentation on Wednesday he wants to "hold staff captive all day long".

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "I don't want them leaving the building," he said.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: The head office in Perth has a restaurant, nine staff psychologists, a gym, and other facilities designed to encourage staff to stay in the office.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "We have a lot of different benefits that we have brought on," said Mr Ellison, whose company has a strict "no work from home policy".

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "Why have I done that? Because when I get them first thing in the morning, I want to hold them captive all day long. I don't want them leaving the building.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "I don't want them walking down the road for a cup of coffee. We kind of figured out a few years ago how much that costs."

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: He said the rest of the mining industry should "get on board" with his thinking on the benefits of working in the office rather than at home.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "The industry cannot afford it. We can't have people working three days a week and picking up five days a week pay - or four days."

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: The company culture at Mining Resources also extends to Mr Ellison's views on parents, with the company building a day-care centre on site big enough for 105 children.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "Another reason for them to come in and enjoy work," he said.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "Drop their little tykes off next door. We have doctors on board and nurses who are going to feed them, but mum and dad will be working in our office."

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: Mr Ellison is not the only boss to enforce a no work from home policy.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: Last week, the head of London-based smartphone maker Nothing sent an all-staff email to announce the end of hybrid working and a move to fully office-based work.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "I know this is a controversial decision that may not be a fit for everyone, and there are definitely companies out there that thrive in remote or hybrid setups," he wrote in the email.

title: Mineral Resources' boss opposes staff leaving office for coffee - BBC News
text: "But that’s not right for our type of business, and won’t help us fully realize our potential as a company."

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Apple has been ordered to pay Ireland €13bn (£11bn; $14bn) in unpaid taxes by Europe's top court, putting an end to an eight-year row.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The European Commission accused Ireland of giving Apple illegal tax advantages in 2016, but Ireland has consistently argued against the need for the tax to be paid.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The Irish government said it would respect the ruling.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Apple said it was disappointed with the decision and accused the European Commission of "trying to retroactively change the rules".

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: A separate European Court of Justice (ECJ) ruling on Tuesday also brought a long-running case with Google to a close, with the company ordered to pay a €2.4bn (£2bn) fine for market dominance abuse.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager praised both judgements. "Today is a huge win for European citizens and tax justice," she said.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: In the Apple case, the ECJ said: "The Court of Justice gives final judgment in the matter and confirms the European Commission’s 2016 decision: Ireland granted Apple unlawful aid which Ireland is required to recover."

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The ruling puts an end to a lengthy back and forth legal process.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The original decision covered the period from 1991 to 2014, and related to the way in which profits generated by two Apple subsidiaries based in Ireland were treated for tax purposes.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Those tax arrangements were deemed to be illegal because other companies were not able to obtain the same advantages.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: That ruling came at a time when the Commission was attempting to clamp down on multinational giants it believed were using creative financial arrangements to reduce their tax bills.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: It was overturned by the lower court of the ECJ in 2020 following an appeal by Ireland.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: However, that verdict has now been set aside by the higher court, which said it contained legal errors.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Apple said in a statement: "This case has never been about how much tax we pay, but which government we are required to pay it to. We always pay all the taxes we owe wherever we operate and there has never been a special deal.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: "The European Commission is trying to retroactively change the rules and ignore that, as required by international tax law, our income was already subject to taxes in the US.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: "We are disappointed with today’s decision as previously the General Court reviewed the facts and categorically annulled this case," Apple added.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The bad news for Apple comes a day after the tech giant released its new iPhone 16 range.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The ECJ ruling means Ireland will have to recover the lost taxes from Apple – something Dublin has spent years of legal wrangling trying to avoid.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The Irish government has argued that Apple should not have to repay the back taxes, deeming that its loss was worth it to make the country an attractive home for large companies.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Ireland, which has one of the lowest corporate tax rates in the EU, is Apple's base for Europe, the Middle East and Africa.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Although corporation tax rates for businesses are set nationally, and are not subject to the EU's jurisdiction, the trade bloc does have extensive powers to regulate state aid and in this case, it argued that by applying very low tax rates to Apple, Ireland was granting it an unfair subsidy.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The latest decision is a colossal victory for the European Commission in its attempts to stop big companies bending the rules.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The Irish government said the issue in the Apple case was "now of historical relevance only" and said the process of transferring assets to Ireland would now begin.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Tove Maria Ryding from the European Network on Debt and Development, an association of trade unions and non-governmental organisations, welcomed the ECJ's decision but stressed "our tax problem is more than just one rotten apple".

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: She said the case addressed tax matters dating back over 20 years and was "a perfect illustration of the chaotic corporate tax system we have".

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: “What we urgently need is a fundamental reform that can give us a tax system that is fair, effective, transparent and predictable," she said.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Europe's top court has also ruled that Google must pay a €2.4bn fine for abusing the market dominance of its shopping comparison service.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: The tech giant had been appealing against the fine, which was originally levied by the European Commission in 2017.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: Google said it was disappointed with the ruling, and pointed out it had made changes in 2017 to comply with the Commission's decision.

title: Apple told to pay Ireland €13bn in tax by EU - BBC News
text: At the time it was the largest penalty the Commission had ever levied - though a year later it issued Google with an even bigger fine of €4.3bn over claims it used Android software to unfairly promote its own apps.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: A competition watchdog has begun an investigation into Carlsberg's £3.3bn agreement to buy soft drinks company Britvic, best known for Robinsons squash and J2O.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: The Danish brewer said it wanted create a single beverage company called Carlsberg Britvic to grow its business in the UK and western Europe.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: However, Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) has been investigating potential concerns that it could reduce competition across the UK market.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: Britvic, external, which is based in Hemel Hempstead, Hertfordshire, had previously rejected a £3.1bn bid, but both companies announced an agreement in July.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: The two drinks giants said the integration of Carlsberg's array of beers with Britvic's soft drinks would create an "enlarged international group" that could expand into "multiple drinks sectors".

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: The CMA said it planned on gathering information before kickstarting a formal investigation.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: CMA is a competition watchdog which looks into concerns such as whether a merger or takeover could result in market dominance at the expense of consumers with higher prices, lower quality products or less choice for customers.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: People have been invited to have their say on the potential impact it could have on competition in the UK and submit their thoughts to the watchdog.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: Carlsberg, external, which also owns lager brands including Kronenbourg1664 and Brooklyn, said it believed the integration with Britvic could secure it £100m in cost efficiencies a year.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: Britvic also holds an exclusive licence with US partner PepsiCo to make and sell brands such as Pepsi, 7up and Lipton iced tea in the UK.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: The acquisition was approved by Britvic's shareholders last month, with the firms expecting to complete the deal in the first few months of 2025 should they get the approval from the competition regulator.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: Ten years ago, Britvic closed its bottling plant in Chelmsford in Essex, where it was founded, but it still has factories in Leeds, Beckton in east London, and Rugby, with centres in Lutterworth, Solihull and Tamworth.

title: Carlsberg takeover of Britvic investigated by competition watchdog - BBC News
text: Carlsberg's brewery network, external includes the Carlsberg brewery in Northampton, Marston’s in Burton upon Trent and Banks’s in Wolverhampton.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: The head of the US central bank has said "the time has come" for officials to cut interest rates, but he offered few clues as to how quickly or how far borrowing costs might come down.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: The speech from Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell was being closely watched, as rising unemployment has revived concerns about how the US economy is holding up under higher interest rates.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: Mr Powell said the bank was increasingly focused on the job market, as it gains confidence that the US was moving past the surging prices that started during the pandemic.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: Inflation, which tracks the pace of price rises, fell to 2.9% in the US last month, its lowest rate since March 2021.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: "The time has come for policy to adjust," Mr Powell said, speaking from a conference in Jackson Hole, Wyoming, while adding that the timing and pace of cuts would depend on data.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: The remarks signalled the start of a new fight for the Fed, after more than two years focused on stabilising prices.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: In his own speech on Friday, Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey said it was "too early" to declare victory over inflation in the UK, despite the Bank's decision to cut rates at its most recent meeting.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: "We need to be cautious because the job is not completed – we are not yet back to target on a sustained basis," he said. "The course will therefore be a steady one."

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: In the US, the Fed has kept its key lending rate at roughly 5.3% - a two-decade high - since last July, holding off on cuts pursued by central banks in other countries, including the UK.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: Mr Powell has argued the US economy was healthy enough to handle the high interest rates, pointing to a steady streak of job gains, which has helped households weather the jump in prices and uptick in borrowing costs.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: But those gains have slowed significantly since last year and the jobless rate has ticked up to 4.3%, reviving fears that the Fed's policies will knock the expansion off course and throw millions of people out of work.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: The US has experienced economic recession after most of the Fed's previous rate-rising campaigns.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: In his speech, Mr Powell acknowledged a significant slowdown in the job market, saying the Fed did not "seek or welcome further cooling".

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: But he pushed back against concerns about another recession in the near future, arguing that the rise in unemployment was consistent with a slowdown in hiring, not a sudden spike in job cuts.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: "There is good reason to think that the economy will get back to 2% inflation while maintaining a strong labour market," he said, adding later that the "pandemic economy" had proven to be "unlike any other".

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: Stock markets rose after Mr Powell's comments, which sent the Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq all up more than 0.5%.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: Analysts said the speech had made it all but certain that the bank would cut rates by at least 0.25 percentage points at its meeting next month as is currently expected - or perhaps by more.

title: Jerome Powell: Time has come for interest rate cut, says Fed boss - BBC News
text: "The lack of any guidance suggests that Powell is keeping his options open," said Stephen Brown, deputy chief North American economist at Capital Economics, after the speech.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: Surfing was first introduced to Australia more than a century ago.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: Since then the sport has blossomed into a cultural phenomenon and a commercial juggernaut.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: Research from the Australian National University (ANU) estimates surfing injects at least A$3bn ($2bn; £1.5bn) into the national economy each year.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: The study, however, comes with a stark warning that surf breaks - areas where the waves start to collapse or plunge - should not be taken for granted and need more legal protection.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “Unfortunately because of climate change, coastal erosion and competition for coastal spaces, the elements that make these high quality waves possible are on many occasions in danger,” explained Dr Ana Manero, an expert in water economics and governance at the ANU’s Crawford School of Public Policy.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “I don’t think the lack of protection right now is deliberate. It is just surf breaks currently they just fall in a blind spot for policy makers.”

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: Global warming and poor water quality are surfers’ main concerns, according to the report published in the journal, Marine Policy.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: About a dozen surf breaks in the state of New South Wales and Bells Beach in Victoria have formal protection but researchers want much more.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “What I am more worried about is those waves that may not feature on a world-class map but they do provide value for people like you and I,” Dr Manero told the BBC from her office in Perth, Western Australia.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “Those waves that do not attract global attention... are the waves we need to focus our attention on.”

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: A previous ANU study found waves off the town of Mundaka in northern Spain vanished because of changes to a sand bar after dredging in a nearby river.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: Research also found that expansion to a marina in Perth caused the disappearance of three surf breaks in 2022 and an artificial reef has now been proposed.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: Some answers for Australia might be found far away in South America or much closer to home.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “In Peru they established what they call La Ley de Rompientes, which means the law of surf breaks, that protects these assets,” added Dr Manero.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: In New Zealand, safeguards are provided by an existing act of parliament and a separate, complementary policy that recognises the importance of national, regional and local surf spots. The level of protection they receive is commensurate to their level of significance to surfers.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: Using data from the Australian Sports Commission, a government agency, the ANU study estimates there are more than 720,000 active adult surfers in the country.  On average they spend about A$3,700 each year.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: It is, though, likely to be a conservative figure because it does not consider children, overseas tourists or money generated through professional surfing.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “It is like this cool economy; cafes, restaurants, surf shops, accommodation. Yeah, it’s good. Love it,” said Matt Grainger, who runs the Manly Surf School in Sydney.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “I’ve had the business for 30 years. Just looking forward, I pretty much see it [with] just a slow growth. So, we try not to grow too fast here like with the surf school because you don’t want to crowd out the actual ocean with too many surfers.”

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “Once you’ve got your board, it’s free and it’s always different; the tide, the wind, the swell,” he told the BBC.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: On a bright and breezy winter’s morning on Australia’s Pacific coast, Mika Flower, an instructor, is preparing to take charge of another lesson.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: The work to conquer, or attempt to master, a wave begins with repetitive drills on the sand.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “I have surfed my whole life. It’s super fun,” Ms Flower explains.

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: “I thought I would love to be able to teach people and share the joy of surfing, and it is nice to not be working in an office. It is nice to be working at the beach getting sunshine and being in the water every day. Australia is, sort of, seen as the country to surf. Everyone wants to jump on the bandwagon.”

title: Why protecting Australia's surf breaks is crucial to the country's economy - BBC News
text: For those chasing the perfect wave, surfing is about embracing the power of nature.  For them, it’s a gift that should be protected.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Donald Trump's media company was hit by a fresh round of selling on Wednesday, wiping out gains the share price had enjoyed this year alongside the rising political fortunes of its namesake.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Shares fell more than 6% to less than $17, which is less than what they were worth at the start of 2024.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: The share price, which hit a peak in April during the former president's criminal trial, has fallen more than 70% from its high.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: The firm, operator of the social media platform Truth Social, still boasts a market value of more than $3.3bn - a hefty sum for a small company with shrinking revenue and growing losses.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Mr Trump's victory in the January Republican primary had helped to stoke interest in the Trump Media at the start of the year.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Buyers snapped up shares of Digital World Acquisition Corp., a publicly-traded shell company, which was created to buy Trump Media and was seen on Wall Street as a proxy for the firm.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Demand jumped farther around the time the merger was formally completed in March.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: The price has swung wildly in the months since.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Its most recent high came in July, after Trump survived an assassination attempt and before President Joe Biden bowed out of the race, but the price has slid lower in recent weeks.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: The falls come as the company approaches the date at which Trump and other early investors will be free to start selling their shares.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Mr Trump's stake is currently worth about $2bn, down from more than $6bn a few months ago.

title: Trump Media shares erase 2024 gains - BBC News
text: Analysts had warned investors to expect big swings in value, describing it as a "meme stock", propelled by sentiment rather than its financial characteristics.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Estate agents are reporting a big increase in housing market activity as people respond to the recent cut in interest rates by the Bank of England.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: One agent in Frome, Somerset, said they had recently experienced their "busiest day for three years" with record numbers registering to buy and sell homes.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Prices are still high - official figures show house prices have risen for four months in a row in Somerset.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: But lower mortgage rates have seen more people look to buy a home, and also to sell.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Will Parfitt has been selling homes in Frome for 26 years.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: He said the last two years had been "the hardest of my career", after mortgage rates rose sharply following the mini-budget of former Prime Minister Liz Truss.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: But the recent rate cut from the Bank of England had prompted many people back into the market.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: He now runs the Forest & Marble agency, handling sales and lettings in Somerset.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: He said: "Yesterday was the busiest day we've had in three years.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: "Saturdays are booked out three weeks ahead. When that starts happening, you know the market is heading in the right direction."

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Like many people in their twenties, Jacob Derrick is still living with his mum and dad in Midsomer Norton. At 24, he is working in IT and earns a good salary.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: "There's been no way I could afford to buy a place," he says, remembering the last four years.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Now, as interest rates start to come down, he is hopeful he might just crack the housing market.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: "I've noticed a massive increase in people selling, so there's certainly a lot more to choose from."

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Mr Derrick is realistic about his chances on his own. He wants to move to Bristol, where he works and has most of his social life. But he knows finding a flat in the city will be tough on a single salary.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: A typical two-bedroom flat was recently found to cost £280,000 in the city, far out of reach of most people on typical incomes.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: But with mortgages starting to come down, Mr Derrick is hopeful.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: "It will be tough," he tells me, "but not impossible."

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Across the West, house prices fell throughout 2023, but recently started to tick up again, according to the Nationwide Building Society which track prices.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: The Bank of England cut its base rate by 0.25% earlier in August, but the governor warned markets not to expect "a flurry" of further reductions.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Despite that, competition in the mortgage market has increased, as lenders try to win new business. Seven of the ten top lenders now have a headline rate around 4%, albeit for a large deposit and a five-year fixed term.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: That means banks are betting on interest rates falling further over the next few years.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: In Frome, estate agent Will Parfitt has seen the impact of these lower rates.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: He said: "We've already seen a lot more first-time buyers coming back into the market, and people upsizing.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: "These are all driven by lower interest rates, and the confidence that they will stay that way."

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: He shows me an old school house, now converted into flats. A two-bed flat is on the market for £200,000.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: "That will sell soon," he tells me.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News
text: Nobody thinks the days of fixed rate mortgages at 2% are coming back. But after the difficult two years experienced by people trying to buy a house, and those who work in the housing market, a few years of stable lower rates will be welcome.

title: Somerset housing market 'busiest it's been for years' - BBC News

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Xbox owner Microsoft is to cut about 650 staff from its gaming division in a new round of job losses after its $69bn (£54.3bn) merger deal.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: The software giant said staff working in "mostly corporate and supporting functions" worldwide would be affected.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: It laid off 1,900 staff in January and, in May, closed four studios bought before its purchase of Call of Duty maker Activision-Blizzard.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: In a memo to workers shared online and verified by the BBC, Xbox boss Phil Spencer said "no games, devices or experiences are being cancelled and no studios are being closed" due to the latest layoffs.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Microsoft's purchase of Activision-Blizzard in October also included Candy Crush maker King and followed its buyout of Zenimax, which owns Fallout maker Bethesda.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Mr Spencer told staff Microsoft had tried to "minimise disruption" as it brought in new teams in the months since the multibillion-dollar acquisition.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: He said the decision to cut more jobs - about 3% of its gaming staff - was made "as part of aligning our post-acquisition team structure" and organising the business "for long-term success".

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Although he said games and studios would not be affected he said there would be "some impacts to other teams as they adapt to shifting priorities and manage the lifecycle and performance of games".

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Mr Spencer acknowledged the news would be "difficult" for workers and thanked those affected for their contributions to the company.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: The games industry has been hit by mass layoffs over the past two years following a rush of investments and acquisitions amid record profits and player numbers during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: PlayStation maker Sony, League of Legends creator Riot Games and Fortnite owner Epic have been among those to lay off hundreds of workers.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Microsoft received particular criticism over the closures of critically acclaimed studios Arkane Austin and Tango Gameworks earlier this year.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Xbox boss Mr Spencer told gaming website IGN, external he was expected to run a "sustainable" gaming business and show growth during a June interview.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: And speaking during an official Xbox stream at Gamescom, external last month, he said the was "a high bar" inside Microsoft for the company's gaming division.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: In its latest finance report, external Microsoft said its gaming revenues had increased, mostly due to its ownership of Activision-Blizzard, which also produces World of Warcraft, Diablo and Overwatch.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Sales of Xbox hardware have fallen since last year though, and the company has been trying to expand its software sales.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Xbox showed off a string of upcoming games from its studios in June, including Call of Duty: Black Ops 6.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: The showcase was praised as one of its best in years, but the company has also upset fans by raising the prices of its Netflix-style Game Pass service and by announcing plans to release certain games on rival consoles.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle - one of the biggest Xbox releases this year - is set to be released on PlayStation 5, although the movie hero's adventure will come to Sony's machine months after Xbox.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: That followed an earlier announcement that four previously exclusive games were coming to the PS5 and Nintendo Switch.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News
text: Microsoft has been contacted for comment on the latest announcement.

title: Microsoft lays off more gaming staff in new cuts - BBC News

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The Labour government laid out its plans for renationalising the railways in July.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: What will this mean for passengers, and how will it work?

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The government has not guaranteed lower fares, but has promised a "best fare guarantee", to make sure people are always paying the lowest fare for their journey.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: It has also promised its reforms would make buying cheaper tickets simpler.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Labour pledges to renationalise most rail services within five years

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: However, railway specialist Tony Miles - who has covered the industry for more than 40 years -  told the BBC when the plans were first announced that any savings were likely to be minimal.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: He said this is because the private operators' profit margins are already so small, at just a few pence for each passenger journey.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: He argued this would mean Labour would only be able to pass on very small savings per journey.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: From just after the Second World War until the 1990s the UK rail system was fully nationalised, with the government owning the rail networks and all of the trains.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The industry was privatised in the 1990s, with services run by a variety of train operating companies.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: At the moment, the infrastructure is managed by publicly-owned Network Rail, while passenger train services are run by individual operators, which are both privately and publicly-owned.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The situation is different in Scotland and Wales, where passenger services are run by the devolved governments. In Northern Ireland, the system is fully nationalised.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Labour is bringing in a new law to make nationalising passenger operators in England the default option, rather than the last resort for companies that have been struggling.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: It will also establish Great British Railways (GBR) to run both the network tracks and trains. This will not happen for at least a year, but there are transition plans in place.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The publicly-owned body will oversee the rail system across England, Wales, and Scotland, and it will be created with a separate law.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Once up and running, it will take over the contracts currently held by private firms in England as they expire in the future.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: However, GBR will not buy back "rolling stock" (an industry term for the train carriages) from private firms, but will continue to lease them.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Rail freight companies will not be nationalised, with the government instead saying that GBR will support and promote freight operators.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The government also plans to set up an independent watchdog, the Passenger Standards Authority, which would "champion improvement in service against a range of measures".

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Whether this will make the trains run better "comes down to how they’re going to fund things" and whether it will allow major construction projects to move forward, says Mark Simmons, deputy editor at International Railway Journal.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: If the new law gets through Parliament quickly, the first new nationalisations could be early next year.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The first operator contracts to be nationalised could be Greater Anglia and West Midlands, whose core terms - the equivalent to a break clause - are up on 15 September. For this to happen three months’ notice is required.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: The next contracts to be taken over would be Chiltern and Govia Thameslink Railway, which operates Thameslink, Southern (and Gatwick Express) and Great Northern, in April 2025.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: All railway operators' contracts or core terms will expire by October 2027.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Soon after the general election, Transport Secretary Louise Haigh met the managing director of Avanti West Coast and a representative of infrastructure manager Network Rail, to urge improvements.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Before the election, she had promised to look into removing Avanti’s contract before 2026.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: However, company bosses are understood to be confident the terms of the contract have not been breached. That means any attempt to remove it could be met with legal action.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Another troubled privately-run operator, CrossCountry, is currently running a reduced timetable because of a backlog of driver training.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Ms Haigh said CrossCountry had warned it would breach its contractual targets for cancellations, and she had reluctantly accepted the temporary service cuts to give passengers more certainty.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Transpennine Express’ contract was stripped in May 2023 after it struggled to run a full timetable amid a shortage of available drivers.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Luxembourg operates a fully state-run system where all train journeys are free, and train tickets in other European countries with more state control than the UK can be much cheaper.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: However, those networks also receive lots of government investment, which can mean higher taxes.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Mr Simmons said trains in the UK are "not as bad as people think".

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: "Sometimes the perception is that everywhere else is better, and that’s very much not true.”

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: However, he said other countries were “powering ahead” with long-term planning for major projects.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: If Labour waits until the current franchise contracts run out and takes them on itself, as the previous government did during Covid, this would not necessarily cost the taxpayer anything.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: However, doing so would also mean taking on the railway operators debts, leases, and liabilities, such as their pension fund pots and the lease contracts for the rolling stock.

title: Train tickets: Will Labour's Great British Railways plan make them cheaper? - BBC News
text: Labour says its plans would save the taxpayer £2.2bn a year, but the government has not guaranteed that all this money would be reinvested in the railways.
