title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: The Body Shop has been rescued from administration, in a deal that appears to secure the immediate future for 1,300 shop and office workers.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: A consortium led by the British cosmetics tycoon Mike Jatania has acquired the ethical beauty brand's 113 UK stores which remain trading, for an undisclosed sum.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: The specialist investment firm Auréa Group will also gain control of the Body Shop's assets in Australia and North America, in a deal which was finalised late on Friday.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: Mr Jatania described the Body Shop as "a truly iconic brand" popular in over 70 markets around the world.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: "We plan to focus relentlessly on exceeding their expectations by investing in product innovation and seamless experiences across all of the channels where customers shop," he said.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: Announcing the deal, Auréa Group said it has "no immediate plans" to shut stores but that it would monitor the footprint of the estate over the coming months as it tries to manage costs.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: The Body Shop was founded in Brighton in 1976 by the late environmental and human rights campaigner Dame Anita Roddick.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: What began as a single shop in the seaside town quickly grew into a global brand known for its beauty offer, perfumes and ethical stance against animal testing.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: Dame Anita and her husband Gordon sold the business to French beauty giant L'Oreal in 2006. Since then it has changed hands twice, including for as much as a reported one billion euros, amid fierce competition from other natural beauty brands like Lush and Rituals.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: The private equity firm Aurelius paid £207m for The Body Shop in late 2023, but in February this year admitted it could not revive its fortunes and placed the UK arm into administration. It owed more than £276m to creditors at the time.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: FRP Advisory has since closed 85 stores, while almost 500 shop jobs and at least 270 office roles have been axed.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: There were more than 75 expressions of interest to take over the ailing chain, reportedly including Next and Marks and Spencer, but after months of negotiations, Auréa announced that it had finally closed the deal.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: With 35 years of experience in the industry, Mike Jatania will serve as Executive Chairman, it said. The former Chief Executive of Molton Brown, Charles Denton, will take over the helm as CEO.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: "I am truly excited to lead this brand which I have admired for many years," Mr Denton said.

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: He added that "bold action" would be required to achieve a "sustainable future".

title: The Body Shop rescued from administration by Auréa Group - BBC News
text: Steve Baluchi, Director at FRP Advisory, said the company's "experienced new owners" had a track record of successful retail turnarounds and that they recognised the brand's value.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The Gruffalo's Child will appear on a new commemorative 50p coin to mark 20 years since the story was first published.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The character will follow in the footsteps of her father, the Gruffalo, who appeared on 50p coins in 2019.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The new coins will not enter general circulation but will be available to buy from The Royal Mint in precious metal finishes, starting at £12.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The book's illustrator Axel Scheffler said he was "honoured" that the Gruffalo's offspring was being celebrated, while author Julia Donaldson said it was "wonderful".

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The new coins will pair the Gruffalo's Child with the "mouse in the woods" from the story, and some will have colour in the design.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The cheapest one costs £12 while a gold one will set you back £99, although past Gruffalo coins have sold for much higher prices on resale sites due to their rarity.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The Gruffalo book series has sold more than 18 million copies worldwide, and has been translated into more than 100 languages.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The books have earned several awards since their release, with an animated version of The Gruffalo's Child first airing on BBC One in 2011 on Christmas Day.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: “The heart-warming tale of The Gruffalo’s Child has captivated readers since its release 20 years ago, and this year, the curious little monster finds a permanent home on a 50 pence piece," said Rebecca Morgan, The Royal Mint's director of commemorative coin.

title: The Gruffalo's Child to go on commemorative Royal Mint 50p coin - BBC News
text: The Royal Mint, which is one of Britain’s oldest companies and the original maker of UK coins, has previously featured hugely popular children's characters on its coins, including Paddington, The Snowman, and Beatrix Potter favourites.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Train drivers at London North Eastern Railway (LNER) are set to strike every weekend in September, October and two in November, union bosses have announced.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Aslef, which represents train drivers, said the walkouts at LNER were due to a breakdown in industrial relations and agreements.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: The fresh strikes are separate to an ongoing pay dispute with all train companies, which edged closer to being resolved in England this week after a new pay offer.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Separately, Border Force officers at Heathrow Airport have announced more industrial action in a row over changes to terms and conditions.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: The Public and Commercial Services union said 650 Border Force officers will strike from 31 August to 3 September, before they begin a period of working-to-rule and refusing to work overtime until 22 September.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: The union said officers were being told to "choose between caring responsibilities and their job" due to what it called "inflexible rosters".

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Aslef said its member drivers at LNER would walk out every Saturday between 31 August and 9 November and on every Sunday from 1 September to 10 November.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: LNER, which operates services on the East Coast Mainline between London and Edinburgh and is run by the government, said it was "surprised and disappointed" by the announcement following recent talks.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Its trains run to and from London King's Cross station and pass through major cities including Newcastle, York and Durham.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Various railway strikes have led to cancelled services and disruption for passengers for more than two years.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: The fresh walkouts, which total 22 days, are separate to the long-running row over train driver wages at 16 train companies, which looks set to be resolved in England following a new pay offer made this week.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Mick Whelan, general secretary of Aslef, claimed the union had been "forced" into taking strike action at LNER.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: He accused the train operator of "repeatedly" breaking agreements, acting in "bad faith", and of "boorish behaviour and bullying tactics".

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: LNER said it would continue to work with the union to "find a way to end this long running dispute which only damages the rail industry".

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: "Our priority focus will be on minimising disruption to customers during the forthcoming Aslef strikes, which sadly will continue to cause disruption and delays," a statement added.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: A spokesperson said the company took "any accusations of bullying very seriously, and this is not something tolerated anywhere in the business".

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: The Department for Transport said the strikes were "extremely disappointing for passengers", adding that transport secretary Louise Haigh had called on both Aslef and LNER to "round the table and work in good faith to resolve this dispute and as quickly as possible".

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: But Conservative shadow transport minister Kieran Mullan said following the new pay deal offered, "it should shock nobody that more strikes are on the cards".

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: "All Labour are doing is encouraging the unions into more of this anti-passenger action, putting our rail network at the beck and call of unions, whilst passengers pay the price," he added.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Nigel Roebuck, who has led Aslef's negotiations with LNER, said members had complained about being consistently "badgered for favours" by managers "outside of rostering agreements and being contacted remotely".

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: "The bottom line is that LNER does not employ enough drivers to deliver the services it has promised passengers, and the government, it will run," he suggested.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: The Aslef union says it has more than 21,000 members and represents 96% of all the train drivers in England, Scotland, and Wales, where it is organised.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Its leadership team has recommended members accept the newly-tabled offer for train drivers in England, which includes a backdated 5% pay increase for 2019 to 2022, 4.75% for 2022 to 2024, and 4.5% for 2024 to 2025.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Shadow transport minister Kieran Mullan said: "After a no-strings-attached offer to throw cash at a Labour-backing union, it should shock nobody that more strikes are on the cards.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: "It's a taste of what is to come, a nationalised train service seeing Labour-backing unions staging walkouts despite a bumper pay deal."

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: In another separate dispute, those working for publicly-run Scotrail are currently being balloted for strike action over pay.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: On Friday, it emerged that the RMT union, which had resolved its pay offer with the previous Conservative government, would expect the same terms as those offered to train drivers to be put forward to rail workers, such as guards and signalling staff.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: Mick Lynch told the Times that he expected a "parallel, synchronised offer", adding there could be “problems” if this is not the case.

title: LNER train drivers to stage weekend strikes across three months - BBC News
text: The RMT has confirmed it will enter pay talks next week with the Department for Transport, which will negotiate on behalf of the train operating companies and Network Rail.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Car company Volvo has abandoned its target to produce only fully electric cars by 2030, saying it now expects to be selling some hybrid vehicles by that date.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: The carmaker blamed changing market conditions for its decision to give up a target it had announced only three years ago.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: It comes as the industry faces a slowdown in demand in some major markets for electric vehicles (EVs) and uncertainty due to the imposition of trade tariffs on EVs made in China.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Volvo, which has traditionally flaunted its environmental credentials, joins other major carmakers General Motors and Ford in rowing back on EV ambitions.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Volvo now expects at least 90% of its output to be made up of both electric cars and plug-in hybrids by 2030.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: The Swedish company may also sell a small number of so-called mild hybrids, which are more conventional vehicles with limited electrical assistance.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: "We are resolute in our belief that our future is electric," said Jim Rowan, chief executive of Volvo.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: "However, it is clear that the transition to electrification will not be linear, and customers and markets are moving at different speeds."

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: The company also said the business climate for EVs had changed, due to factors such as a slow rollout of charging infrastructure and the withdrawal of consumer incentives.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Independent equity analyst Anna McDonald said consumers still had concerns about switching to EVs.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: “Some of the subsidies that governments had put in place to encourage electric car purchases have ended and also there’s just that ongoing lack of demand because consumers are worried about charging," she told the BBC's Today programme.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: “It still remains the case that electric cars remain more expensive.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: "While the EU and the US are putting tariffs on Chinese cars that are imported to stop them kind of swamping the market, that just means that vehicles have to be made outside China which is more expensive in themselves.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: "Car manufacturers are not keen to start making a loss on these vehicles," Ms McDonald added.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Registrations of EVs across the European Union dropped by nearly 11% in July, according to the European Automobile Manufacturers Association.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Volvo is majority-owned by Chinese car giant Geely and because it uses factories in China, it will also be affected by tariffs on imports of Chinese-made EVs in Europe and North America.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Last week, Canada announced it was imposing a 100% tariff on imports of China-made electric vehicles, after similar announcements by the US and the EU.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Western countries have accused China of subsidising its EV industry, giving its car makers an unfair advantage.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: China has rejected those allegations and criticised the tariffs as "discriminatory".

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Ford has also been scaling back on its EV ambitions. Just last month, the US car giant announced it was scrapping plans for a large, three-row, all-electric sport utility vehicles (SUVs) and postponing the launch of its next electric pick-up truck.

title: Volvo gives up plan to sell only EVs by 2030 - BBC News
text: Its rival General Motors has also been cutting EV production goals in the last year.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: The newly-announced boss of Starbucks, Brian Niccol, has come under fire after it was revealed he will commute almost 1,000 miles (1,600km) from his family home in Newport Beach, California, to the firm's headquarters in Seattle on a corporate jet.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Critics have noted what they see as a discrepancy between the company's public stance on green issues and the lifestyles of its top executives.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Mr Niccol is due to take up the role at the helm of the world's biggest coffee shop chain on 9 September.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: A Starbucks spokesperson told the BBC Mr Niccol will have a primary office in Seattle where he will spend most of his time when he is not "visiting partners and customers" around the world.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Mr Niccol's job offer, external did say he would "not be required to relocate to the company’s headquarters", but added: "You agree to commute from your residence to the company’s headquarters... as is required to perform your duties and responsibilities".

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: The document states that he will be eligible to use the company's aircraft for "business related travel" and for "travel between [his] city of residence and the company's headquarters".

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Starbucks also said it will set up a small remote office in Newport Beach for Mr Niccol to use when working from California.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Starbucks has a hybrid work policy, external that means employees have to be in the office at least three days a week.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: “Brian’s schedule will exceed the hybrid work guidelines and workplace expectations we have for all partners," a Starbucks spokesperson said.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: The coffee shop chain added that Mr Niccol will buy a home in Seattle and was not expected to travel back and forth daily.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Dan Coatsworth, an investment analyst at AJ Bell, told the BBC Mr Niccol "on paper" was being given the "same hybrid working terms as other office-based employees, as one might expect".

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: "However, what leaves a sour taste is the idea he can use a private jet to nip 1,000 miles between California and Seattle," he added.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Mr Coatsworth said while using a private jet was not only bad for the environment and would send a bad message to customers and staff, it was also "ultimately not a practical way to run a $105bn business with an estimated 400,000 employees".

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: "A leader needs to be at the heart of a business, not sitting on the beach enjoying the perks of the job," he said.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: "The fact Brian Niccol was drafted in to give a new lease of life to Starbucks implies he has a big challenge ahead. This isn’t taking the reins of a business firing on all cylinders; it’s a repair job which means being in the engine room at all times."

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: The topic of where people work from has been debated in recent years, with companies in many industries wrestling with whether to allow the remote work practices that exploded during the coronavirus pandemic to continue.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Andrew Speke, a spokesperson for High Pay Centre, a think tank which tracks executives' pay, said it was important for business leaders that "employees can see that it’s not one rule for them and one rule for their bosses".

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: The terms of his employment also sparked a backlash on social media.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: "That's nice... good convenience for top talent! But hope we don't see too many new 'sustainability' and 'environment' related ads from @starbucks? *Wink*," said one X user., external

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: "The new Starbucks CEO is 'supercommuting' 1,000 miles to Seattle on a private jet to work, so don’t be too harsh on that waitress who gave you a plastic straw when you didn’t want one," said another, external.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Some sectors, such as banking, signalled early on that they would expect staff to return to the office full-time, while others, often in the tech industry, have said they will allow remote work indefinitely. Many places have opted for a mix.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Others focused on how much Mr Niccol is set to get paid in his new job.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: "How come we never talk about CEO pay when we talk about rising prices?" former US Secretary of Labor Robert Reich posted, external.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: According to the terms of his offer, Mr Niccol's annual base pay will be $1.6m (£1.2m). On top of that he could get a performance-related bonus of as much as $7.2m and up to $23m a year of Starbucks shares.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Starbucks defended the plan, saying that Mr Niccol was "one of the most effective leaders in our industry" and that his compensation was "tied directly to the company’s performance and the shared success of all our stakeholders".

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: A report published by the United Nations in 2021 showed that the world's wealthiest 1% of people produced double the combined carbon emissions of the poorest 50%.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Starbucks announced this month that Mr Niccol would be replacing Laxman Narasimhan as its chief executive.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: The announcement came as the coffee chain looks to boost flagging sales.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Mr Niccol had led the Mexican fast food chain Chipotle since 2018, helping it to recover from a crisis after outbreaks of food poisoning.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: During his time in the role the firm's sales doubled and its shares surged from less than $7 each to more than $50.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: Chipotle also opened almost 1,000 new stores and new technologies were introduced to automate food preparation.

title: Starbucks new boss under fire for 1,000-mile commute - BBC News
text: In recent months, it has been seen as a bright spot in the restaurant industry, where many businesses have reported that customers are cutting spending.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Ford is shaking up its strategy for electric vehicles (EVs), scrapping plans for a large, three-row, all-electric SUV and postponing the launch of its next electric pickup truck.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Chief financial officer John Lawler said the firm was adjusting its plans in response to "pricing and margin compression".

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: The move comes as growth in demand for electric cars has faltered, leading to price wars and other pressures.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Ford said the new timetable would allow it to take advantage of technological advances in batteries and other areas that are expected to lower costs and expand how far the cars can go without charging.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Overall, the Michigan carmaker said changes would reduce the share of annual capital expenditures dedicated to "pure" electric vehicles from 40% to 30%.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: They are expected to cost about $1.9bn (£1.5bn) in write-downs and new spending.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Chief executive Jim Farley said the firm had "learned a lot" from its efforts and had built a new plan that would give customers choice and "play to our strengths".

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Just a few years ago, Ford outlined plans for an aggressive push to electric vehicles, with hopes to produce some two million a year by 2026.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: It launched an electric version of its best-selling F-150 pickup truck in 2022 to great fanfare.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: But Ford, like others in the industry including rival General Motors, had already said it would scale back its investments and ambitions, spooked by signs of weaker than expected consumer demand and preference for hybrids, which use a combination of fossil fuels and battery power.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Though sales of electric cars in the US have picked up again in recent months,  competition has kept pressure on carmakers.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Ford reported last month it had sold more than 50,000 electric cars since the start of the year, up more than 60%.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: But its electric business also lost nearly $2.5bn.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Ford said it was moving some battery production to the US from Poland, as part of its strategy to lower costs. The move will allow the firm to access government incentives from the Inflation Reduction Act.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: "An affordable electric vehicle starts with an affordable battery,” Mr Farley said. “If you are not competitive on battery cost, you are not competitive."

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Ford had initially expected to begin production of its next electric pickup truck next year at a new factory in Tennessee. That launch has been postponed until 2027, it said.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: Ford will also offer a hybrid version of its large, three-row SUV, instead of an all electric, battery-powered model as planned.

title: Ford scales back EV plans citing price pressures - BBC News
text: It said it was focusing its all-electric efforts on a van for business customers, with assembly starting in Ohio in 2026.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: A new retail hub opens today in Sheffield as a key part of the city centre redevelopment plans.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: Grade II listed Leah’s Yard on Cambridge Street will offer a contemporary hub for a range of independent businesses.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: The opening of hub is seen as the final piece of the jigsaw for Heart of the City project, Sheffield City Council said.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: Ben Miskell, chair of the council's transport, regeneration and climate policy committee, said the area had once played a "vital role" in the city's industrial past and would once again be able to "contribute to Sheffield's future".

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: The regeneration of the former industrial workshops saw it removed from Historic England's Buildings at Risk register last year.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: The council said it was the "jewel in the crown" of the Heart of the City scheme, which is led by the city council and their strategic development partner, Queensbury.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: The ground floor of Leah’s Yard incorporates a range of retail and food and drink businesses, including a book shop, a florist, a market farm shop and a craft chocolate café and bar.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: Meanwhile, the upper floors of Leah’s Yard provide a home to a network of businesses including a barber and a group of creative companies and freelancers.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: Mr Miskell added: “Having brought this part of the city back to life through our outstanding Heart of the City programme, Leah’s Yard represents the icing on the cake alongside Pound’s Park, Cambridge Street Collective and Elshaw House.”

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: Sheffield artist, Pete McKee, also revealed his highly anticipated new gallery on the Cambridge Street side of the development.

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News
text: Mr McKee said previously: “I wanted to move to the city centre to help be a part of our beautiful city’s new beginning."

title: Sheffield: New independent retail hub opens its doors - BBC News

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: OpenAI and global magazine giant Condé Nast have announced a partnership to allow ChatGPT and its search engine SearchGPT to display content from Vogue, The New Yorker, GQ and other well known publications.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: The multi-year deal is the latest such agreement struck by OpenAI with major media firms.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: The content produced by media organisations is sought after by technology companies that use it to train their AI (Artificial Intelligence) models.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: Some media firms including the New York Times and the Chicago Tribune have resisted this and taken legal action to protect their content.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: OpenAI and Condé Nast did not disclose the financial terms of the agreement.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: “We’re committed to working with Condé Nast and other news publishers to ensure that as AI plays a larger role in news discovery and delivery, it maintains accuracy, integrity, and respect for quality reporting,” said Brad Lightcap, OpenAI's chief operating officer.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: News media organisations have seen their business models challenged by the rise of social media and other digital platforms.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: "Our partnership with OpenAI begins to make up for some of that revenue, allowing us to continue to protect and invest in our journalism and creative endeavours," said Condé Nast's chief executive officer Roger Lynch.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: OpenAI launched its prototype AI-powered search engine, SearchGPT, last month.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: In a statement at the time, the company said it was gathering feedback and insights from its partners in the news industry to develop the new platform.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: Others that have partnered with the AI firm include Time Magazine, the Financial Times and the Associated Press.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: AI chatbot technology is seen by many analysts as a key part of internet search engines in the future.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: Search engine giant Google has also been racing to add AI-powered tools to its products.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: While other AI companies are pursuing search products, Google remains by far the dominant player, claiming more than 90% of the global market.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: The changes to how search engines respond to queries - offering conversational paragraphs instead of directing users to links - have also raised alarm among news media firms, many of which rely on search traffic for audiences and revenue.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: Last year, the BBC said it was taking steps to prevent content on its websites from being used by OpenAI and other firms without permission.

title: Artificial Intelligence: Vogue publisher and OpenAI strike deal - BBC News
text: The blog post also said the BBC would explore opportunities offered by generative AI "to deliver more value to our audiences and to society."

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: The government is to provide £10.5m worth of funding to prepare for new EU border checks this autumn.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: The Port of Dover, Eurotunnel at Folkestone and Eurostar at St Pancras will receive financial aid to help reduce queues for travellers.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: From the autumn, travellers from the UK and other non-EU countries will have to go through a new digital border system called the Entry/Exit System (EES), which is being brought in by the EU.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: This will involve having your photograph and fingerprints taken.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: The government money will be spent on providing ports with the necessary technology to complete these checks.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: The scheme applies to British people and other non-EU nationals entering a European country using the EES for a short stay.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: They will need to register fingerprints and a photo with their passport details to proceed with travel.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: Every time those travellers enter or exit a participating European country, this will be recorded. Once they have given their fingerprints and details, that registration will be valid for three years.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: During that time it must be validated every time someone crosses the border. This will replace passport-stamping.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: In most cases the EES checks will happen when you arrive at an international airport but if you're travelling via the Port of Dover or an international train then the checks will take place in the UK.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: The technology that ports will use to take biometric data of travellers has not yet been confirmed.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: It was previously suggested that a gadget similar to an iPad could be used to take fingerprints.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: The EES was originally meant to begin in 2022 but it has faced many setbacks.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: It had previously been rescheduled for May 2023, then the end of 2023, and now is expected to come into force in November 2024.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: Lilian Greenwood, Future of Roads Minister, said the government had been reviewing the EES plans to ensure "registration can be smooth and queue times kept to a minimum".

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: "Nobody wants to see excessive queues at our ports, which is why we’re providing this funding to ensure our borders are as prepared as possible for the upcoming change – despite EES being an EU initiative," she added.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: Eurostar chief safety and stations officer Simon Lejeune said the government had supported an upgrade of its technology and facilities to meet the requirements.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: “Eurostar will be fully prepared and compliant by November, ensuring a smooth transition for all our passengers," he added.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: Emma Ward, chief operations officer for the Port of Dover, said the port was doing all it could to be "ready with the facilities that will be used by French border officials operating the new system".

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: Each port is set to receive £3.5m of the funding, which is the first of its kind aimed at preventing EES-related delays.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: The government money will be used by Dover to help pay for a marina to be filled in, in order to provide extra space for coach passengers to be processed.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: Eurostar and Eurotunnel will use their share to pay for technology and staff training. Eurotunnel will add more kiosks if needed.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: All three have already invested tens of millions of pounds of their own money on preparing for the new system.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: Getlink, which manages Eurotunnel, started work two years ago to adapt to EES changes.

title: UK government to spend £10.5m on new EU border checks - BBC News
text: "The focus has always been on customer satisfaction, delivering the most competitive crossing time and experience at the border for non-EU travellers," Yann Leriche, chief executive of Getlink, said.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: As he slipped the key card into the reader on his hotel room door and tried the handle - to no avail - he realised what he had done.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: For years, Steven Murdoch, a security researcher at University College London, had taken care not to put tickets or cards with magnetic stripes in his pocket next to his smartphone. This is because the magnets in smartphones are sometimes strong enough to wipe the data on magnetic stripes.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: But so-called magstripe hotel key cards are rare these days, increasingly superseded by contactless cards with radio frequency identification (RFID) chips inside them.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: As such, during his hotel visit in January this year, Prof Murdoch forgot to take precautions and, he concludes, wiped his room key – having used it only once.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: “I should have known better, this is the sort of thing I do know about,” he says. Upon arriving back at reception, he realised he was not alone.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: “There was a queue of people with exactly the same problem as me,” he recalls.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: The magnetic stripe was invented by an IBM engineer, external in the 1960s – his wife was instrumental in the process as it was she who suggested melting a strip of magnetic tape onto a card using a clothes iron.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: In the decades since, magstripes have been used on bank cards, rail tickets, IDs and even cards containing medical information, to set up hospital machines.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: But that murky brown strip of plastic usually made with polluting heavy metals may not be around for much longer.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: From this year onwards, for instance, Mastercard will not require banks to put a magnetic stripe on debit and credit cards.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: For ticketing, new technologies including printable barcodes and reusable contactless cards are considered more environmentally friendly and potentially more convenient.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: You also can’t wipe them by accidentally putting them too close to your iPhone.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: There are, broadly, two kinds of magnetic stripe, called HiCo and LoCo. The latter is cheaper, less durable, and more susceptible to disruption from magnets, says Lee Minter, head of global operations at Nagels, which makes magstripe tickets and other products. Recently, the company investigated reports from a customer who said multiple magstripe tickets they had bought had got corrupted.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Mr Minter says he can’t be 100% sure but he and his colleagues are of the opinion that it was caused by part of a circular magnet within the customer’s iPhone.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: “It matched perfectly to the area which had been wiped,” he says.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: In response, Apple says: "Smartphones and other items contain magnets or components that may have a risk of demagnetizing low coercivity cards. To prevent this from happening, users should keep these cards stored separately."

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: While such disruption remains relatively rare, Mr Minter says that the magnetic stripe is declining in popularity either way. Of the five billion tickets Nagels prints every year, less than one-fifth now have magnetic stripes, he estimates.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Mr Minter is keen to stress the potential of thermally printed paper tickets, much like receipts, which are now being used in trials at multiple rail stations around the UK. These come with a QR code that can be used on ticket barrier scanners. There is a separate code on the back to stop people forging tickets.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Stuart Taylor, head of commercial development at Northern, a train operator, says 70% of his firm’s customers now buy digital tickets and that Northern could axe the familiar orange-trimmed, magstripe-sporting versions in just five years’ time.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: “There is a clear environmental benefit,” says Mr Taylor. “Times change, I guess.”

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Northern is now trialling the thermally printed paper tickets made by Nagels as an alternative. There have been some issues with printer jams and the tickets getting stuck in ticketing machines but these problems have largely been addressed, says Mr Taylor.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: He emphasises that there are no plans to withdraw paper tickets, nor to cut any staff involved in ticket sales.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Are there any benefits to keeping magstripe cards or tokens around?

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: “No,” says Sue Walnut, product director for intelligent transportation systems at Vix Technology, bluntly.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: She argues there are now so many different ways of validating a rail ticket - for example, QR codes presented on phone screens, tickets printed at home, prepaid contactless cards - that there is less need to retain magstripe technology than ever before.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: But magstripe tickets and entry cards do slot conveniently into credit card holders in wallets and purses. The new paper tickets being trialled by Northern and other rail firms are larger. “They are a bit unwieldy and cumbersome,” says Ms Walnut.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Magstripe has hung around for so long partly because it is relatively cheap and the specifications for reading machines were put in place many decades ago, says Stephen Cranfield at Barnes International, which makes equipment for magnetic stripe testing.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: “If you took your card today and used it in a magstripe reader from 1970, it would still be able to read it,” he says.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: His firm has worked on a variety of systems - including one designed to allow kidney failure patients to use a magstripe card for setting up their dialysis machine.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Despite the ubiquity of dark brown or black magstripes, they can actually come in a whole range of colours. “It’s quite popular in China, actually – gold stripes,” explains Mr Cranfield.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: But now that US banks are finally switching to chip and PIN cards, the market for magstripe is clearly dwindling.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Prof Murdoch says although magstripe technology is extremely well established, it is “inevitable” that it will gradually disappear. One downside to that, he suggests, is that magnetic stripe failures and fraud are currently well understood. Newer technologies, while in theory more secure, may also be more complex - and therefore exploitable by criminals using novel methods.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: Sometimes, members of the public contact Prof Murdoch when they are having trouble proving to their bank that they have been the victim of fraud.

title: Is this the end for the magnetic stripe? - BBC News
text: “If the transaction was done by magstripe, then it’s a very easy argument to say someone copied it,” says Prof Murdoch as he points out the irony. “But if the transaction was one of the more secure methods - then it’s much harder.”

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: An expected rise in energy bills coupled with the end of winter fuel payments for most pensioners is "really frightening", a group of older people has said.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: One member of a walking group in Swansea had to return to work in her 70s while another said she had damp in her home after cutting back on heating to save money.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: The energy regulator will announce a new price cap on Friday, which is expected to increase by about 9% from October.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: The UK government said it was "taking difficult decisions to fix the foundations of the economy" and would target winter fuel payments to "those most in need".

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: Retired Royal Mail worker Pauline Anderson, organiser of the Swansea Ageing Well community walking group, said many members were worried about what winter would bring.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: "There are some who are in their 70s and still having to go to work, at 70 you shouldn’t have to be doing that," she said.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: The loss of the winter fuel payment, worth between £100 and £300, as well as an expected increase in bills has led to anxiety.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: From the autumn only those on pension credit, or other means-tested benefits will receive the winter fuel payment.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: But about £117m in pension credit is going unclaimed in Wales this year, according to estimates.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: Margaret, from Port Talbot, travels to Swansea regularly to take part in the group activities.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: She does not receive any benefits and, at 78, said she was "really frightened" about what losing the winter fuel payment would mean.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: "I lost my husband five years ago and I’m on my own and the pension I’m getting is very small," she said.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: Her friend Anne, 62, does not qualify for the state pension yet, but said everyone had been trying to cut back their energy usage last winter.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: "We cut back on the thermostat so much that we ended up with damp in the house, so then we had to increase from 14C to 15C to see if that would be any better," she said.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: People are generally advised to heat their home to 18C in winter and Public Health Wales has said 30% of excess winter deaths were due to cold homes, external.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: Ofgem, the energy regulator, imposes a price cap on the amount suppliers can charge households for each unit of energy and standing charges.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: The price cap has fallen recently and is £1,568 per year for a typical household using electricity and gas and paying by direct debit.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: But it remains about £350 - or 29% - higher now than it was in summer 2021, external.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: But some of the Swansea walkers support the UK government’s decision to restrict winter fuel payments.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: Christine, 78, and her friend Beryl said they should only go to those who need them.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: "Millionaires get the winter fuel payment," said Beryl.

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: "I agree with it being means tested but whether the means tested side of it is fair, I don’t know."

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: The UK government said it was "committed to pensioners" by "protecting" the triple lock pension and "keeping energy bills low".

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: It said it would “work with local authorities to boost the uptake of pension credit, reaching the many pensioners who could still benefit from this year’s winter fuel payments".

title: Energy bill cost rise frightening, Swansea pensioners say - BBC News
text: You can check whether you are getting all the benefits you are entitled to by calling the free and confidential helpline 'claim what's yours, external' on 0808 250 5700.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Inflation in the US continued to cool last month, official figures showed, raising confidence that the US central bank will cut interest rates next week.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Consumer prices rose 2.5% over the 12 months to August, as prices for petrol, used cars and trucks, and some other items fell.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: That marked the slowest pace since February 2021 and was down from 2.9% in July, despite an unexpected rise in housing costs.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: The Labor Department figures come during a presidential campaign in which rising living costs have been a key issue.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Analysts said the data increased the likelihood that the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates by 0.25 percentage points at its meeting next week, but reduced the odds of bigger cut.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: "Overall, inflation appears to have been successfully tamed but, with housing inflation still refusing to moderate as quickly as hoped, it hasn’t been completely vanquished," said Paul Ashworth, chief North America economist for Capital Economics.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: The data shows price pressure is fading for key household items.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Grocery prices, which were surging just a few years ago, were unchanged from July to August and are up less than 1% from a year ago, according to the report.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: The cost of petrol, another staple, has also dropped, falling over the month and more than 10% from August 2023.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: However, prices for other items continued to climb.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Not including food and energy - which tend to fluctuate and can obscure underlying trends - prices were up 3.2% over the year, as airline tickets, car insurance, rent, and other housing costs grew more expensive.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: "This serves as a bit of a reminder not to get too carried away with a few months of better inflation data," said Brian Coulton, Fitch Rating's chief economist.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: "Certainly not enough to stop the Fed cutting rates later this month, but the stickiness of services inflation... will be one reason why the Fed will not be cutting rates at an aggressive pace over the next year or so."

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Central banks, including the Fed, started upping borrowing costs two years ago in an attempt to slow inflation.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Prices began to rise globally in 2021 because of pandemic-related supply issues and a jump in government spending.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Russia's invasion of Ukraine in 2022 then caused oil prices to surge, further fuelling global inflation.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: US inflation hit a high of 9.1% in June 2022, but has since fallen closer to the 2% rate considered healthy.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Jasmine Loeber, a stay-at-home mother from Pennsylvania, was so shocked by price increases in recent years that she began posting on social media about her expensive supermarket hauls.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: But the 26-year-old told the BBC that prices have recently started to become more affordable.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: She is still shopping strategically - avoiding certain brands and sticking with stores known for being budget friendly - but is now seeing more discounts.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: "I've noticed, over the last few months, they've got red tags on everything," she said, adding that her family recently took its first holiday in three years.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: But she said wider financial pressures, like housing costs, still weighed so heavily that she did not plan to have more than one child.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: The latest figures went largely unremarked in the aftermath of the first debate and as political leaders marked the anniversary of the 11 September attacks on New York's world trade center.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: Jasmine, who lives in a state both campaigns see as must-win in November, said she did not vote in 2020 and was unsure whether she would this year.

title: US inflation falls to its lowest level in over three years - BBC News
text: "It's really hard to be believe that they're actually going to be able to do anything about it," she said.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: A man who lent thousands of pounds to people illegally has been ordered to pay back £6,000.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: Richard Darcy, 60, of Crescent Towers, Leeds, admitted illegal money lending between 2017 and 2023, but said he only did so to those who were "desperate and in need of essentials".

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: He was investigated by the England Illegal Money Lending Team (IMLT) along with West Yorkshire Trading Standards and West Yorkshire Police.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: Darcy appeared at Leeds Crown Court on Thursday where he was told to repay the money within three months or face a jail sentence.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: Simon Mortimer, prosecuting on behalf of the IMLT, said Darcy never had authority to lend money from the Financial Conduct Authority (FSA) and was therefore acting illegally.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: He said IMLT and police officers searched his home in November last year after someone reported his money lending.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: Financial investigations showed he had three income streams - selling furniture, a part time job and income from the lending of money.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: He was found to have issued loans in the region of around £8,000.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: Darcy said he had researched the FSA website and was aware that he required authorisation to continue lending money legally, but as it was not an easy process, he chose to ignore the guidelines.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: Judge Tom Bayliss KC said the lending was a means of making money.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: He said: "You’re not a vicious loan shark but you were illegally lending which is exploitative, lending to people who likely couldn’t get money elsewhere."

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
text: He fined Darcy £6,000 with an order that it must be paid within three months, or he could face a prison sentence.

title: Leeds man fined £6,000 over illegal money lending - BBC News
