title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: The US government is taking aim at the engine of Google's immense wealth - its extremely lucrative ad tech business.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: A trial beginning on Monday will hear the Department of Justice's case that the search engine's parent company Alphabet illegally operates a monopoly in the market.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: The company earned more than $200 billion, external (£152bn) last year through the placing and selling of ads seen by internet users.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: Alphabet has argued its success is due to the "effectiveness" of its services - but prosecutors say it has used its market dominance to stifle rivals.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: “It is a really important industry that grabs billions of consumer dollars every year,” said Laura Phillips-Sawyer, a professor at the University of Georgia School of Law.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: “I think all consumers have an interest in this litigation."

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: It is the second major antitrust case the tech giant has faced in the US.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: In August a judge ruled its dominance of search was illegal, with the penalties Google and Alphabet will face as a result of that decision so far unclear.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: According to the lawsuit filed by the Department of Justice (DoJ) and a coalition of states in 2023, Google dominates the digital ad marketplace and has leveraged its market power to stifle innovation and competition.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: Google meanwhile contends it is just one of several hundred companies that facilitate the placement of digital ads in front of consumers.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: It argues that competition in the digital ad space is growing, not contracting - citing increased ad growth and revenues for companies such as Apple, Amazon and TikTok as proof in a blog post responding to the DoJ's lawsuit, external in 2023.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: Both sides will present their cases to US District Judge Leonie Brinkema, who is expected to deliver a verdict.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: The bench trial comes on the heels of a landmark decision last month in a different monopoly case brought by the Justice Department against Google.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: Judge Amit Mehta ruled that Google acted illegally to squelch competition in its online search business.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: “Google is a monopolist, and it has acted as one to maintain its monopoly,” he wrote.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: During last year's trial, Google said it dominated online search because it had a better product.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: And the company is seemingly deploying a similar defence in the ad tech case.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: When asked for a statement, it referred the BBC to its 2023 blog post, in which it states that “no-one is forced to use our advertising technologies – they choose to use them because they’re effective."

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: Judge Mehta held a status conference on Friday as he begins the process of deciding on remedies for Google’s conduct.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: “The DoJ clearly had a big win, and they’re going to ride that momentum,” Dan Ives, managing director at Wedbush Securities, told the BBC.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: He said he expects those remedies to involve "business model tweaks, not a breakup" of the company.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: Meanwhile, in Justice Brinkema’s courtroom, the arcane process that governs advertising technology could make the DoJ's attempts to prove its case an uphill climb.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: “We all use search. We all intuitively understand that product,” said Rebecca Haw Allensworth, an antitrust professor at Vanderbilt University Law School.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: By comparison, advertising technology is “so complex that I think that’s going to be a real challenge for the government to make a clear, simple monopolisation argument here.”

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: The US is not the only country where regulators are unhappy with Google's ad tech business.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: On Friday, the UK Competition and Markets Authority said it believed Google was abusing its dominance in the ad tech industry, according to the findings of its initial investigation.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: It said it found that Google used anti-competitive practices to dominate the market for online advertising technology - and the potentially unlawful behaviour could be harming thousands of UK publishers and advertisers.

title: Google's lucrative ad tech business goes on trial - BBC News
text: A Google representative said the decision was based on a "flawed" understanding of the ad tech sector.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “Why did the politician bring a ladder to the debate? To make sure he could reach new heights with his promises!”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Ask AI to write a political joke, and the above is an example of what you can get.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Perhaps not funny enough to deliver on stage in front of a paying audience, but that doesn’t mean there is no room for AI in comedy.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Comedians are increasingly experimenting with the technology to write scripts and brainstorm ideas, including Anesti Danelis. Earlier this year, the Canadian asked popular AI chatbot ChatGPT to write him a show.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: The result is what he has been performing throughout this summer, including at this month’s Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: The BBC sat down with Anesti after his sixth performance in seven days at the Toronto Fringe Theatre Festival in July. He explained the writing process behind his show “Artificially Intelligent”.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “I was playing around with ChatGPT, and the results it gave me were terribly hilarious, and I thought ‘maybe there's a show in this?’.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Despite some rubbish jokes, he says the tool was useful for brainstorming.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “I asked it to ‘write me five songs about bisexual dilemmas’, or ‘being an immigrant child’, and it gave me ideas that I would have never thought of.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: What he wasn’t expecting from AI was its understanding of how to devise a show.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “I told it to make me a running order, and it explained where every song should go and why, and it made total sense. I was surprised by how much it could explain the reasoning behind it.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Despite using the technology to write chunks of the script, Anesti’s show very much relies on his delivery. Throughout the performance the comedian switches from a keyboard to a guitar to deliver songs and monologues. There’s lots of interaction, including a serenading of an audience member, with a song written about them by ChatGPT.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Reflecting on the experience, Anesti says: "I learned through the process that human creativity can't be replicated or replaced, and in the end about 20% of the show was pure AI, and the other 80% was a mix.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: So far, he says, he has only had good feedback from audience members, including Olivia Smith and Bethany Radford, who both live in Toronto.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Olivia admits she’s sceptical of AI, but enjoyed seeing it played with creatively.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “I think I'd feel a little cheated out of an experience if the entire thing was written by technology, but it was funny seeing AI on stage because it was creative,” she says.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Bethany, who is an actor, agrees, and says: “There is a place for AI in creation and writing so long as it’s transparent that it’s been part of the process.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: A recently released study from the University of Southern California found that AI-generated jokes outperform those crafted by human beings. Bethany, however, is not so sure, and feels “humans are pretty good at sniffing out AI”.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: If she is watching something, she adds: “I feel like I know when the writing had no human involved. But I'm sure that will change as it gets smarter.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Making audiences laugh is big business, and over the past decade the stand-up comedy market in the US has almost tripled, external in terms of the combined value of tickets sold. That is according to data from trade publication Pollstar, which monitors the live performance sector. It says US comedy ticket sales hit $900m (£700m) in 2023, up from $371m in 2012.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Meanwhile, a separate study last month said that live comedy was now worth more than £1bn, external a year to the UK economy. This figure includes not just ticket sales, but also the revenues of comedy venues and festivals, and the positive impact on the wider local economies.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: US comedian Viv Ford is also performing at this month’s Edinburgh Festival Fringe.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Her show is called “No Kids On The Blockchain”, and details her time living with “14 tech-loving crypto [currency] bros in San Francisco”.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Though she wrote the show herself, she explains she tested her material on ChatGPT.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: "I'll say, ‘hey, is this joke funny?’. And if it says ‘it’s funny’, genuinely, it does not land with an audience,” says Viv. “But if it says a joke ‘is offensive’ it does so well.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “And sometimes ChatGPT will say ‘the joke is fine, but could use some work’, in which case I toss it away and start again.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Viv knows that lots of people won’t be so embracing of AI in the arts. It’s a view she used to take until she lived in San Francisco, where so many tech firms are based.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “I'm so aware that the only reason I think this way is because of my four-year indoctrination in the school of San Francisco,” she says. “I realised AI can be your weapon, just like Google can be your weapon. If you know how to use AI correctly, you are unstoppable.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Not everyone in the comedy world is keen to try AI though, including Kiwi-Filipino comedian James Roque. He says it doesn’t fit with his approach to humour.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “My belief and ethos is that the best comedy is the kind that is deeply human and vulnerable, and AI couldn’t do that,” he says.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Mr Roque is also performing at Edinburgh this month, and he thinks audiences will notice if other comedians use AI. “They can sniff out when something isn’t authentic,” he says.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “So if you haven’t created it, I think audiences are smart and emotionally intelligent enough to know something is off in the show.”

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Could AI be the future of comedy? No one can be sure.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: Despite writing the majority of his current show with AI, Anesti Danelis isn’t convinced he would do it again. He also has concerns for the next generation of comedians who might grow to rely on it.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “I think the dangerous thing about AI is that it can be a crutch,” he explains.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: “If you’re an established comedian who knows your voice, AI gives good advice. But when you're a new comedian and you don't have that voice yet, you need to learn without AI.

title: AI and stand up comedy - BBC News
text: "Otherwise, a generation of comedians will be saying the same repetitive, distilled stuff.”

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: UK national debt is on course to treble over the next half a century due to several pressures, according to the government’s official forecaster.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Those pressures include an ageing population, climate change, and rising geopolitical tensions, the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR) said in a report.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: The OBR said without extra tax revenues or a return to post-war productivity levels, the public finances were not sustainable over the long term, and "something has got to give".

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Chief Secretary to the Treasury Darren Jones said: “The OBR has laid bare the shocking state that our public finances were left in by the previous government."

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Jones added that the UK was facing the "highest debt since the 1960s, highest taxes since the 1940s, and debt on track to be almost three times our GDP".

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: The Conservative Party has been contacted for comment.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Debt is the total amount of money owed by the government that has built up over years.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: It rises when there is a deficit - when the government spends more than it receives in income - and falls in those years when there is a surplus - when it spends less than it receives.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: The higher the debt-to-GDP ratio, the less likely a country is to pay back its debt in full.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: UK national debt is currently at almost 100% of GDP.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: The OBR says its base scenario is a national debt of 274% of GDP in 2071, with risks from war, disease, cyber-conflict and trade tensions pushing that even higher.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Over the next 50 years, the government's public spending is projected to rise from 45% to over 60% of GDP.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: However, income generated is predicted to remain at around 40% of GDP.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: By 2071, the OBR projects the equivalent of a more than £200bn per year increase in public spending on health, social care, pensions and related benefits.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Its Fiscal Risks and Sustainability Report claims the previous and current UK government's aspirations to raise defence spending to 2.5% of GDP could add pressure to the public finances.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: In addition, the cost of transitioning to net zero, battling extreme weather linked to climate change, and a falling birth rate could also lead to more spending and less revenue, it said.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: The bill for state pensions and social care is set to rise substantially.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Some of this would be mitigated by lower education and working-age benefit spending.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: The public finances are already under pressure due to "a succession of extraordinary shocks" over the past two decades, the report notes.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: This includes the global financial crisis, the pandemic and the energy crisis.

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: Based on policy settings from March 2024, the analysis warns that public finances will be put on "an unsustainable path".

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: A spokesperson for the Prime Minister said the government is seeking to "restore economic stability".

title: National debt set to treble over next 50 years, says OBR - BBC News
text: "Work has begun to support the economy and businesses, and that's what our focus will be on", she said.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: The rising cost of public services and benefits pushed government borrowing to higher levels than expected in July, official figures show.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Borrowing, the difference between spending and tax income, hit £3.1bn last month, the highest level for July since 2021, the Office for National Statistics (ONS) said.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: The unexpected increase has prompted analysts to speculate over what tax and spending decisions the chancellor will announce at the autumn Budget.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: One economist said Rachel Reeves faced "tough choices", while another added the government would likely raise taxes.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: The chancellor has previously said some taxes will be increased, but has reiterated she would not raise VAT, national insurance or income tax.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Jessica Barnaby, deputy director for public sector finances at the ONS, said the latest public finance figures showed income tax receipts had grown "strongly" and debt interest payments had fallen last month.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: But she added this was more than offset by rises in the cost of public services and inflation-linked benefits increases, leading to higher borrowing.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: While the overall tax take increased by £2.1bn in July, compulsory social contributions fell by £1.1bn last month largely because of the reductions in the rates of National Insurance, which were cut by the previous Conservative government.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: The rise in government borrowing was £1.1bn higher than most economists had expected.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Borrowing is usually lower in July compared to other months because the government has taken a higher number of self-assessed income taxes by that point in the year. This year's July figure was up by £1.8bn on 2023.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Rob Wood, chief UK economist at Pantheon Macroeconomics, said the latest borrowing figures showed public spending was "already overshooting Budget forecasts".

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: "Further revisions could easily change the picture, but Chancellor Rachel Reeves will likely have to raise taxes and borrow more in the medium term to cover spending more on public services," he added.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Isabel Stockton, senior research economist at the Institute for Fiscal Studies, added Ms Reeves faced "tough choices" in her first Budget on 30 October, which is where the government will set out its taxation and spending plans.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: The choices, made by the chancellor, will impact what public money is used to pay for things such as hospitals, schools and the police.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Ms Reeves will also base decisions on meeting the government's own, self-imposed, fiscal rules, which are designed to maintain credibility with financial markets. Most governments in rich countries have such rules.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Darren Jones, chief secretary to the Treasury, said Wednesday's borrowing figures were "yet more proof of the dire inheritance left to us by the previous government".

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: He said taxpayers’ money was being "wasted on debt interest payments rather than on our public services".

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: A row between Labour and the Conservatives has been rumbling over the current state of the public finances.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: Ms Reeves has previously said the government will have to raise some taxes due to what she claims is a £22bn "hole" in the public finances, left by the previous Conservative government.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: However, the Conservatives have denied this and have instead accused Labour of misleading the public on tax rises.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: As well as the borrowing figures, the ONS revealed the UK's national debt remained at its highest level since the early 1960s last month.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: It said government spent £107.4bn in total this July, £3.5bn more than in the previous July.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: The interest payable on central government debt in July was £7bn, the second highest interest payable for that month since it started recording that data in 1997.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: However, the amount was still lower than the Office for Budget Responsibility, the government's official forecaster, had estimated.

title: Cost of public services drives up UK government borrowing - BBC News
text: The latest ONS spending figures are provisional, so the they could change ahead of the Budget, and prompt different policy decisions.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Over 2,000 workers have applied for voluntary redundancy at Tata Steel’s south Wales sites.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: The majority are based in Port Talbot, where the company plans to close its second blast furnace in a month’s time.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Tata Steel said it had begun assessing whether those who had expressed an interest in taking redundancy were in roles which could be closed.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: The first of 2,800 workers to lose their jobs are expected to leave the business within weeks.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Unions have pledged to ballot their members on whether to accept the redundancy deal, with the first of 2,800 workers expected to leave the company within weeks.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: The redundancy terms are said to be the company’s best ever offer to staff.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Tata Steel will give employees 2.8 weeks’ salary for every year of service, up to a maximum of 25 years.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: They will receive a guaranteed minimum payment of £15,000 and an attendance-related payment of £5,000.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: A Tata spokesperson said: “We are currently working through how people’s aspirations may align with the future organisational structure requirements.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: “Whilst we have made great efforts to put together an employee support package that will help many of those people affected to transition out of the business, it is also vital that we retain our core knowledge, skill base and experience through this most challenging of times.”

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: The three unions representing Tata Steel workers – Community, Unite and the GMB – have previously agreed to give members a vote on whether to accept the redundancy deal. The company said it expected the vote to happen “shortly”.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Union sources expect the deal would be widely supported by staff, following months of discussion with the company.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Tata Steel UK’s restructure will see a total of 2,800 jobs lost across the UK. Around 300 of those will go at Llanwern near Newport in three years’ time, with that cohort of workers yet to be issued any formal redundancy notice.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Of the 2,500 whose jobs are under threat this year, around 300 to 400 are believed to be at risk of compulsory redundancy. The numbers are likely to fluctuate as the company and unions work through the expressions of interest in voluntary redundancy and seek to move those at risk to other parts of the business.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Workers expect the second of two blast furnaces in Port Talbot to be switched off on 28 September, which will end the production of steel from iron ore in south Wales.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Tata plans to build a £1.25bn electric arc furnace, which produces steel by melting scrap metal.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: The UK government is expected to reach a final agreement with Tata Steel over £500m in funding for its electric arc furnace at the beginning of September.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Labour also committed a further £2.5bn towards the future of steelmaking in the UK, and unions have called on the government to commit some of that funding to other investments in south Wales.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: Adding a plate mill or similar technology to the Port Talbot operation, which could produce steel plate for floating offshore wind turbines, is under discussion.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: The Tata Steel spokesperson said the company continued to “work closely with the UK government to finalise discussions” around its investment in steelmaking.

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: They said the existing commitment to end blast furnace production and invest in greener technology “would reduce our carbon emissions by at least five million tonnes a year and support UK steel sovereignty.”

title: Tata Steel: Over 2,000 workers apply for voluntary redundancy - BBC News
text: They added: “We are also working hard with our trades union colleagues to conclude a memorandum of understanding on a range of issues regarding the restructuring of the UK business and our transition to green steel. We hope that our Trades Union partners will be putting this to their members shortly.”

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: Top executives at the 155-year old Campbell Soup Company plan to change the iconic firm's name to The Campbell's Company.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: Chief executive Mark Clouse said the move aims to better reflect Campbell's growing product line, which currently also includes sauces, snacks and beverages.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: Investors are set to vote on the name change at the company's annual meeting in November.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: While canned soup remains a key part of the Campbell's business, the company has sought to adapt to a changing market by acquiring other businesses such as Rao’s sauces maker, Sovos Brands.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: “We will always love soup, and we’ll never take our eye off of this critical business,” Mr Clouse said during the company's investor day. “But today, we’re so much more than soup.”

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: In addition to its most famous line of products, Campbell's portfolio includes other offerings such as Goldfish crackers, Cape Cod crisps, V8 beverages, Prego sauces.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: Mr Clouse said Campbell will only need its soup sales to remain stable for the company to meet its financial targets.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: Other executives noted, however, that soup sales are set to benefit from an aging population in the US, as older people are more likely to eat soup.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: Campbell was the first company to sell canned soup more than a century ago.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: The product served as inspiration for one of American artist Andy Warhol's most iconic pop art works.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: The company estimates its net sales will rise between 9% and 11% in its 2025 fiscal year.

title: Iconic firm Campbell Soup drops soup from name - BBC News
text: Campbell's leaders expect its Goldfish crackers to be a key driver of growth and to ultimately become its largest brand by 2027.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The government generally spends more than it raises in tax.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: To fill this gap it borrows money, but that has to be paid back - with interest - and that can influence wider tax and spending plans.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The government gets most of its income from taxes. For example, workers pay income tax, everyone pays VAT on certain goods, and companies pay tax on their profits.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: It could, in theory, cover all of its spending from taxes, and in some years that happens.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: But if it can't, it will cover the gap by raising taxes, cutting spending or borrowing.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: How the government raises and spends £1 trillion a year

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: Higher taxes mean people have less money to spend, so businesses make less profit, which can be bad for jobs and wages. Lower profits also mean companies pay less tax.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: So, governments often borrow to boost the economy. They also borrow to pay for big projects - such as new railways and roads - which they hope will help the economy.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The government borrows money by selling financial products called bonds.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: A bond is a promise to pay money in the future. Most require the borrower to make regular interest payments over the bond's lifetime.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: UK government bonds - known as "gilts" - are normally considered very safe, with little risk the money will not be repaid.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: Gilts are mainly bought by financial institutions in the UK and abroad, such as pension funds, investment funds, banks and insurance companies.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The Bank of England has also bought hundreds of billions of pounds' worth of government bonds in the past to support the economy, through a process called "quantitative easing".

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The amount the government borrows varies from month to month.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: For instance, when people submit tax returns in January, they often pay a large chunk of their annual tax bill in one go, so the government sees a jump in the amount of money it takes in.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: So it is more helpful to look at the whole year, or the year-to-date.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: In the last financial year, to March 2024, the government borrowed £122.1bn.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The most recent monthly figures show that borrowing was £3.1bn in July, an increase of £1.8bn on the same month last year.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The total amount the government owes is called the national debt. It is currently about £2.7 trillion.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: That is roughly the same as the value of all the goods and services produced in the UK in a year, known as the gross domestic product, or GDP.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: That current level is more than double what was seen from the 1980s through to the financial crisis of 2008.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The combination of the financial crash and the Covid pandemic pushed the UK's debt up from those historic lows to its current level.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: But in relation to the size of the economy, UK debt figures are still low compared with much of the last century, and also compared with some other leading economies.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The larger the national debt gets, the more interest the government has to pay.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: That extra cost was not as big when the interest rates due were low through the 2010s, but it became more noticeable after the Bank of England raised interest rates.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The amount of interest the government pays on national debt fluctuates, and by one measure, hit a 20-year high in early October 2023.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: Around a quarter of UK debt is index-linked, meaning payments are directly linked to the rate of inflation. When inflation rose it pushed up the bill for servicing debt significantly, although these payments are now easing.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: If the government has to set aside more cash for paying its debts, it may mean it has less to spend on the public services which it borrowed to fund in the first place.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: Some economists fear the government is borrowing too much, at too great a cost.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: Others argue extra borrowing helps the economy grow faster - generating more tax revenue in the long run.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: With measures such as a cut in National Insurance announced at the March Budget, the OBR expects borrowing to rise slightly in the next financial year, before remaining in line with previous forecasts.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: It would fall below 3% of GDP by 2025-26, meeting one of the financial rules the previous government decided to set itself.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: But the OBR has previously warned that public debt could soar as the population ages and tax income falls.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: In an ageing population, the proportion of people of working age drops, meaning the government takes less in tax while paying out more in pensions.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: In its latest forecasts in March, the OBR said debt, measured against the size of the economy, is still set to rise over the next four years, before falling back marginally in the fifth year.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: Other economists argue that big economies like the UK could borrow much more than they currently do, and the negative impact is greatly exaggerated.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: The deficit is the gap between the government's income and the amount it spends.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: When a government spends less than its income, it has what is known as a surplus.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: Debt is the total amount of money owed by the government that has built up over years.

title: How much money is the UK government borrowing, and does it matter? - BBC News
text: It rises when there is a deficit, and falls in those years when there is a surplus.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: Boeing's new chief executive Kelly Ortberg has pleaded with workers to not go on strike as it would put the company's "recovery in jeopardy".

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: It comes hours ahead of a crucial union vote that could trigger industrial action at the embattled company.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: The aviation giant's executives and union representatives reached a deal earlier this week that includes a 25% pay rise over four years but it has yet to be approved by union members.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: If workers vote against the agreement it would lead to a second ballot on whether to start a strike as early as Friday.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: "I ask you not to sacrifice the opportunity to secure our future together, because of the frustrations of the past," said Mr Ortberg in his message to staff.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: "Working together, I know that we can get back on track, but a strike would put our shared recovery in jeopardy".

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: On top of the proposed 25% pay rise, the preliminary deal would offer workers improved healthcare and retirement benefits, as well as 12 weeks of paid parental leave.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: It would also include a commitment from Boeing to build its next commercial plane in the Seattle area if the project is started during the lifetime of the contract.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: The union initially targeted a number of improvements to workers' packages, including a 40% pay rise.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: However, it appears the reaction from the 30,000 Boeing workers represented by the union was not entirely positive.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: Union leader and top negotiator, John Holden, said it was not clear whether the deal had enough support among union members to be approved.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: "They are angry," he told the Reuters news agency.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: The current contract between Boeing and the unions was reached in 2008 after an eight-week strike.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: In 2014, the two sides agreed to extend the deal, which is due to expire at midnight on Thursday.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: A rejection of the preliminary agreement between Boeing and its largest union would be a further significant setback for the firm.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: A strike could potentially shut down aircraft production at a time when the company is facing deepening financial losses and struggling to repair its reputation following recent incidents and two fatal accidents five years ago.

title: Boeing boss makes last-ditch plea to workers ahead of strike vote - BBC News
text: It would also be a major blow to Mr Ortberg, an aerospace industry veteran and engineer, who took over as Boeing's chief executive last month with a mission to turn the business around.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: Data centres in the UK are to be classified as critical national infrastructure, joining the emergency services, finance and healthcare systems, and energy and water supplies.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: It means they would get extra government support during a major incident, such as a cyber attack, an IT outage or extreme weather, in order to minimise disruption.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: Data centres are huge warehouses full of vast banks of computers that remotely power services such as artificial intelligence (AI) applications, data processing and streaming.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: Their development has faced criticism over their energy and water use.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: But the new Labour government says it backs the sector - with technology secretary Peter Kyle describing data centres as “the engines of modern life”.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: There are currently 13 sectors listed as critical national infrastructure in the UK. The list was last updated nine years ago, when space and defence were added.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: The previous government launched a consultation in December 2023 to discuss the potential addition of data centres.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: A team of officials will now be set up to specifically monitor potential threats against data centres and coordinate a response in the event of a serious incident, such as the recent worldwide chaos sparked by an update from the cybersecurity firm Crowdstrike, which affected millions of people and businesses.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: However there will not be any new regulations, nor is additional scrutiny of data centre operators’ existing contingency arrangements planned.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: “It’s not surprising that data centres are now to be classed as critical infrastructure as they house so many critical online services,” said Prof Alan Woodward, a cyber security expert from Surrey University.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: “Many people think of services as being in an ethereal cloud, but everything is based at some point on physical infrastructure and more often than not this is based in a data centre.”

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: In 2023 the former deputy Prime Minister Oliver Dowden warned of Russian “attempts to attack British infrastructure".

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: Lindy Cameron, the former boss of the National Cyber Security Centre, said more needed to be done to protect it from cyber threats.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: “Bringing data centres into the Critical National Infrastructure regime will allow better coordination and cooperation with the Government against cyber criminals and unexpected events,” she said.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: The need for data centres is growing, in part because of the proliferation of AI-based services, which require considerable computing power.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: On Wednesday, Amazon Web Services announced it will invest £8bn building and operating data centres in Britain over the next five years.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: Microsoft and Google are separately building their first UK such premises at the moment.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: But environmental concerns about data centres and their demand on resources remain - they are energy-hungry and can require large quantities of water for cooling.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: The chief executive of the National Grid said in March that data centre power use in the UK would increase six-fold in the next decade.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: Plans to build the data centres also often run into local opposition - in June, councillors in Buckinghamshire rejected a proposed development because of its impact on the green belt.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: Bruce Owen from Equinix, which runs data centres in the UK, told the Today Programme, on BBC Radio 4, he was "really encouraged" by the move.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: “The UK, for us, as a global data centre provider, is a critical market," he said.

title: Data centres as vital as NHS and power grid, government says - BBC News
text: “Over our history within the UK we’ve invested over a billion pounds and we’re very encouraged by this signal, and therefore it encourages us to continue to invest and serve our customers in the UK.”

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News
text: An East Yorkshire caravan maker is planning to cut up to 175 jobs.

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News
text: Swift Group said the redundancies were due to a "challenging and difficult trading period" in the caravan and holiday homes sector.

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News
text: The company added: "The organisation has taken the difficult decision to restructure and resize the organisation in order to protect the long-term health of the business.

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News
text: "Following a series of responsible actions which have been deployed over recent months, it is regrettable that this action has become necessary. All employees will be well cared for and respected throughout."

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News
text: The firm was founded in 1964 and it is one of the UK's largest maker of caravans, holiday homes and motorhomes.

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News
text: According to the company's website, it employs 1,300 people and has a turnover in excess of £300m. Its main factory is based in Cottingham.

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News
text: Earlier this year, another East Yorkshire-based holiday homes manufacturer, Willerby, announced it was cutting 131 jobs.

title: East Yorkshire caravan maker announces up to 175 job losses - BBC News

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: Qantas will refund or downgrade hundreds of passengers who were sold first-class flights at a huge discount last week because of a coding error.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: "Unfortunately, this is a case where the fare was actually too good to be true," a spokesperson for the Australian airline said.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: On Thursday, when the erroneous offer was put up on its site, around 300 people quickly booked return flights between Australia and the US, paying 85% less than the usual first class fare.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: Qantas said it will switch passengers who bought the bargain tickets into business class - one step down from first class - "at no additional cost".

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: Customers paid a fraction of the usual price, with the discounted fares available on the site for about eight hours.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: That meant they would have paid a few thousand Australian dollars for tickets that are meant to cost more than AUD20,000 (£10,000), entitling them to whiskey and champagne, an à la carte food menu, plus a memory foam mattress and a "pillow menu" when they want to sleep.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: However, the airline's terms and conditions state when customers book that if there is an error or mistake that is reasonably obvious in the fare price, the airline is entitled to cancel the booking and offer a full refund.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: "As a gesture of goodwill, we’re rebooking customers in business class at no additional cost. Customers also have the option of a full refund," Qantas said in a statement.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: A passenger travelling business class would still be paying 65% less than usual for their ticket, the airline said.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: It's not the first time an airline has mistakenly offered discount prices - in 2019, Cathay Pacific accidentally sold $16,000 business-class seats for $675. In the end, it did honour the tickets for those lucky passengers.

title: Qantas accidentally offers cheap first-class fares - BBC News
text: But airlines don't always honour tickets sold mistakenly for cheap: in 2018, British Airways cancelled tickets to Dubai and Tel Aviv which were sold for £1 instead of £200.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: A fudge maker said her business had been "devastated" after its Instagram account, used to promote its products, was suspended without notice.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: Claire Brennan, who owns Want That Fudge in Scunthorpe, said the account had been running for 10 years and had more than 93,000 followers.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: Mrs Brennan said the platform was vital for her business and helped to generate sales from customers across the UK.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: A spokesperson for Meta, the parent company for Instagram and Facebook, told the BBC it was "investigating the issue".

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: Mrs Brennan said: "I'm so frustrated because that account shows a huge chunk of our company history so having that audience taken away is soul destroying.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: "We share pictures of fudge and chocolate. We haven't done anything wrong and we don't understand why the account is suspended."

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: Mrs Brennan, who runs the business with her husband Pete, said she created a backup account but that was also removed.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: "We've been trying for weeks to appeal the decision and there's been no support from Meta. We've sent emails and messages and had no response.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: "If we could just speak to a human being, they'd see it's a mistake."

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: The closure of the Instagram account is a further blow to the business which was forced to temporarily close in August after its premises on Birkdale Road was targeted by vandals.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: Mrs Brennan said: "It just feels like we're having a string of bad luck at the moment.

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
text: "We're a small business. It's annoying, but the main thing is we still have our shop and we're still able to get orders out all over the country."

title: Scunthorpe fudge maker devastated by Instagram account suspension - BBC News
